PETITION.TITLE: Housing Loan Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That we oppose the deregulation of housing interest rates without adequate safeguards to protect homebuyers.
2. That we condemn the Government for breaking its unequivocal promise not to deregulate these interest rates.
3. We express our concern that the Government's decision will cause undue hardship to many Australian families.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should:
urge the Government to reverse its decision and re-impose the interest rate ceiling.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

That we strongly support ``The A.C.T. Smoking and Tobacco Products Advertisements Prohibition Bill'' introduced by Senator Evans, because it represents the first positive national step towards the eventual elimination of wide spread serious ill health caused by smoking tobacco.

PETITION.TITLE: Television Standards
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate, of the Parliament of Australia assembled.

We, the undersigned, plead that Parliament becomes aware that the Public has no legal right to influence the setting of Standards for Television Programming, that we deplore the new Standards which came into force on 1st February, and that we call on Parliament to amend the Broadcasting and Television Act 1942, section 16 (2), so that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, when determining Television Standards, and screening hours, shall consult with the Australian people:
because at present the Tribunal is compelled by law to consult only with television stations on these matters,
because the new standards are a result of such consultation, and have already been implemented without public discussion,
because the new Standards are ambiguous, and without definition,
because the new Standards are composed of modifying terms which circumvent the proscriptions,
because the media is only motivated by aspirations of pecuniary superiority,
because, in contrast, the public is only motivated by their wish to exercise pastoral care over the nurturing home environment of their children,
because we believe that the Standards wrongly ascribe extreme importance to ``the storyline'' of a film screened,

because we believe that the Standards wrongly ascribe total unimportance to the effects of viewing, especially violent films, on the young, the impressionable, the immature, the unstable, or the socially disadvantaged,
because we refuse to accept the media-imposed assessment of community standards,
and because we wish to impart our demand to be consulted, our demand to have legal status in decision-making, and the right to counsel those whose decisions so deeply affect our homes.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you will give this matter your earnest attention.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Vigor) agreed to:
That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to terminate provisions in Acts which appropriate money without specifying the amount appropriated.
Bill presented by Senator Vigor, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
Purpose
The purpose of this Bill is to increase the accountability of the Public Service and statutory authorities to the people of Australia.
Background
Section 83 of the Constitution provides that no money shall be drawn from the Treasury of the Commonwealth except under appropriation made by law.

Currently, each year the Parliament receives a budget for the year's expenses from the government. It then approves appropriation of funds to meet this budget through Appropriation Bills Nos. 1 and 2, and usually further Appropriation Bills in the course of the year.

All appropriations come under scrutiny in the Senate by the Senate Estimates committees, which make recommendations to the Senate for consideration during debate on the Appropriation Bills. The Parliament, in debating the annual appropriations, in fact only regularly debates and approves expenditure under the Appropriation Bills Nos. 1 and 2, together with the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill, whose appropriation was until 1982-83 included in the Appropriation Bills Nos. 1 and 2.
Appropriation Bill No. 1 is the appropriation for recurrent expenditure of the Public Service as well as grants made to other people and organisations to achieve the aims of government.

Appropriation Bill No. 2 is the appropriation for capital works and expenditure of a capital nature by the Public Service, as well as capital grants made to other people and organisations by the government.

These two Bills together account for an ever diminishing part of the actual expenditure by government each year. The major part of the Budget is expenditure called `special appropriations', which for 1985-86 amounted to $47,470.3m, or 68.7 per cent of total Budget outlays.
Special Appropriations

Special appropriations result from expenditure on matters provided for by specific Acts of Parliament. For example, States grants, including some for distribution to local government, are negotiated by the government independently of the Parliament, and then approved by Parliament.

The States Grants (Universities) Acts, the Universities (Financial Assistance) Acts, the States Grants (Advanced Education) Acts, the States Grants (Teachers Colleges) Acts, the States Grants (Pre-School Teachers Colleges) Acts, the States Grants (Science Laboratories and Technical Training) Acts followed by the States Grants (Technical Training) Acts and the States Grants (Technical Training Fees Reimbursement) Act, and by the States Grants (Science Laboratories) Acts, the States Grants (Secondary School Libraries) Act, the States Grants (Capital Assistance) Act, the States Grants (Independent Schools) Acts followed by the States Grants (Schools) Acts, and the States Grants (Capital Assistance) Acts are all Acts of Parliament dealing with special appropriations relating to Federal payments to assist the States with education costs.
Most of these Acts come regularly before Parliament for amendment, sometimes twice in one year, and are considered by Parliament outside the normal budget and appropriations procedures.

Similar Bills come regularly before the Parliament for States grants for health, social security and welfare, unemployment relief, housing assistance, transport, water supply and electricity, industry assistance and research grants. Other Bills in this category appropriate money for certain statutory authorities, for payments to holders of public office, for bounties and subsidies, and so on.
Continuing Provisions

These Bills appropriate the money necessary for the purposes of the Acts in a number of ways, either by direct annual amounts indexed for cost of living increases, by triennial funding arrangements, by rolling triennial funding according to predictions based on five-year plans, by matching States, local government or private funding on a dollar for dollar or some other basis, or by meeting specific needs as they arise.

A number of the Acts in force which contain continuing provisions, appropriate the money necessary for the purpose of the Acts without specifying any limitation on the amount appropriated. These continuing and unspecified appropriations are known as standing or special appropriations. Because they have continuing effect, the provision of the money to be expended under them is not subject to annual scrutiny and renewal by Parliament.

The proportion of government outlays which only irregularly, though sometimes frequently, come before Parliament has been increasing regularly over the years. In 1973-74, 58.3 per cent of government outlays were by special appropriation, while this year around 70 per cent of outlays are by special appropriation. This means that around 70 per cent of government expenditure will escape scrutiny and renewal by the Parliament. Only 30 per cent of government expenditure is subject to a deliberate parliamentary decision that authority for the expenditure be granted.

(a) `Special Appropriations' includes special appropriations out of the Consolidated Revenue Fund as well as net payments out of the Loan Fund, net movements in Trust Funds and various other expenditures not covered by the Appropriation Bills.

The figures in the Table show the Budget estimates for each year. That is, the `Total Budget Outlays' in any year are the Budget estimates for that year rather than the actual outlays. This approach has been taken for two reasons:
(1) Because data on the split-up between `Special Appropriations' and appropriations under the Appropriation Bills are only readily available in respect of Budget estimates; and
(2) Because the estimates are what come under scrutiny by the Estimates Committees.

Standing or special appropriations are an unnecessary restriction on Parliament's ability to control the financial destiny of Australia. Many of the Acts which do specify ceilings on expenditure come regularly before Parliament to have these ceilings revised as circumstances change. Some of the Acts which require the expenditure of money for their operation provide that the necessary funds are to be appropriated by the Parliament in a separate Act, and the money required is included in the annual appropriation Bills. There is no reason for not providing for all government expenditure in this way.
Function of this Bill

This Bill has the effect of abolishing all existing standing or special appropriations, and requiring that the money needed for the operation of all Acts be appropriated annually and as required by the Parliament. The budgets are now estimated yearly, and they include both ordinary and special appropriations. However, Parliament does not currently have any direct input into the process of reviewing them.
Timing

The Act is timed to come into effect on 1 July 1987. This means that funds required for the operation of the various Acts affected by the Bill need to be included in the annual Supply and Appropriation Bills for the 1987-88 year, and all subsequent financial years. All provisions in Acts which appropriate unspecified amounts of money will cease to have effect as from 1 July 1987.
Parliamentary Scrutiny

Executive government and Public Service seem intent on bypassing the parliamentary processes. Such an attempt has occupied much of Parliament's time this week. For the second year in succession, the Government has presented Parliament with a loans Bill which would allow it to borrow year after year without referring to the Parliament.

The Standing Appropriations Abolition Bill is a move in the other direction, towards re-establishing the power of the Parliament, and accountability to the people, breaking down the Yes Minister syndrome of control by top public servants and executive government. This is a Bill designed to reinforce democracy in Australia.

The advantages for all Australians from the Parliament making a proper examination of the annual accounts of the nation are obvious. Currently, when only such a small proportion of outlays is under full parliamentary scrutiny, there is little ability to weigh the importance of one program against another. In fact, it is possible for a policy decision made years ago, and which has since been revised, to be left in place because of the inability of Parliament to reconsider the matter in the perspective of total government spending. Unless a provision is brought regularly to the notice of Parliament, it may well languish, or worse still prosper, `out of sight and out of mind'. We have many quaint legislative reminders of the past lying in the statute books.

I remind honourable senators of the Honey (Export Inspection Charge) Bill 1984, which came to light in a routine attempt to raise money by increasing all rural produce inspection levies. On investigation resulting from questions raised by my Australian Democrats colleague, Senator Michael Macklin, it was found that no country to which Australia exports honey has any requirement for inspection of honey. As a result the levy was dropped. Without that scrutiny, and in fact without the request for an amendment to that Act, honey producers in Australia would still be paying that export inspection levy.

How much of our current government expenditure is still being wasted on out-of-date requirements, and is not coming under regular scrutiny because the relevant appropriation is a standing or special appropriation hidden in an Act which does not need to be regularly amended by Parliament?

Likewise, how much parliamentary time is wasted in regular amendment of individual small appropriations at random times throughout the year, when they should be considered in the overall Budget context?
Conclusion
In `hard times', such as we are told by the Government we live in, we must be careful to review all expenditure, so that we can prune out luxuries, stop waste and put an end to monetary peccadillos.

This Bill will have the effect of increasing the effectiveness of Parliament's scrutiny of public expenditure, and of increasing the efficiency and effectiveness with which the appropriations are considered.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: INDEPENDENT AND MULTICULTURAL BROADCASTING CORPORATION BILL 1986INDEPENDENT AND MULTICULTURAL BROADCASTING CORPORATION (TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS AND CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motions (by Senator Vigor)-by leave-agreed to:
That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to establish an Independent and Multicultural Broadcasting Corporation, and for related purposes.

That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to enact certain transitional provisions and make certain amendments in consequence of the enactment of the Independent and Multicultural Broadcasting Corporation Act 1986, and for related purposes.
Bills presented by Senator Vigor, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have my second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows-
Purpose

The purpose of these two Bills is to establish a solid and sympathetic legislative framework for the SBS to guarantee the continuance of its work in developing a strong, independent, multicultural broadcasting service in Australia. The two Bills should be considered cognately, since the first Bill establishes the Independent and Multicultural Broadcasting Corporation, while the second Bill provides the legislative means for handing over SBS functions to the new IMBC.
Background

The Connor report into `Serving Multicultural Australia-The Role of Broadcasting' proposed that the SBS be given independent legislative status through the establishment of a Multicultural Broadcasting Corporation to carry out the multicultural broadcasting functions of SBS. This Bill implements the relevant proposals of the Connor report, by establishing the Independent and Multicultural Broadcasting Corporation, and giving to this Corporation the necessary functions, powers and resources for continuing the development of multicultural broadcasting throughout Australia.
The functions considered to be essential by the Connor Committee of Review of the Special Broadcasting Service included:
The provision both of ethnic radio, through 2EA and 3EA, and of multicultural television through Channel 0/28;
the support or creation of ethnic public broadcasting stations wherever in Australia there is sufficient community interest and support;

the distribution of programs to the ABC and public stations, and provision of access on Channel 0/28 to local public television groups, so that locally-relevant programs are available to people of all ethnic origins throughout Australia to maintain their language and cultural inheritance;

the funding of public broadcasting through the Public Broadcasting Foundation, and support for public broadcasters through the supply of networked news, current affairs, features and information programs to broadcast on their stations, and the offer of access for broadcasting their programs on SBS stations.

It is to endorse these latter functions of caring for public broadcasters, and to emphasise the independence of the IMBC in its policies, that we have included the term `independent' in the title of the new Independent and Multicultural Broadcasting Corporation. We have followed the recommendation of the Connor Committee by giving the IMBC responsibility for funding all public broadcasters rather than just the ethnic public broadcasters. This avoids unnecessary duplication of funding provisions.
Objects
The objects of the Independent and Multicultural Broadcasting Corporation are:

To co-ordinate multicultural and multilingual broadcasting services for the advantage of the Australian community as a whole as well as our component ethnic and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities;
to help the ethnic and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities in Australia to maintain their language and develop their culture;
to promote mutual understanding and tolerance between all Australians through an understanding and appreciation of the diverse cultures within Australia;

to develop public broadcasting services throughout Australia, funded through the Public Broadcasting Foundation, and supported by provision of program material to broadcasters and access for public television groups to broadcast their television programs on Channel 0/28.
Australia a Multicultural Society

Over 40 per cent of all Australians were either born overseas, or have at least one parent born overseas. Over 60 per cent of all Australians have at least one grandparent of non-Anglo-Celtic ethnic origin, and most likely have some experience of a language and culture of non-English origin. The only ethnic groups which have long established cultural roots in Australia are the Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders, who today are almost foreigners in their own land.

The only country in the world with a higher proportion of overseas-born citizens is Israel. In Israel, cohesion of the population is achieved through a common religious identity and culture. In Australia, we have no such common bond.

Yet a strong independent Australia can be achieved through a united multicultural society, in which every person is part of a cohesive whole society, has a strong cultural identity and self value, enjoys equality of opportunity and access to resources, and shares equal responsibility for, commitment to, and participation in society. These principles are the essential elements of multiculturalism, which recognises the strength in diversity of experience and unity of purpose.
Discrimination Still Exists

Australia today does not yet enjoy the benefits of a truly multicultural society, as is evident in this Parliament, where the representation of Anglo-Celtic ethnic people far exceeds that of people of other ethnic origins. We no longer have any representative in this place of the Aboriginal people. Our law, our public service, and our media show a similar discrimination against people of non-Anglo-Celtic ethnic origins.

Throughout Australian society we see similar discrimination against migrant and Aboriginal people. In 1983 the Committee of Review of the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs reported some of the effects of being disadvantaged, second-class citizens as:

. . . increasing evidence of psychiatric and other health problems, industrial disputes and the exposure of appalling work conditions, and more generally . . . the sense of restlessness, apathy and disillusionment among large sections of the migrant population.

The Henderson Commission of Inquiry into Poverty identified lack of access to information as a major cause of poverty among migrants, and it was in large part to remedy this problem that the SBS was originally given the charter to sponsor ethnic broadcasting services.
Special Broadcasting Service

In 1980 the Ethnic Television Review Panel reported the need to establish an Independent and Multicultural Broadcasting Corporation under its own Act of Parliament, and legislation to achieve this was drawn up and widely circulated for comment throughout the community. The government, however, finally succumbed to the pressure of entrenched interests and dropped its legislation, and gave the SBS the job of introducing multicultural services by regulation, without an independent charter from Parliament.

The success of the SBS to date has been outstanding, and it is probably for this very reason that pressure is now on the Government to pull its teeth and absorb it within the ABC, where multicultural programming would have to compete with the other interest groups served by the ABC.

The SBS has expanded the role of the ethnic radio stations in serving individual ethnic language communities. The ethnic radio stations in Sydney and Melbourne, 2EA and 3EA, are the communication lifeline for a number of isolated migrants in those cities and a link to their cultural heritage.

SBS has introduced television broadcasts of foreign language programs with English subtitles, English language programs of wide community interest, and excellent world news and current affairs services. It has developed a policy of employing people of diverse ethnic origins, and has been an innovative broadcaster.

It has done much to increase communication and understanding between Australians of different backgrounds, and thus to foster equality of opportunity for all. However, just as it is still necessary to legislate for equal opportunity for women in the workforce, the separate multicultural broadcasting service remains necessary until people of all ethnic backgrounds achieve equal status and opportunities in society.
Multiculturalism under Attack

The Government, however, is moving in the other direction, ignoring its policy commitment to multiculturalism. This is being demonstrated not only in the proposal to merge the SBS with the ABC, but also in the concerted attack on all the programs which educate, inform and enhance the status of migrants in Australia.

The closure of the independent and ethnically egalitarian Institute of Multicultural Affairs in Melbourne and its replacement by a body within the Public Service in Canberra is a sheer pretence at meeting the needs of migrants, most of whom live in Melbourne, Sydney and the other State capitals. It also goes directly against the recommendation of the Jupp Committee of Review of Migrant and Multicultural Programs and Services.

Withdrawal of funding for the English as a second language teaching program is a kick in the teeth for newly-arrived migrants, and the Federal Government is hiding behind the States by suggesting that State governments fund it out of their other educational allowances. The Commonwealth is avoiding its responsibility.
This Bill now gives the Parliament a chance to prove its commitment to multiculturalism.
Control of the Media

The current control of broadcast media is highly centralised, with too little participation by local, regional and State community bodies, and too little account taken of the specific needs of the various subcultures in Australia. Such uniformity leads to vulnerability, bigotry and rigidity within the community, none of which Australia can afford.

The combination of national, ethnic broadcasting, public and special interest broadcasting under the umbrella of the IMBC will help to balance the domination of the commercial media by a few large centralised networks. It will also increase familiarity with things foreign, to give Australians confidence and knowledge to cope with changing circumstances.

By encouraging the study of the languages, cultures and ideologies of our ethnic communities we enhance their identity and acceptability to other groups, making Australians conscious and proud of the values of the minority groups to which they belong. By providing real two-way access through the media we encourage a broader group involvement in the planning, production and presentation of programs. The richness of Australia's culture depends on diversity, breadth and depth of common understanding and interests.
Democrats Oppose SBS-ABC Merger

The Government plans to merge the SBS with the ABC. There are many cogent reasons for keeping the multicultural broadcasting function independent of the ABC over the immediate future. This Bill enshrines in law the essence of an independent SBS and fulfils the commitments of Liberal, Labor and Democrat policies for multicultural broadcasting.

The role of the SBS as an equal opportunity employer with special affirmative action with respect to Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders could not be matched by the ABC at this stage, because the ABC has an established work force that is quite unrepresentative of the multicultural nature of Australian society, due in large part to its emphasis in the past on English culture. The SBS employs over 40 per cent staff of other than Anglo-Celtic ethnic origin, which corresponds roughly to those proportions in the Australian community as a whole.
No Cost Savings Overall

Similarly, in the short term, the costs of integrating the two organisations would be likely to far outweigh any benefits of economy of scale or of shared facilities. There is no tangible evidence of the $2m which the Government claims will be saved-in fact, the opposite appears to be the case.

Currently the SBS has a different system of staff tenure and conditions, which would be costly to integrate into the ABC system. The SBS is covered by a number of unions, and integration into the ABC with its strong staff union could well introduce industrial unrest over the initial period.

The SBS has also succeeded in negotiating contracts with overseas program suppliers on a much more favourable basis than the ABC has been able to achieve, and in Australian dollars rather than overseas currencies. Integration with the ABC would bring with it a cost penalty in this major area of SBS operations. The supplementary estimates earlier this year bear this out completely.

In fact, while there is undoubtedly scope for savings in staff numbers, services and facilities, the higher cost structure of the ABC makes the possibility of real savings most unlikely. A comparison of the annual budgets of the two organisations underlines this very cogently:

The annual budget of the ABC last year was around $430m, out of which the ABC supported two radio networks, one with mainly national programming, a rural service, and one television network Australia-wide;

The annual budget of the SBS was around $47m, out of which the SBS supported two radio stations in Sydney and Melbourne with mainly local programming, and one television network in all Australian capital cities, and in major regional population centres.
The annual budget of the public broadcasting sector from all sources of revenue was under $8m for the same period.
The Public Broadcasting Sector

Public broadcasting is the most cost-effective of the non-commercial broadcasting services, and this is obviously a major reason for the Connor report's recommending expansion of ethnic broadcasting through the public broadcasting stations.

With the integration of some public broadcasting funding into the new IMBC, the cost structure of ethnic broadcasting is likely to continue at well under that of the ABC, and its different ethos will be maintained.

Support for public broadcasting comes from the community in several ways: From audience subscriptions, from work done voluntarily, from donations, from sponsorship of programming by commercial and private organisations, and from government funding.

The Public Broadcasting Foundation was established by the Public Broadcasting Association of Australia to administer funding for public broadcasters. When in opposition, the Government promised to provide a capital grant for public broadcasting which would be administered by the Public Broadcasting Foundation as a trust fund. The trust would have invested the moneys vested in it, and from the earnings supported public broadcasting initiatives in Australia. In this way, taxpayers funds would have been preserved, and the public broadcasting sector would have become independent from government funding and isolated to some extent from annual budgetary variations. This capital grant has not eventuated-another broken promise.

The extent of government support for public broadcasting is slight with no increase in this year's allocation of just over $1m. For the most part, public radio in this country operates under chronic financial stress, despite all efforts to raise funds in innovative ways, or through `sponsorship'.

This Bill transfers to the Independent and Multicultural Broadcasting Corporation the responsibility for funding public broadcasting. Through the Public Broadcasting Foundation the IMBC has responsibility for sponsoring public, ethnic and Aboriginal broadcasting services. It is also directly responsible for providing news, current affairs and general programs to both public broadcasters and the ABC, so that ethnic communities Australia-wide have access to locally-relevant programs in order to maintain their language and culture.
Public Television

Public broadcasting includes both public radio as we now enjoy it, and also public television. Public television is a significant part of the television services available in the USA, and its development in Australia has been advocated for a long time.

The Green inquiry recommended in 1976 that we provide for public television, catering for special interests such as education, community, and ethnic programs. It suggested starting public television services in the UHF band from 1981 onwards. In 1977, amendments were passed to the broadcasting legislation to include definitions of public broadcasting and public television.

Public television, which requires a larger capital investment, also has greater organisational infrastructure expenses and significantly higher costs in program acquisition and production. Its viability depends on having a significantly higher level of funding than public radio. It is simply not feasible for a public television service to operate on a similar financial basis to public radio. A more flexible and much broader revenue base is necessary.

Finance for public television will have to come from one or both of the only two financially significant areas of the economy-from the government or from commercial organisations through advertising. While government may be prepared to provide initial capital grants for equipment and developmental assistance, this source of funding cannot be seen as continuing in the long term.

This leaves some form of advertising as the only source of ongoing funds for public television. For this reason we have included in the powers of the IMBC under this Bill the ability to raise money by advertising, to the extent that this does not interfere in meeting its obligations to the community under the Act, and to the extent allowed by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal.

Under current legislation, public television licensees have the same advertising guidelines as commercial television stations, whereas public radio stations are limited in the sponsorship announcements they can broadcast.
An alternative funding source could be a levy on the advertising revenue earned by the commercial radio and television stations.
Community Access

Another means or providing community access to television broadcasting is through licensed channel sharing. Currently both the ABC and the SBS do not broadcast continuously throughout the day. This `downtime' could be profitably used by licensed public television services for developing innovative forms of television such as telemarketing, and for broadcasting community-based programs.

In this way, public television services can share existing facilities, and get off the ground for a smaller capital outlay. Both the ABC and the SBS have been approached by public television associations about providing this type of co- operative service. The ABC has decided not to do this, but the first regular broadcasts of public television through the SBS community-access `windows' are scheduled to start early next year.

These community-access windows on Channel 28 are yet another innovative way in which the SBS has been exploring its role in developing diverse multicultural broadcasting throughout Australia. This Bill provides a firm legislative support for their initiatives in this area.
Community Benefits from Public Broadcasting

The work done by the public broadcasters in teaching communication skills is a strong justification for claiming support from the commercial and national broadcasters, since both of these sectors of the broadcasting industry recruit heavily from the ranks of public broadcasters and are able to avoid training expenses on the scale of ten years ago.

The public broadcasting sector offers training in communications to over 20,000 volunteers. The professional nature of the commercial and national broadcasting organisations makes it very difficult for them to provide training on such a large scale, and the academic prerequisites for courses through the education system close off this vital area of literacy for the underprivileged people in our community. Communication skills are a major step towards social equality and equity.
Public radio has also been the lifeblood for many Australian musicians.
Aboriginal Television

The recent award of a remote commercial television services licence to Imparja Television is an outcome of video and television production work by the Central Australian Aboriginal Media Association over a number of years. CAAMA has contributed significantly to increasing effective communication skills among Aboriginal people.

Encouraged by the Institute of Aboriginal Studies remote television project, the Aboriginal communities at Yuendumu, 300 kilometres north-west of Alice Springs, and at Ernabella in South Australia, developed their own television production resources. In 1985, seemingly unable to acquire any form of television licence through the Department of Communications, they went ahead and transmitted their own television locally without a licence. Eventually an embarrassed Department gave them experimental licences under the Radiocommunications Act.

In this way these enterprising, and in effect, de facto public television stations are the first public television stations to get off the ground in Australia. They have proved that public television can be run on a shoe-string budget.

I visited the facilities at Ernabella recently, and was impressed with the quality of programming and consistency of service achieved using equipment which cost about as much as an average home video camera outfit. Their programs are now being marketed and shown worldwide, although their small budget severely hampers their work in editing their program footage for commercial marketing.

These productions on Aboriginal life and culture are a bridge between the cultures of old and new Australia, and they will prove to be of incalculable value in the years to come, for their innovative techniques, their artistic merit and their cultural integrity.

We look forward to similar originality and success as other public television stations follow in their footsteps. The flexibility and youth of the SBS-IMBC will promote a freedom of operation for these public broadcasters which will allow a truly experimental Australian television art to flourish, free of the bureaucratic constraints which have developed over many years in the ABC.
Cooperation between the IMBC and the ABC

In their work for the Connor Committee, the consultants Peat Marwick considered that an immediate merger between the SBS and the ABC would be administratively difficult. The differing corporate ethos and the unwillingness of SBS staff to merge further adds to these difficulties. Economies can be achieved much more effectively by a program of co-operation and sharing of resources, while maintaining the separate identities and economic attitudes of the two organisations.

This legislation requires the IBMC to co-operate closely with the ABC, with the ethnic broadcasters and with the public broadcasters in sharing services and programs. It also stipulates that the IMBC shall operate to minimise its demands on the public purse by maximising its opportunities to produce revenue through broadcasting of such advertisements as are allowed by the Broadcasting Tribunal, while having regard to the proper performance of its functions.
The Independent and Multicultural Broadcasting Corporation Bill also requires the Corporation to take account of standards set by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal.

The powers given to the IMBC in this Bill are comparable to those which the ABC enjoys, with additional functions to allow it to perform its roles in funding and supporting public broadcasting and in providing access on its television channels to public broadcasters. It is also allowed to broadcast advertisements in order to maximise its revenue raising capacity to the extent permitted by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal.
Administration of the IMBC

A Board is established to determine policy, to oversee the performance of the Corporation, and to maintain the independence and integrity of the Corporation while taking into consideration the policy of the Commonwealth government as it is from time to time expressed to the Board. The duties of the Board and of the Managing Director are similar to those laid down for the ABC, and similar provisions are also made for staff, finances, technical services and application of the Broadcasting Act. The Chairperson, the Deputy Chairperson and ordinary members of the Board shall be appointed by the Governor-General to ensure that the membership of the Board reflects the diversity of communities within Australia, and shall hold office on a part time basis for no longer than five years. In addition, the Board shall include a staff-elected member or his deputy, and the Managing Director of the Corporation. The Bill also provides for a national consultative and State consultative committees, as well as ad hoc advisory committees to be established by the Board.
Transition Arrangements from SBS to IMBC

The Independent and Multicultural Broadcasting Corporation (Transitional Provisions) Bill 1986 provides for the handover of staff, property, powers, liabilities, contracts, proceedings, duties and moneys from the SBS to the Corporation.

It also includes amendments to the Archives Act 1983, the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Act 1983, the Broadcasting Act 1942, the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918, the Copyright Act 1968, the Freedom of Information Act 1982, the Radiocommunications Act 1983, the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act 1984, the Telecommunications Act 1975, the Trade Practices Act 1974, and the Public Service Regulations to replace references to the Special Broadcasting Service with references to the Independent and Multicultural Broadcasting Corporation.
Conclusion
I reiterate the main objects of the Independent and Multicultural Broadcasting Corporation Bill and its companion transition Arrangements Bill:

(a) To contribute to the development of a multicultural society through the provision of broadcasting services of a high standard which promote mutual understanding, appreciation and acceptance of the diverse cultures within the Australian population and which, through the encouragement of the study of the languages, traditions and ideologies of those cultures, foster within their members a sense of cultural identity and pride; and
(b) to facilitate community access to the broadcasting media through broader group involvement in the planning, production and presentation of programs;
(c) to provide a smooth transition from the SBS to the IMBC.

These two Bills follow the recommendations of the Connor Committee of Review in establishing an Independent and Multicultural Broadcasting Corporation, to co-ordinate existing ethnic, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander broadcasting services, and to develop public broadcasting services throughout Australia, for the advantage of the Australian community as a whole as well as our component cultural communities.

They establish the right media structure for a strong, independent, multicultural Australia-the Australian Broadcasting Corporation complemented by a vibrant new Independent and Multicultural Broadcasting Corporation as national broadcasters, a regional and urban commercial broadcasting sector, and a secure, voluntary, and enthusiastic public broadcasting structure.
I commend the Bills to the Senate.

The Customs Tariff Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1986 which is now before the Senate proposes the removal of the 2 per cent revenue duty applicable to imports from general tariff sources under item 71.07 in Schedule 3 to the Customs Tariff Act 1982. This item covers gold, including platinum-plated gold, unwrought or semi-manufactured. The removal of the duty is to take effect on the third day after the legislation receives the royal assent. The main commodity involved in the removal of the revenue duty is gold bullion. It is accepted by the Government that the duty is impeding the development of the Australian gold market by restricting imports and preventing the necessary liquidity in periods of peak demand. SALES TAX (EXEMPTIONS AND CLASSIFICATIONS) AMENDMENT BILL 1986

During his Budget Speech the Treasurer announced, as part of the 1986-87 Budget, a number of changes to the scope of the present wholesale sales tax system to operate from midnight on 19 August 1986. This Bill, and two others I will introduce shortly, will amend the sales tax law to give effect to those changes. Given the comments already made by the Treasurer in his Budget Speech and the details contained in Statement No. 4 of Budget Paper No. 1 and the explanatory memorandum being circulated to Honourable Senators, I will do no more than outline briefly the changes proposed.

First, the rate of sales tax on alcoholic wine and cider and other similar fermented alcoholic beverages is to be increased from 10% to 20%. Secondly, certain presently exempt non-alcoholic beverages are to be taxed at the 10% rate. These include packaged flavoured milk, non-alcoholic wine and cider and similar beverages and, broadly, all non-carbonated fruit juice products containing not less than 25% by volume of Australian fruit juice.

Another change concerns the rate of sales tax payable on `luxury' motor cars and station wagons, including four-wheel drive vehicles. Where the wholesale price for sales tax purposes of such vehicles exceeds $19,892, sales tax will be levied at the top rate of 30%. The amount of $19,892 is the tax-exclusive wholesale price, on which sales tax is calculated, equivalent to a $29,646 retail price. This latter amount is the present upper cost limit on which depreciation is allowable on motor cars and station wagons for income tax purposes. This amount will be adjusted each 1 July in line with the indexation adjustment to the income tax depreciation limit.

Finally, Mr President, the Bill will correct a number of anomalies and inconsistencies in the various schedules to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act. The main changes are-all swimming pools, spa pools, spa baths and hot tubs and accessories, which are currently exempt from tax or subject to tax at only 10%, will become taxable at 20%; the tax payable on certain film and video recordings will increase from 10% to 20%; household fittings and sanitary ware will be subject to tax at the same rate as other household items, namely 10%; the rate of tax on gardening and industrial hand tools and machinery for business or industrial use will be increased to 20%; negatives, transparencies and film strips that are produced from exposed film, will be brought within the sales tax base, at the 20% rate; purchases of computers, calculators and other scientific equipment by individuals such as teachers, students and others for use in schools or universities will no longer be tax exempt. but such purchases by schools and universities themselves will remain exempt; all aircraft, including hot air balloons and other similar aircraft, are to be eligible for exemption from sales tax if used for business or industrial purposes; and, finally, several exemption items will be amended to confirm the scope of exemptions currently reflected in decisions of the Commissioner of Taxation. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
SALES TAX LAWS AMENDMENT BILL 1986

This Bill will amend Sales Tax Assessment Acts (Nos 1 to 10) and the Sales Tax Regulations. The specific changes are as follows: The value of computer software has traditionally formed part of the sales tax base where its value has been reflected in the selling price of goods on which it is contained. However, in recent times those marketing such goods have, purportedly to protect copyright, used the technique of licensing the use of the software, thus separating its value for sales tax purposes from its carrying medium, for example, a disc or tape, which alone has minimal value.

The Government could not stand idly by and allow this erosion of the sales tax base, nor permit its spread to other areas such as the marketing of sound recordings or videos. Measures in this Bill will ensure that the value of computer software, sounds or visual images when licensed separately from the carrying medium is brought back within the sales tax base.

As the Treasurer has already indicated in his Budget Speech, `in-house' production of software will not be affected by these changes, nor will software produced for export. Software acquired as an aid-to-manufacture will also remain eligible for exemption. The Bill does not seek to tax the electronic transfer of software by means of the telephone system or satellite communications. The Government will, however, be giving further consideration to this question.

The Bill will also change the sales tax treatment of swimming pools that are constructed on site. In the past, these pools, which are at the top end of the market, were not subject to sales tax. From midnight on 19 August 1986, the construction of the container or shell of such swimming pools will be treated as the manufacture of goods for sales tax purposes and subject to tax at the rate of 20 per cent.

Until now the process of developing exposed photographic film did not constitute manufacture for sales tax purposes. This Bill will change that. The price charged for developing exposed film will be taxed at 20 per cent.

Finally, the Bill will bring the sales tax law into line with the Customs law, by ensuring that goods imported into Australia on a temporary basis may be entered for home consumption `tax-free', where they will be for use in connection with an America's Cup yacht race in Australia or the bicentennial celebrations.
The explanatory memorandum being circulated to honourable senators also contains detailed explanations of the technical aspects of this Bill. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON SCIENCE, TECHNOLOGY AND THE ENVIRONMENT

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Haines, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the following matter be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Science, Technology and the Environment:
The treatment of food by irradiation in Australia and, in particular:
(a) the health and nutritional implications of food irradiation;
(b) the associated storage, transport and disposal of nuclear materials;
(c) the environmental impact of food irradiation plants;
(d) the economics of food irradiation;
(e) the adequacy of current and proposed Federal, State and local laws covering food irradiation and associated activities;
(f) the importation and exportation of irradiated food;
(g) the need for training of staff involved; and
(h) food labelling,
and that in its report the Committee make such recommendations as it considers appropriate for changes in public policy and law.

The reasons that the Australian Democrats have sought this inquiry need to be made clear. The Government has already announced an inquiry by the Australian Consumers Association, funded with public moneys, to look into this issue. However, we believe that, no matter how useful that inquiry may be, the Parliament should undertake an inquiry of its own. The reasons for this are obvious. The Australian Consumers Association is not able to call for papers and people. It is not able to inquire into many of the matters that are obviously of commercial value. I cannot see any reason why a particular company which is interested in pursuing food irradiation in Australia would be interested in talking to the Australian Consumers Association. It has no power in law to inquire into these matters. To go back to a previous committee chaired by the then Senator Peter Rae, it is fairly obvious that in many parliamentary inquiries there is material that is of great commercial value. Hence, that is unlikely to be made available to a group such as the Australian Consumers Association, no matter how well it inquires.

One aspect of a parliamentary inquiry is that it is able to call for people, papers and information and that people are required to appear before it. On 29 May I spoke in the Senate about a United States firm which has shown interest in food irradiation in Australia, Radiation Technology Incorporated of New Jersey. I listed the violations for which that company had been before the United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission. I believe that such a company would be unlikely to appear and discuss this matter with the Australian Consumers Association. The Committee has to be able to look at the matter.

Some of the questions that need to be examined in this context include the involvement of the nuclear industry and/or the food industry. We should see whether the nuclear industry's primary interest is the use of caesium 137 from the radioactive wastes generated by nuclear fuel reprocessing. What safeguards would be taken in respect of the importation of that substance and cobalt 60, which would be necessary for gamma radiation, if that were the method chosen? What interest is being shown by firms in Australia already using irradiation, for example, in the sterilisation of medical instruments? Do they see this as a legitimate extension of their businesses? What would be the extent of the waste products to be disposed of? What safeguards would be necessary to protect the workers? How much nutritional value would be lost? Does irradiation destroy vitamins in food? So one can go on. I believe that before Australia proceeds down this path the public wishes to have information on a whole host of questions.

Wild and exaggerated claims have been made by people on both sides of the issue. It is vitally important that, rather than embarking on a massive exercise of public experimentation on food, we should make available to the Australian public all the facts that are able to be gathered. The most appropriate way is through a committee of inquiry. Committees of the Parliament have shown in the past that they are able to take up these controversial issues; they are able to weigh them soberly and to make recommendations which have a standing in the community. This chamber in particular has been prominent in that type of movement. I believe that this is one such area. After all, we have inquired into many aspects of public policy which affect only a small group of people. This particular area affects every Australian, often three times a day. There is great community disquiet on this matter.

It is not a matter solely for this Parliament. It is also a matter for the State parliaments in their labelling policy. It is also a matter for local governments and their policies. I hope that a committee inquiry will be able to sum up the position. I draw attention to a notice of motion given in the House of Commons on 9 April this year on irradiated food. It reads:

That this House notes with grave concern the admission of a company from the Imperial Food Group that, having had a consignment of prawns condemned by the Southhampton Port Health Authority on the grounds of bacterial contamination, it had the consignment irradiated by Gammaster B.Y. in the Netherlands to conceal such bacterial contamination and caused them to be reimported; notes that this practice is illegal under the United Kingdom Food (Control of Irradiation) Regulations; notes too that it is also contrary to the recommendations of the Joint Export Committee of the World Health Organisation Food and Agriculture Organisation of the United Nations and the International Atomic Energy Agency, which bodies demand that irradiation be used solely to extend the shelf life of food otherwise wholesome and never be used to conceal contamination, thereby rendering salable food that is not truly wholesome; notes further that this instance highlights the inadequacy of existing food monitoring provisions and standards of enforcement procedures, presenting a potential public health hazard . . .

It goes on, but the point I want to emphasise is that in Britain there has been a very public exercise whereby a particular company found itself with a substantial consignment of food which was bad. It exported the food and had it irradiated, then reimported it. The reason is that irradiation kills the smell and the food is therefore able to be placed upon the market.

There is considerable difficulty in this area with regard to controls. I believe that it needs to be looked at before we move in this area, if we do move. It goes beyond simply concealing bacterial contamination. While irradiation can reduce the bacterial load on food-known in the trade as the bug count-it will leave unaffected the toxins generated by earlier bacterial contamination. This surely is a major potential health hazard for Australian people, which we need to address before any permission is given to proceed in this area.

Unfortunately, testing food for the bug count is one of the main methods by which Australian authorities determine the wholesomeness of imported food which may otherwise look satisfactory. The use of irradiation makes such bacterial testing systems totally ineffective. As far as I have been able to determine, no tests are available at present to enable Australian authorities to detect whether food has been irradiated. It seems to me that that is an admission that we are unable to determine, whether or not food has been bacterially contaminated previously and then irradiated, because no tests are available to us. On my understanding, from talking to scientists in this area, we are some two to three years away from having such tests available to us.

Since Senator Haines placed this notice of motion on the Notice Paper for debate today, which was done last week, I have had given to me a Press release from the Chairman of the all party House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation. I will read the Press release to the Senate as it will clarify where we are now:

Mr Peter Milton, Chairman of the all party House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation announced today that his Committee would be conducting an extensive inquiry into food irradiation and other uses of ionising radiation.

The Committee will be examining the use of ionising radiation for commercial sterilisation, disinfestation and food preservation and in particular, the effects on human health and safety, environmental impacts and the adequacy of assessment and regulatory procedures.

Mr Milton said that he had long been concerned by the apparent acceptance by the Government that there would be few problems with its use in Australia. He said that he believed that this conclusion was reached without proper examination.
`This concern is also apparent in the community. Just under 100 petitions have been presented to the House over the last six months containing many hundreds of signatures.'
Mr Milton saw his Committee's inquiry as complementary to the investigation to be conducted by the Australian Consumers Association.

`Ours however will be far more wide ranging. We also have the advantage that witnesses can give evidence under privilege and we have quite extensive powers in calling for information which may not be available to the ACA.'

It seems to me that those points answer the issue at hand, and since our motion is put in the form of a reference to the Standing Committee on Science, Technology and the Environment it might seem to be inappropriate to push ahead with it at this time. However the Australian Democrats would like the Senate to be involved in this exercise in some way. That was our reason for moving the motion. It may be inappropriate now to move in such a way; I had little notice that the House of Representatives Committee was moving in this area. When we inquired last week there was no possibility of any such move, so it has taken my Party by surprise. It may be appropriate, therefore, for me to seek leave to withdraw this motion in the hope that the Standing Committee on Science, Technology and the Environment will talk to the House Committee with a view possibly to having a joint committee of inquiry. That might suit both committees. It seems to me that we cannot do that on the run here, so it might better be left to the Standing Committee on Science, Technology and the Environment, which I understand has an interest in this area, to talk to the House Committee with a view to coming back here with a joint reference. I am in the hands of the Senate, and I will seek leave to withdraw the motion to allow that type of procedure to occur if the Senate so desires.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suggest that a more appropriate course would be simply to adjourn this debate so that the kind of discussion Senator Macklin is talking about can occur. If he withdraws his motion now he may well be tempted to re-introduce it at some later stage and we will have yet another speech from him, or someone else, advancing the cause or otherwise of irradiation. I suggest that Senator Macklin, having embarked upon a speech on this subject knowing full well that at the end of it he would suggest that his motion be withdrawn, is trying the patience of the Senate a bit. We do not mind giving people the odd free kick in terms of the procedures of this place, but that is sailing a little close to the wind. Rather than giving Senator Macklin or anyone else another opportunity to introduce the same motion again, a preferable course would be to adjourn the matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, the Government has taken the view that the granting of $90,000 to the Australian Consumers Association to conduct a major study on this matter and to report back in a public way to the Government should be sufficient to put at rest the fears that exist, for better or worse, in the community on this issue. People within the Parliament may take the view that they need the full panoply of the powers and privileges of a Senate, House of Representatives or joint committee to do the job, but that is not at this stage a view that the Government shares. Nonetheless we are willing to participate in any further discussions that may be held between the various interested members and senators on this matter to try to resolve it satisfactorily. On that basis, and after that explanation, I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
