SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Monday night I was debating the Loans Bill 1986 and I was talking about how the Budget decisions have affected the families of this country. The Government, as previous Labor governments have done, has committed the greatest atrocities against traditional families that have ever been perpetrated. Let us look at what has happened to just one section, the dependent spouse rebate, which is the major commitment any government can give to a family structure. It is recognised that tax relief is necessary to help a family in which the mother stays at home to bring up the children. Let us look and see what has happened to the dependent spouse rebate over the period of our Government and this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: When we came to government the dependent spouse rebate was worth $400. By the time we left government we had increased that rebate to $830 for spouses who did not have dependent children, and to $1,030 for those who had dependent children at home. There has been no increase by this Government for the dependent spouse rebate, and that suits the ideology of this Government whose main aim is to put women in the work force. It believes that the name alone of the dependent spouse rebate is incorrect; that no woman should be dependent. The Government does not like the term and therefore it will not increase it. Let us look at what has happened to the dependent spouse rebate as a percentage of the average weekly earnings under the last Labor Government, the Fraser Government and the Hawke Government to get a full idea of just what Labor ideology is in this area. In 1972-73, as a percentage of the average weekly wage, the dependent spouse rebate was 6.88 per cent. By the time Mr Whitlam was thrown out of government, that had decreased to 4.54 per cent of the average weekly wage. As I said, when we followed that Government into power it was 4.54 per cent and we increased that, over the period we were there, to 5.48 per cent. Once again, because a Labor government is in office, that dependent spouse rebate has gone down. It is now 4.6 per cent-just about the same devastation to the dependent spouse rebate by the Hawke Government as happened under the Whitlam Government.

If we wonder to what families the dependent spouse rebate goes, we have only to look to the Institute of Family Studies. It says that the dependent spouse rebate goes overwhelmingly to average families. The figures that were issued indicate that around 50 per cent of those families that the dependent spouse rebate goes to have incomes of less than $20,000 a year. Only 7 per cent to 8 per cent of families receiving that rebate have incomes of over $35,000 a year. So the rebate does not go to the wealthy members of the community; it goes to the average families and the lower income families.

Let us look at how personal tax affects families. When we left government in 1983, the tax threshold as a percentage of average weekly earnings was 25.39 per cent. It has now dropped to 20.89 per cent. This shows the Government's complete disregard for the family which is struggling to make ends meet because of the extra tax that has been imposed.

Let us look at family allowances. There has been absolutely no increase in the family allowance under this Government. Under our Government it was increased twice. Families have been affected in other ways. The Medicare levy in this Budget has gone up 25 per cent. The abolition of the subsidy for a patient who attends a private hospital will now mean that families which have been struggling to pay private hospital insurance will have an additional cost imposed on their contribution rates. Because insurance companies are losing $20, $30 or $40 a day they will have to put up their contribution rates. As well, the levy has been increased. We all remember very clearly the promise that that levy would never be increased by the present Government, but that promise has gone by the board. What has happened to interest rates? We know that home interest rates have gone from 13.5 per cent to 15.5 per cent. Interest on other borrowings has gone sky high and is as high as 20 per cent.

Getting back to the medical side, what is the cost of medical services? The maximum cost has gone from $10 for a medical service to $20. The Government has doubled the medical prescription charges. The maximum to be paid is $10; it was $5. The Government has even put sales tax on flavoured milk and fruit juices, which have gone up by 10 per cent. One could hardly call those two commodities luxuries; most families believe they are necessities. The family allowance for 18- to 24-year-olds has gone completely and for 16- and 17-year-olds it is now means tested.

The Government is gradually whittling away the small concessions given to families. It has whittled away the family allowance for 18- to 24-year-old students and has now means tested the allowance for 16- and 17-year-olds at school. Families have lost the tax deductions they used to get for education and health. I can assure you, Madam Acting Deputy President, that families do not forget. They are well aware of what is happening and how the Government is getting at them. As I have said, this is just the philosophy of this Government; that is what it is all about. It is not supporting the traditional family in any way but has done everything possible to make sure that conditions are so difficult for families that the woman is forced out into the work force.

The Government certainly needs the Bill that has been debated over the last couple of days. As Senator Messner's amendment says, this legislation is very necessary as the deficit is so high. However, we do not go along with the Government's wish to avoid bringing this Bill before the Senate. I believe the only reason the Government could possibly have is to avoid the accountability to Parliament when the need arises for governments to borrow. I have much pleasure in supporting the Opposition's amendment, which states:

`but the Senate notes with concern the continuing increase in the nation's indebtedness, the continuing balance of payments and trade crisis, the continuing high levels of interest rates and the Government's cosmetic approach to the reduction of its spending outlined in the recent Budget'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the Loans Bill 1986. It is a piece of legislation that provides for the financing of the prospective Budget deficit for 1986-87. The Loans Bill is, in essence, a machinery financing measure. Provisions in the Bill prohibit borrowings for expenditures additional to those already authorised by the Parliament. The Treasurer, Mr Keating, announced in his Budget Speech a deficit for this financial year of some $3,500m. That deficit involves a prospective deficit in the Consolidated Revenue Fund, which is the Government's major bank account, of some $5,100m. Existing authorisations available to the Government enable some $2,500m of expenditure to be charged to the Loan Fund this financial year. This Bill seeks authority to borrow moneys from the Loan Fund to cover the shortfall of some $2,600m. It is important to note that that figure of $2,600m is substantially less that the $3,800m borrowed last financial year. That reflects the tremendous success of the Hawke Labor Government in reducing the Budget deficit of the Commonwealth of Australia. The Hawke Government has achieved a major reduction in the Government deficit and it is very welcome news indeed.
—Why do you want perpetual authority to borrow, if you reckon it is so good?

—To refresh Senator Messner's memory, the Budget deficit has been reduced enormously in recent years. For example, last financial year it was $5,700m; this financial year we have a prospective deficit of some $3,500m, a reduction of $2,200m. Those figures are all very well, but it is very important to relate the size of the deficit to Australia's total annual national income. The deficit for this financial year will be of the order of 1.4 per cent of Australia's total national income, our gross domestic product. That compares very favourably with the prospective deficit of Mr Howard, when he was Treasurer, for 1983-84 of $9,600m--
—That is a lie.

—That would have come in at some 4 per cent of Australia's gross domestic product, compared with the 1.4 per cent deficit budgeted for this financial year. Senator Messner, like a lot of other members of the Liberal Party of Australia, has been involved in what I can describe as a Stalinist rewrite of history in recent years. I would advise Senator Messner to read very carefully the gripping and thorough account in the book by Mr Paul Kelly, The Hawke Ascendancy, in which he describes step by step the emergence of this prospective deficit of $9,600m for 1983-84. Far from being a lie, Mr Kelly very directly and accurately points out the fact that Australia would have had a Budget deficit of almost $10,000m in 1983-84 had Mr Howard continued to be Treasurer of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: This Budget provides for zero real growth in government outlays; that is, government spending will not rise faster than the rate of inflation this financial year. Total public sector borrowings will fall by more than $2,000m from the figure for last financial year. This is a very big achievement, a very real improvement in the situation in Australia. The net bond selling task of the Commonwealth Government will be zero this year; that is, there will not be any new bonds sold by the Commonwealth Government over and above the need to finance maturing bonds. That is a very, very big improvement on the situation in recent years. One of the important side effects of that will be to reduce growth in public debt interest, which will be held at 10 per cent of Commonwealth spending this financial year, after a period of steady growth since Mr Howard became Treasurer. The reduced borrowing requirement by the Commonwealth Government will ease pressure on our domestic capital markets, thereby hopefully helping to reduce interest rates in Australia. Lower interest rates are a key objective in this 1986 Budget to bring about greater private sector investment, which is central to economic recovery in the present circumstances.

Members of the Opposition, and Mr Howard in particular, make loud noises about expenditure restraint and they are urging the Government to make greater spending cuts. Does the Opposition really live up to its rhetoric? Did the Fraser Government succeed in reducing the Budget deficit? Did Mr Howard, when he was Treasurer-he was Treasurer of this country for five successive years-succeed in reducing Commonwealth outlays? Mr Fraser failed in reducing the Budget deficit. Mr Howard failed to reduce Commonwealth outlays. They failed miserably on both counts. Outlays went up, not down. The deficit exploded; it did not diminish under Mr Howard.

Mr Howard's record of budgetary mismanagement and incompetence is unmatched by any Treasurer of the Commonwealth of Australia since the Great Depression. In 1982-83, for example, there was a massive increase in the Budget deficit, from some $500m to more than $4,000m. It increased eight-fold in one financial year. Under Mr Howard as a proportion of gross domestic product the deficit rose from 0.4 per cent to 2.7 per cent. That is Howard's record when he was the Treasurer of Australia. In the same year, 1982-83, Commonwealth outlays increased by a huge 6.9 per cent in real terms; that is, Commonwealth Government spending rose almost 7 per cent ahead of the inflation rate in the community in Mr Howard's last year as Treasurer. In this Budget we are budgeting for zero real growth in Commonwealth expenditure. That is the difference between a Liberal government and a Labor government.

From 1978 to 1982 Mr Howard was the Treasurer of Australia. In every one of his five Budgets he overshot his expenditure target. That is his record as Treasurer of Australia. The end result of Mr Howard's mismanagement was an horrendous prospective Budget deficit of $9,600m for 1983-84. That was the legacy of seven wasted years of Liberal government. That was Mr Howard's bequest to the nation. Yet Mr Howard and his acolytes are still prepared to talk about reduced government expenditure and credibility in politics in the same breath. As I pointed out, Mr Howard, in every one of his five Budgets, overshot his expenditure target, yet he now calls for expenditure restraint by the Hawke Labor Government.

The Opposition's tax and policy commitments are an insult to the intelligence of every voter in the nation. In contrast to the Liberals, the Hawke Labor Government has reformed the Australian taxation system. The personal income tax reductions to be introduced on 1 December are the final elements of the Hawke Government's tax reform package. It is the most far-reaching reform of the Australian taxation system. The aim of the reform is to restore fairness and equity, to reduce the burden of taxation on the average pay as you earn taxpayer. The tax package will not raise the overall level of taxation in the community. It is a tax reform package that redistributes, not increases, tax levels in the community. The Opposition tries to cloud that point, that it is a tax reform package. It does not increase overall the level of taxation in the community. Now we have in this place, in the House of Representatives, in the media and in the community--

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you forgetting the fringe benefits tax?

—People are going around-Senator Walters has now said it-saying that they want to abolish the fringe benefits tax, part of this Government's long overdue clampdown on tax avoidance and tax evasion in this country. The fringe benefits tax will raise about $575m next financial year. The Liberals oppose that tax. It is an essential and key element of the Government's tax reform package. Without it, we will not be able to introduce wide-ranging personal income tax cuts for the great bulk of the taxpaying community. The Liberals want to remove the fringe benefits tax. They are saying that they do not want personal income tax cuts for the rest of the community. It really boils down to that.

SPEECH.PARA: Under the old taxation system, high income earners were able to avoid or minimise tax. The system was full of loopholes and rorts. They excelled in disguising taxable income as tax free gains. They were into negative gearing arrangements for rental properties and other real estate to reduce the taxation they paid on their income from their personal exertions. That is what was going on under the previous Government.

The Liberal Government encouraged the proliferation of fringe benefits such as the so-called company car. What a misnomer. It encouraged companies to pay school fees and pay for private telephone calls-all tax free remuneration in a non-cash form. In some cases, according to the information available to the Government, top executives were receiving about 40 per cent of their total remuneration in a tax free form. That was condoned by the party that wants to perpetrate the subsidised lunch for well-to-do business people. The Liberals want to continue for a narrow section of the community that taxation advantage which is paid for by the rest of the taxpaying community. Those tax rorts cost the community hundreds of millions of dollars. Pay as you earn taxpayers-the average taxpayers-were forced to shoulder the burden; yet, when Mr Howard was Treasurer, payment of income tax was optional for the wealthy. It was a voluntary tax for the rich in Australia.

No responsible government could tolerate a tax system that forced low and average income earners to subsidise the lurks and perks of the rich; yet Mr Howard tolerated and perpetuated this blatantly unfair and regressive tax system. In fact, under the Fraser-Howard Government, tax evasion and tax avoidance were among the few growth industries in Australia. While the manufacturing industry was in decline and other sectors went backwards, tax avoidance and evasion grew. From 1978 to 1982, Mr Howard, the Treasurer, was prepared to license the great Australian tax rip-off.

The Government's tax reform package will close loopholes and eliminate rorts. The fringe benefits tax, the capital gains tax and the disallowance of entertainment expenses will ensure that, for the first time, high income earners will pay their fair share of tax. As I pointed out earlier, the revenue raised by the fringe benefits tax, which the Liberals want to scrap, is a key element in financing the personal income tax reductions for average Australian taxpayers from 1 December 1986. Without the fringe benefits tax, there will be no substantial income tax reductions for the great bulk of Australian taxpayers from that date.

Of course, the Opposition chooses to deny that point. It seizes on parts of the Government's tax package and tries to create the impression that the Government is raising taxation. The Liberals, in saying that they would repeal the fringe benefits tax, are really telling the great bulk of wage and salary earners that they would deny them personal income tax cuts. It boils down to no fringe benefits tax and no significant personal income tax reductions from 1 December this year.

The tax cuts on 1 December will follow those introduced in November 1984 by the Hawke Labor Government. At that time taxpayers on average incomes saw a reduction in taxation of $7.60 a week. Those tax cuts in November 1984 represented stage 1 of the Government's income tax reductions. In December this year there will be a further reduction of $5.10 a week for someone on an income of $400 a week. In just two years, from November 1984 until December 1986, the reduction in taxation for someone on $400 a week will have been $12.70 a week-a substantial reduction in personal income tax.

This morning we heard Senator Walters mouthing off about the tax free threshold. The best the Liberals could do in regard to the tax free threshold-exempting some income from taxation-was to exempt those earning up to $4,595 from taxation. That was Mr Howard's record in his five years as Treasurer of this nation. From 1 December 1986 the tax free threshold will be not $4,595 but $5,100. That is the record of the Hawke Labor Government compared with the dismal record of the Fraser-Howard Administration.

This Government is reducing income tax rates substantially. Persons in the major tax bracket paying a marginal tax rate of 46c in the dollar will, from 1 July next year, pay 40c in the dollar-a significant reduction in personal income tax for average wage and salary earners. As I have pointed out in this place before, the marginal tax rate for those in the lowest income tax bracket will be 24c in the dollar as a result of the Hawke Government's taxation package. The best that Mr Howard, in five years as Treasurer, could achieve as the lowest income tax rate was 30c in the dollar. This is the difference between the two governments-30c in the dollar under Mr Howard; 24c in the dollar under the Hawke Labor Government.

In talking about taxation and the economy, the Opposition is treating the Australian electorate with contempt. It is asking voters to forget the Liberals' miserable economic performance when in government. It is asking the electorate to believe its rag-tag bunch of promises and rhetoric which pass for policy. But the Opposition is asking voters to vote for it at the next election. That must be either the greatest exercise in political naivete or the greatest political confidence trick since Federation.

I would like to refer to some statements made this week in the Senate in the debate on this legislation. They are examples of what is said by Opposition spokespersons about the economy. I refer first to Senator Parer from Queensland. There might have been a special reason for the hype injected in his speech on Monday night-there is a State election in Queensland and possibly he was chasing a headline. The morning edition of the Dateline News Digest on 23 September 1986 stated:
Senator Warwick Parer (Liberal, Queensland) said that judged by almost every statistic known, Australia under the Hawke Government was probably in its worst position since the depression.

He has not been a senator for all that long. Either he was suffering from a mental block or he is engaged in some sort of Stalinist rewrite of history, because he ignored the key indicators. He said: `Judged by almost every statistic known'. I looked at the unemployment figures and found that, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics, the level of unemployment under the Fraser-Howard Government in the 1982-83 recession was 10.4 per cent. The level of unemployment is now 8.3 per cent. So, judging by that key indicator, Australia certainly is not in the worst position in its history. It is certainly not in its worst position since the Great Depression. Clearly it is better off than it was in 1982-83 when Mr Howard was the Treasurer of Australia. There has been a 2 per cent reduction in unemployment since then.

Senator Parer talked about every statistic known, but he ignored employment growth. Look at the results. In the last financial year there was a 3.9 per cent increase in the total number of Australians at work. Some 200,000 to 300,000 extra Australians found work last financial year. However, in 1982-83, when the Liberals were in power and Mr Howard was Treasurer, the labour market shrank; it did not grow. The number of persons in work in Australia fell by 1.7 per cent. In fact, in the last year of the Liberals some 186,000 Australians lost their jobs. That is the record. I do not know which statistics Senator Parer was referring to but he certainly was not talking about unemployment or employment. I might go on to say that he could not have been talking about inflation either because despite the claims being made about inflation from the other side of the chamber--

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, the worst in 25 years.

—Senator Knowles is clearly ignorant of the facts, and I would point them out to her. In 1983 when the Liberal Government lost office the inflation rate was 11 1/2 per cent. That is the fact. I do not know how Senator Knowles can talk about--
—In real terms it is the worst for 25 years.

—That is a contradiction in terms. There is no such thing as real terms inflation. Senator Knowles seems to be very confused. There is no such thing as real terms inflation. Inflation is a monetary concept and it has nothing to do with real values. I point out that when Mr Howard lost office in 1982-83, inflation in Australia, as measured by the consumer price index, was running at 11 1/2 per cent. It is now not 11 1/2 per cent, not 10 1/2 per cent, not 9 1/2 per cent, but 8.4 per cent. That is the difference between Mr Howard's record as Treasurer and the record of the Hawke Labor Government. They are some of the key statistics that demonstrate the nonsense that Senator Parer and other Liberals were talking in this chamber on Monday evening about the state of the economy.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Short has also spoken in the debate. As a former adviser to the Treasury, I understand, and a former adviser to Mr Howard, he ought to know better. I have listened to Senator Short's speeches in this chamber over a period and I have found that his big subject of interest is foreign debt. Of course, Senator Short has made some incredible bungles when talking about foreign debt. He has claimed-and remember, he is a former Treasury officer-that the great majority of Australia's foreign debt is government debt. That is what he has said week after week and month after month. That is an absolute nonsense; it is a fiction. The great majority of foreign debt owed by Australia is owed by private and public companies, companies which are listed on stock exchanges. That is a fact and the figures are publicly available. I am pleased, I must say, that in a very lame way Senator Short has now changed his terminology. He is now referring to the `relative' increase in public debt. So yet another part of the notes of a Liberal Party speaker has crashed to the ground. Whoever prepares those speakers' notes ought to be sacked because a gross fiction is being perpetrated. The great majority of Australia's foreign debt is owed by the private sector.

I would like to go on and analyse the speech Senator Michael Baume made in this place on Monday evening. The honourable senator puts himself up as an expert on the economy. I understand that Senator Michael Baume also was an adviser to Mr Howard when he was Treasurer. It may be because he and Senator Short were advisers that we had to face the problems of the recession in 1982 and 1983. Senator Baume used the 1982-83 recession as a basis for comparing the economy during that time with the present circumstances. After being pressured from this side of the chamber, he said that the 1982 recession was caused by drought. Of course, what Senator Baume is really trying to do is protect his own back because he was one of the people who advised Mr Howard-he was one of Mr Howard's minders-on the economic policies to pursue in 1982-83.

I would like to dispose of the argument of the drought of 1982-83 being a key cause of Australia's economic problems at that time. I would simply refer to the gross domestic product figures which are still available. I advise people to look at Budget Statement No. 1, which contains the economic growth figures. Of course, we should remember that there was negative growth during that period. However, we should look at those figures and hold them up against Senator Baume's claim that the recession was caused by Australia being in the grip of a drought. Certainly there was a drought, but it did not cause a recession in this country. For example, if we consider Australia's gross domestic product, which is the total income of Australia measured right across the economy, for that year and take out the farm sector we find in that non-farm gross domestic product figure-a figure which is publicly available and which is most used by economists to look at growth-that non-farm growth fell by one per cent in 1982-83. So, while Senator Baume claims that the drought was responsible for taking the economy backwards in that year, it is clear that the non-farm sector was in decline. It is very difficult to accept the arguments put forward by Senator Baume that all the problems in that disastrous period in Australia's recent economic history when Mr Howard was Treasurer were caused by drought.

Senator Baume went on to say in the same speech-he does not seem to find it easy to be consistent in his logic-that manufacturing industry now is well down on its 1981 peak. He said that manufacturing production in the present day and age had not recovered to its 1981 peak. Of course, what he was really saying-it was a Freudian slip-was that in fact it was falling in 1982 as well. Despite his claims that the economic problems faced by this country in 1982-83 were caused by drought, it can be shown on the basis of two publicly available indicators that that is an absolute fiction and that he was talking rubbish in the debate earlier in the week.

The Hawke Government has not backed away from the tough economic decisions needed in Australia. It has not reverted to the political expediency of the Fraser-Howard years. It certainly has not reverted to the soft options of Mr Howard. The Hawke Government's tough decisions, cuts in government spending and other measures are necessary to overcome the economy's structural problems. The imbalances in Australia's economy can be corrected if economic policy responses are positive, planned and well managed. The 1986-87 Budget continues the framework for this response and the imbalances will be corrected. The Hawke Government is guiding Australia's economy from dependence on commodity exports to promoting export orientated manufacturing industry and the result will be a sounder footing for Australia's economy, for Australia's future prosperity and continued economic development.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Loans Bill 1986 is a machinery Bill required by the government of the day because it cannot overdraw on the Consolidated Revenue Fund. In areas of expenditure such as defence, where programs are committed, it is necessary to ensure that money is available and, therefore, the money has to be drawn from the Loan Fund. Obviously, the amount borrowed must take account of the extent of the Budget deficit, which in this case is $3.5 billion. However, there has been a wide ranging debate which has been really in the nature of a debate that would normally occur on the Appropriation Bills. I do not intend to engage in such a wide ranging debate. I do not say that that is not necessary. Obviously, the task of Opposition senators is to take every opportunity to point out what they see as the shortcomings of the Government and it is a task of Government senators to listen to those comments and to respond to them.

SPEECH.PARA: I will raise just a couple of issues that emerged from the speech of the previous speaker, Senator Maguire. He took Senator Short to task about what he perceived to be Senator Short's overemphasis on public sector indebtedness. As Senator Maguire quite rightly said, the great majority of Australia's overseas indebtedness results from the private sector. On Monday, Senator Short pointed out the nature of the total public debt. He indicated that the total debt of the public sector, of Federal, State and local government, is very disconcerting. He indicated that, as a percentage of gross domestic product, public debt has risen from 39.8 per cent to 50.6 per cent over the last 10 years. At 30 June 1976 the level of total public sector securities on issue in Australia was $28.9 billion. At 30 June this year that figure was $117.4 billion-a more than four-fold increase.

Furthermore, something that should be noted with concern is that a public debt of $117.4 billion, which was the figure at the end of June this year, represents more than $7,300 for every man, woman and child in Australia, or more than $17,000 for every taxpayer. As was pointed out by Senator Short on Monday, the interest bill on the Federal Government's share alone of that debt is more than $7 billion, which is 10 per cent of the total Federal Government outlays. It is more than we spend on the nation's defence, on education or on health. That must be addressed. It is important for the Government to recognise the problem and to overcome it. Senator Short added that the growth in our foreign debt had been even more dramatic and that, in the last three years alone, it has increased from less than $30 billion to almost $90 billion as our balance of payments on current account has accelerated into deficit. Senator Short said:

Last year . . . that deficit was $14 billion; this year it will be higher, even on the Government's own estimates. On this basis, our foreign debt will exceed $100 billion by the end of June next year. Our foreign debt is increasing by $40m every day of the 365-day year.

They are figures which need consideration. Quite obviously, a further substantial foreign debt is incurred by the private sector. Nevertheless, the Australian Parliament does have a responsibility to consider the causes of that part of Australia's overseas indebtedness which is generated by Federal Government action.

As I have said, I do not intend to engage in a debate that is more appropriate to the Appropriation Bills. In any event, Mr Acting Deputy President, I do not imagine that you would allow me to. But the other aspect that I want briefly to deal with with relates to certain things said by the previous speaker about taxation. He gave the impression that everything is rosy and that people should be grateful for what is being done for them in the area of taxation. Let me say to honourable senators that everything may be okay for some people, but it is not okay for the vast majority. In particular, everything is not okay for people with family responsibilities.

In the last 10 years a worker on average earnings, with a wife and four children, has suffered a loss in real disposable income of 11 percentage points and, despite the much trumpeted tax cuts of this Government, will suffer a further one per cent loss by this time next year. Put in money figures, over the period from 1976 until next year, that worker will have suffered an annual loss in real disposable income of $600. Of course, some people will benefit and have benefited from the taxation policies of successive governments and of this Government. If that same worker did not have a dependent spouse and four children but had a spouse who also was working, and if their combined income was 50 per cent higher than average weekly earnings that couple, as a result of the policies, would not suffer a loss but would benefit to the extent of a $1,000 increase in disposable income. Is that a fair system? It is not. Unless the Government focuses on that particular fact, it will suffer a substantial reversal in the next election. I deliberately said that it was as a result of policies of successive governments, because the previous Government's policies were inadequate. But the policies of this Government appear not to heed the cry of those who have the responsibility of raising a family in this day and age of increased costs and burdens.

If the Government does not hear that cry of the vast majority of ordinary families out in the electorate, let it listen to the statements made only yesterday, I understand, by Professor Borrie. At a seminar of the Department of Demo-graphy at the Australian National University's Research School of Social Sciences, Professor Borrie drew attention to the fact that, unless there is an increase in the fertility rate-in the number of children being born-we shall go out the back door. What he said, having given a detailed paper, was:

The ultimate biological and social aim must surely be at least generation replacement if society is to survive. To this end an average of about 2.5 children a couple was required to ensure human survival.

Since 1971, Australia had been returning rapidly to the situation of the 1930s, with evidence of an average completed family size of 2.4 a married couple-not adequate to provide replacement. In recent years, total fertility in Australia was an average of only 1.9, well below replacement level.

For a government that is responsible for the continuance of society, that surely is a very real warning. If the Government does not hear the practical cries of ordinary families-those with the responsibility of parenting-at least it should look at where its policies are taking Australia, and it is taking Australian society right out the back door.

Professor Borrie's whole lecture should be studied very carefully, not only by the Government, the Opposition, the Australian Democrats and every member of Parliament, but also by those people in the community who have substantial influence on government and on the direction of society. Professor Borrie also made another interesting comment when he said:

. . . throughout human history `natural fertility' and life expectations of about 35 years had kept population numbers reasonably balanced, but the achievement of life expectation of 75 or more years had destroyed this natural system, and explosive population growth rates had been prevented only by increasing efficient checks on fertility-contraceptives and sterilisation.
He warned that today these checks were so universal and so efficient that in Australia and many other Western countries, the intrinsic levels of fertility were below generation-replacement level.

That and the anti-family taxation policies of successive governments pose real problems for this nation. I mention in passing that many people in power-I am talking of the bureaucracy-have come through the era of kneeling at the feet of gurus such as Erlich, the author of The Population Bomb. Those scientists and others who tackled Erlich's proposition of the population explosion, who were able to point out the possible effects of anti-family policies, and more particularly the likely effects of new methods of production and agriculture in sustaining any natu-ral population growth, were pooh-poohed at the time because they were against the Erlich dogma, but people are now starting to listen to them. I trust that the Government will listen to them, too.

One of the problems of the Loans Bill is that it seeks to prevent such legislation being presented to Parliament each year. Over the years the Loans Bill, which is a machinery Bill to ensure that the Government has the ability not to overdraw on the Consolidated Revenue Fund, is brought into the Parliament each year. On this occasion, as on a similar occasion last year, the Government is seeking to make this a standing statute. That would prevent such a Bill being introduced each year. Last year, for the first time, the Government tried that course, but the Senate amended the Bill to ensure that it would have to come back to the Parliament each year. The House of Representatives ultimately accepted that amendment. It is important for this chamber, as the House of review and in exercising audit and control over the functions of government, which is our responsibility, on this occasion also to amend the Bill to ensure that it is not a permanent statute but the government, whatever government it may be, will be required to bring it back each year. That would enable this chamber to give consideration to the purposes for which the loan fund might be used. I believe that would be in the interests not only of the Opposition but also of the Government, because a future conservative government may wish to utilise the loan fund for various purposes, legitimate though they may be, but purposes which are not, in the consideration of the then opposition, in the best interests of the country. That would then give to the Parliament, particularly the Senate, the opportunity of exposing those purposes; thus democracy would be served. I intend to vote for such an amendment because it is in line with the responsibility of the Senate not to act as a rubber stamp for the House of Representatives or for the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —While some specific references in this Loans Bill relate to expenditure incurred by the Department of Defence, the overall purpose of the Bill is to facilitate the funding of the prospective Budget deficit for 1986-87. For this reason I think it proper to direct my remarks to the broader question of the Budget deficit and those aspects of Government policy which most contribute to it. This is well summarised by the Opposition's amendment, which points to the concern at the continuing increase in the nation's indebtedness, the continuing balance of payments and trade crisis, the continuing high level of interest rates and the Government's cosmetic approach to the reduction of its spending.

SPEECH.PARA: This morning I found Senator Maguire rather amazing. He does not bother to stay in the chamber to hear some of the facts. He spent probably 80 per cent of his time talking about the Fraser Government and how dreadful it supposedly was by comparison with this wonderful Hawke socialist Government and the world's greatest Treasurer, Mr Keating. The fact of the matter is that inflation has risen from 5.1 per cent when the Australian Labor Party took office to 8.4 per cent; Senator Maguire admitted that it is now 8.4 per cent. As I pointed out to Senator Maguire-he chose not to believe it-inflation in real terms is at the worst rate for 25 years. The Government has achieved this in only three short years. It is undoubted that by any measure this Government is a big spending and big taxing government. Tax revenue in real terms has increased at an annual rate of 5.4 per cent in just three years, compared with a 3.3 per cent increase in the seven years of the previous Government. Tax receipts as a percentage of gross domestic product are the highest in post-war history. Government expenditure in real terms has increased by 5.3 per cent per year under Mr Hawke and only 2.1 per cent per year under the previous Liberal Government. Expenditure as a percentage of GDP also is the highest figure in post-war history. If Senator Maguire or any of the other Government senators think that that record should be praised, I suggest that they think again because the whole question of the Budget deficit illustrates the weakness of the economic management of this Hawke Labor Government.

A reduced Budget deficit has been achieved by papering over the cracks and by recourse to taxation, while the tough expenditure decisions simply have not been made. While the Government might proclaim the reduced deficit as a sign of its responsible management, this figure of $3.5 billion still represents outlays of 29.4 per cent of GDP; a percentage exceeded only once under Mr Whitlam in the last three ALP Budgets. Because so many supposed spending cuts are deferments, ongoing expenditure savings will be less than those of 1986-87, as the Government has merely put off the hard decisions until next year.

On the other hand, the increase in taxes is very real; up by $1.4 billion in 1986-87, raising the tax take to a record 25.5 per cent of GDP. The Government has netted this extra $1.4 billion by breaking its trilogy commitment not to raise the level of taxes. This fourth Hawke Budget shows that since 1983 tax receipts have shown an annual average real increase of 4.9 per cent, compared with 3.3 per cent under the previous coalition Government. Over the same time the average annual real growth in outlays has been 3.9 per cent; a long way ahead of the 2.1 per cent average in the seven Liberal years. These figures in particular tell us what is behind this Bill and the whole economic and fiscal program of this Government. Both Government borrowings and the Government's failure to tackle expenditure are the major causes of the highest real interest rates that we have seen for generations. The extent of borrowing has resulted in the loss of confidence in the dollar which we are seeing daily and have seen for months gone by.

The ALP chooses to defend the dollar by the quick fix method of pushing up interest rates. It should be remembered that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) stated repeatedly, right back from the 1984 election campaign, that he would not lift the ceiling on home mortgage rates. What have we seen in recent months? We have seen that savings bank mortgage interest rates are 15.5 per cent, up from 11.5 per cent in December 1984; the time when he was saying that he would not lift the ceiling on home mortgage interest rates. This in turn accounts for an increase of only 0.6 per cent in dwelling investments in 1985-86, compared with 11.6 per cent in the previous year. All it amounts to is yet another broken promise by this Prime Minister. What right have Ministers of this Government to criticise businessmen for refusing to invest and expand when the prime rate for business has increased from 14 to 18 per cent over the same time? Long term interest rates of 14 per cent, double those of major Western economies, and short term rates touching 18 per cent, or three times the rate of Japan and the United States of America, stand as a rebuke to the economic competence of this Government.

The accumulation of four Budget deficits is a major cause of the prediction in this current Budget that we face an 8 per cent inflation rate in 1986-87, compared with 2.3 per cent in the other 24 Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries. The determination of this Government to tackle such root causes of inflation as escalating labour costs is suspect when it merely talks of discounting 2 per cent from a likely 4 per cent wage claim at the next national wage case.

We simply cannot discuss this Bill without continued reference to the Budget deficit. I believe it is highly appropriate that the projected deficit figure of $3.5 billion is the same amount that this Government expects to spend on unemployment benefits. I fear very much that the second figure will rise and drag the first figure up with it. With the June quarter statistics showing that the growth in full time jobs has reduced to zero-another little figment of Senator Maguire's imagination was that employment was going up-we find it hard to believe in the Budget prediction of 1.75 per cent employment growth for 1986-87.

Equally dubious, of course, is the anticipated growth in gross domestic product of 2 1/4 per cent. Yet we have to remember that, on this Government's admission, a growth rate of 3 per cent is needed to stop further unemployment growth. The Budget's prediction of 36,000 more people receiving the unemployment benefit is far too optimistic. We should remember that one merchant bank projected that as many as 180,000 more Australians may be out of work in 1986-87. Even if unemployment does not reach this horrific level, a rise substantially above that predicted in the Budget can only blow out the deficit. I have a particular concern for the level of youth unemployment, running at 22.7 per cent for 15- to 19-year-olds. When Senator Maguire was speaking I asked him how successful the infamous Priority One : Young Australia campaign had been. He chose not to respond to that interjection because he knows that the unemployment figure for 15- to 19-year-olds is worse than it was when the Priority One scheme was introduced. The Government has provided in the last month only a few more than 2,000 of the 10,000 traineeships it promised. Nearly all of those are in the public sector, paid for out of the public purse, not in the private sector. So in anyone's language, the Priority One scheme has been an absolute disaster and a con for 15 to 19-year-olds who are seeking employment. Each and every wage subsidy scheme that the Australian Labor Party attempts is an implicit admission that youth wages are too high, and the continuation of rigid minimum wage rates will add significantly to unemployment and be a continued drain on the public purse.

This Government has done back flips all over the place in the last few months on every matter one could imagine, not the least of which is encouragement for those on the dole to work for their payments. The Prime Minister said quite clearly and categorically that he would institute a system whereby the unemployed could gain work experience by working for the dole. Of course, increasing pressure from the Labor Party's Left in every State has made him back off. It is important to recognise that this problem will never be tackled so long as we have a government that sides with the truly reactionary forces on the industrial scene that aim to stop Australians selling their labour at a price the market can support. Instead of denouncing other suggestions and initiatives, ALP Ministers would do better to question the validity of those famous judgments of 1907 and 1909 on which our industrial system is based and which now contribute to unemployment and high Budget deficits. The assertion of Mr Justice Higgins in 1909 that `the remuneration of the employee cannot be allowed to depend on the profits actually made by his individual employer' must be recognised as a dangerous myth in the reality of 1986.

We need a government that is prepared to denounce the continuing fallacy that wage levels can be divorced from profitability, and that is an important matter on which we must act accordingly. SPEECH.PARA: The reduction in the predicted deficit has been achieved, if that is the right word, by some half-hearted expenditure restraint and some very doubtful predictions as to economic growth and the extent of unemployment. There is, of course, a third factor-a very real increase in overall taxation. Much of this increased taxation falls on the business sector, ultimately reducing its capacity to expand and employ, thereby taking us down the road to declining revenue and higher welfare spending. Anti-business taxes, which I have already mentioned, continue to be levied in disregard of clear warning signals from the private sector, and we must remember that that sector is the ultimate revenue and employment base. Even though this Government seeks to increase just the public sector, we in the Liberal Party firmly believe that the ultimate revenue comes from the private sector, as does employment.

The first of these warnings is the fall in non-farm gross domestic product for three successive quarters. In anyone's language that is the definition of a recession. Consumer sentiment has fallen steeply during 1986 and the Budget Papers predict that business investment will fall one per cent in 1986-87. Again we might ask whether this understates the likely outcome, since the June quarter survey by the Confederation of Australian Industry and the Westpac Banking Corporation shows that 35 per cent of businesses plan to reduce investment over the next 12 months. Investment statistics attract far less publicity than unemployment figures and the deficit, yet this ALP Government seems not to recognise that the lack of investment is the major cause of our most spectacular problems. Certainly the taxation policies implemented this year act as a positive disincentive to investment, employment and expansion. ALP Ministers attack business for its failure to expand. Why do they not return incentive? Business might then be able to expand. Australia's corporate tax rate is 49 per cent, compared with 34 per cent in the United States of America, 33 per cent in Singapore and 35 per cent in Britain. This Government is trying desperately to say that it is not a big taxing government and that it is not creating disincentives for business.

At the same time the private sector is now grappling with this wretched fringe benefits tax, which affects large and small businesses and people on high and low incomes alike. The Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) would have us believe that the fringe benefits tax is purely and simply hitting the high income earners. That is simply not so, and it has been demonstrated for months. This Government is convinced that it will not change a whisker of the fringe benefits tax but will just continue to penalise the Australian community at will.

In Western Australia, we saw in late July the closure of the Agnew nickel mine, and with it the shut-down of the town of Leinster and the dispersal of hundreds of families. Yet Senator Walsh sits in this chamber as a Western Australian senator who supported the introduction of the fringe benefits tax and he could not give a continental about the people in his own electorate who have been pushed out of employment by this tax. The fringe benefits tax in Leinster, coming on top of declining nickel prices, was the deciding factor in this social and economic tragedy, and let us not forget it. The loss to national export earnings will be $55m and there will be a cost to revenue of $10m in company tax and $10m in pay as you earn receipts. Nothing could better illustrate the self-defeating nature of this tax and the fact that it will contribute to higher deficits and the need for future loans Bills.

Again, the inequity of the tax has been shown by the example of a major Perth car dealer whose salesmen, as the recipients of benefits, have agreed to reimburse their employer for the cost of the tax. When, however, these employees provide their boss with the money to pay the fringe benefits tax it is assessed as extra income for the employer and taxed accordingly. Just when it has become so clear that Australia needs to generate more investment and, in particular, more risk taking investment, the ALP capital gains tax that has come in creeps forward as a growing disincentive to capital accumulation and entrepreneurial activity. Only now are the full ramifications of the Act becoming apparent, since pre-September 1985 assets will lose their tax free status if more than 50 per cent of share capital changes hands. This creates further administrative nightmares and is another reason for many businesses to abandon plans for expansion. In Australia we should be encouraging people to invest in property and make all other investments possible. But no, this Government provides every possible disincentive that it can think of to make sure that people will not invest in this country and will take their money overseas.

One other major policy area with firm potential for blowing out the Budget deficit is, of course, Medicare, because there has been an enormous blow-out in the last 12 months in Medicare. This shows clearly how the ideological preoccupations of the socialist Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) result in inferior health care at greater cost to individual Australians and to public expenditure generally. The Treasurer had the gall to say in his Budget Speech that the Medicare levy would be increased `so that Medicare is self-financing'. This same Government, specifically the Minister for Health, Dr-non-medical-Blewett, said as recently as March that there would be no increase in the Medicare levy. Yet what do we see only a few months later? We see an increase in the Medicare levy, supposedly so that it will be self-financing. The simple arithmetic of the situation contained within the same Budget Papers makes an absolute mockery of this statement, because it is impossible to make any of the figures work out.

This Government expects to pay out just under $4,000m in medical and hospital benefits. That, in effect, constitutes the cost of Medicare as opposed to such other major areas of health spending as pharmacy and veterans' and nursing home benefits. At the same time, expected receipts from the Medicare levy will amount to $1,645m in 1986-87. Even when we are generous to the Government and look at the increased 1.25 per cent levy over a full 12 months, the amount raised will be under $1,800m-a long way short of that $4 billion expenditure. We have, then, a supposedly self-financing health system that would require a levy of 2.8 per cent of personal income to meet its costs. But, of course, the Government will not tell people that it is 2.8 per cent. It will just rip 1.25 per cent off and take the rest out of general revenue, so that nobody is any the wiser. It has been doing that for as long as this wretched jolly Medicare has been in existence, anyway.

People are getting worse service than they have ever received in their lives. Once again, the disincentive has been increased so that fewer people will be able to insure privately for their health. The Government has taken away the day bed subsidies to private hospitals so that private health insurance is bound to go up. It has to go up. So this increased measure of taxation, perhaps amounting to an extra $52 over the year for the average wage earner, meets no more of the cost of Medicare than did the one per cent levy. The shortfall must be met by either general taxation revenue or government borrowings. Any way it goes it amounts to more tax. This Government has tinkered with a dishonest levy without addressing the rising cost of medical benefits which, over two years of spending, is up 27 per cent. Last year the Government budgeted for an 11 per cent rise in medical benefits that grew by 15 per cent, causing a blow-out of $166m. With this track record the $3,230m allocated in the Budget for medical services may well be exceeded in the present financial year.

The Liberal Party has proposed the obvious step of restricting bulk billing to those people with health care cards, putting, I might say, a real brake on the medical benefits spiral. This is viewed as either an infringement of socialist principles or simply just too difficult. In the same way this ALP Government ignores the advice of as respected a figure as Professor David Penington, who for months has been warning that unrestricted bulk billing would continue to create an open-ended cost spiral. The Government ignores the fact that during 1985 the number of bulk-billed services rose by 18 per cent, while the number of patient-billed services rose by less than 2 per cent. Health policy must be addressed if we are going to get reductions.

Expenditure on health, as with social security which rises with unemployment, is an example of how the policies of this Government will inevitably result in increased outlays. Because of its refusal to abandon big spending socialist policies, Australians can expect either increased borrowing over the long term, with still greater recourse to loans, or increased taxation-and we are copping both at the moment. We are already beginning to see that high levels of taxation result only in the destruction of the revenue base and huge Budget deficits. This Bill, unexceptional in itself, I suppose, is a pertinent reminder of the ALP-Hawke Government's economic mismanagement-its fiddling on the fringes and its absolute string of broken promises. This Government has simply been spending too much, taxing too much, borrowing too much and interfering too much. If there is going to be any hope for this great country it needs a government that is prepared to bite the bullet on the simple reforms that are needed: The encouragement of overseas investment, not a disincentive; the reduction of taxation, providing incentive to employees and employers alike; the reduction of government spending; and the reduction of union power. A Howard-led Liberal government would have the gumption to take these hard measures that would bring back profitability to this country and to its people. I think that it is most important that, if we are going to address this Bill in any sense of the matter, we must look at the ramifications of it over the short and long term, and also at what the options are. A Howard-led Liberal government would deliver the reforms that are needed; this Government simply does not have the intestinal fortitude or the ability to do so.

The Loans Bill governs the Government's borrowing programs. That matter was aired significantly and at length during the debate on the motion for the second reading. The point that should be made at this stage is that this Government continues to be a substantial borrower. Its policies have led to increasing borrowing of overseas money by Australians, whether by governments or by the private sector. This has led to an increase in the total funds borrowed on the overseas markets from about $35 billion at the time the Australian Labor Party came to power in March 1983 to an amount approaching $100 billion. They continue to be the facts of life. We continue to borrow and borrow to pump up the standard of living of Australians.

We have just had the first change in our credit rating in Australia's history. Overseas lending advisers, organisations and financial institutions are faced with the fact that Australia is not a top grade lending risk in the world community. In fact, Moody's Investor Services Inc. has reduced Australia's credit rating from AAA to AA1. Although this does not represent a substantial change in how Australia is perceived by other countries, the fact remains that this country has reduced its standing in the world's eyes by virtue of the policies this Government has tended to put in place in the past three years. Those policies, this Government and this Treasurer (Mr Keating)-who was described by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) as the `world's greatest Treasurer'-have brought us the first downgrading of Australia's credit rating in the history of the Federation. That has to be a significant factor-if not an economic one, then certainly a political one-in the life of this Government. We will continue to hammer the disgrace that has been brought on this country by this Government's policies and the introduction of the measures which produced that result overseas.

Some points which arose during the second reading debate have a bearing on the matter under consideration. Senator Maguire raised many issues concerning tax avoidance. The truth is that, under this Government's tax measures, which will have effect from July next year, people earning $18,000 or $19,000-not even average weekly earnings but substantially below them-will suffer a marginal rate of tax of 40 per cent on their overtime earnings and the bonuses and allowances they receive in addition to their normal wages. That is the net result of this Government's new tax measures which will apply from next July. That income range is by no means handsome. The tax rate applies to the great bulk of taxpayers. It comes as no surprise to learn that, for the first time, come next July taxpayers in that range, and there are about two million of them, will find themselves paying a marginal tax rate of 40 per cent on their income. That is the kind of tax reform that this Government claims is saving the taxpayer a great deal of money. The Government says: `We are introducing reforms by way of the fringe benefits tax and the capital gains tax in order to give people tax cuts'. However, for the first time we find that people on low levels of income are paying a penalty rate of tax of 40 per cent. I repeat: Two million people in that category will in fact be paying more when the new tax proposal of this Government comes into force next July.

The Opposition's amendments before the Committee seek to restore this legislation from what is a perpetual authority for the Government to borrow to an annual authority for the Government to borrow. The Opposition proposed amendments and drew attention to this point when this issue was discussed in the Senate 12 months ago. Those amendments, which were supported by the Australian Democrats, were passed and the Bill was amended. Senator Walsh went to some length during the second reading debate to answer the arguments that we have been putting down on this matter, but he has completely missed the point that we have been making. The point is not the one that he focused on-that is, the question of whether or not expenditures are properly covered by appropriation or other legislation. That is not the point at all. The point is simply that the kind of principle that this Government has incorporated in the legislation would take away from the Parliament the scrutiny of the Government's borrowing program. Parliament would have no say at all if the Government succeeded in using this Bill as a means of permanently gaining approval for its borrowing program. If this were done, the Parliament would have no overall authority and no oversight of the Government's borrowing programs.

I return to my earlier point about borrowing programs. In three years under the Hawke Labor Government we have gone from being a $35 billion debtor country to being a $100 billion debtor country. Is that not enough reason for members of the Opposition to want to ensure that the Parliament and the Senate have total scrutiny of the Government's loan program and have the opportunity to debate the principles behind a government's borrowing program? Is that not a sufficient reason, quite apart from the points that Senator Walsh raised, to ensure that this Parliament plays a proper role in the conduct of this nation's affairs and that it authorises and continues to authorise the borrowings of this Government on the loan account? That, to me, is the point at issue here. It is quite simple and I am sure that all members on this side of the House, including the Australian Democrats, can see it. Clearly, the Government cannot.

This is not just a simple accounting machinery measure. What this Government is about-and this is the scandal-is taking away from Parliament its right to oversee the borrowing program of the Government, taking away Parliament's right to ask questions about the borrowing program, to inquire into what is happening and to see and expose the Government's programs which, of course, are basic to our total financial structure. That is why we have moved these amendments. We stand very strongly on that point.

I would like to make one point about a matter that was raised by Senator Walsh. He spoke of the appropriation for defence and other matters being covered by appropriate legislation. It is interesting to note that of the total--

TALK.START.PARA: —We are limited by the Appropriation Bills.

—That is the point that I am just about to make. It is interesting to note that only 32 per cent of the Government's total expenditure this year of almost $75,000m is actually covered by the Appropriation Bills that are before the Parliament. Less than one-third of the expenditures that this Government undertakes is specifically authorised by the Appropriation Bills. The other two-thirds is authorised by standing legislation, which ranges from Bills and Acts such as the social security Act and various repatriation Bills, right through to legislation which authorises special health expenditures and things of that nature. In other words, the Parliament has very little direct control over two-thirds of this Government's expenditures.

SPEECH.PARA: We can see what has been happening over the years-the gradual erosion of the power of control of the Parliament over the Government's expenditure. We can see quite clearly in this Budget that $50 billion worth of expenditures out of a total Budget of $75 billion are in fact not subject to specific authority or specific appropriation by legislation of this Parliament. We believe that this trend towards extending this power with respect to loans, to the borrowings of the Government by virtue of the Loans Bill that is before us, to a perpetual authority to borrow is the major issue and is very closely related to the issue I am raising.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are saying that Carlton is a fool, are you?

—No, I am not saying that Mr Carlton is a fool at all. He is saying quite clearly that, from a machinery point of view, the legislation may have some merit. We here are taking the broader view that it is the Parliament that has, and should continue to have, control over the borrowing programs and the appropriations of the Government. For that reason, I have moved the amendments standing in our name. Probably the first amendment is the most significant, in that it seeks to change the title of the Bill from a loans Bill, which connotes that the Bill has some continuing authority beyond one year, to a loan Bill, indicating borrowings only in respect of this financial year.
