—Order! Before the Minister answers, I again draw honourable senators' attention to the length of questions. If it continues, I will direct that the questions be placed on notice.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the alleged statement by Rear-Admiral Martin, it is the case that, while being interviewed about the naval review on Sydney's Channel 9 program at 7.45 this morning, Rear-Admiral Martin said: `Inevitably some of the ships would be carrying nuclear weapons'. However, I am advised by the Minister for Defence that what Rear-Admiral Martin intended to say, and what he thought he had said, was that it was not inevitable that some of the ships would be carrying nuclear weapons. Rear-Admiral Martin's intention was to confirm the Navy's policy of neither denying nor confirming the carrying of nuclear weapons in visiting warships. Rear-Admiral Martin, not yet retired, has said that this was a simple slip of the tongue which he regretted.

ANSWER.PARA: As to Senator Sanders's throw-away line in parenthesis of some hundreds of accidents with nuclear weapons under the United States Navy's nuclear weapons accident reporting system, let me immediately correct the record about that. Of the 630 incidents-not 380 but 630 incidents-that have been reported over the 20-year period of the operation of the Navy's nuclear weapons accident report system, 364 did not involve nuclear weapons at all but rather dummy weapons that are used for training purposes. The 264 incidents that did concern nuclear weapons in some way did not involve their nuclear components. They involved things like stripped threads on a bolt; sprinkler systems being activated inadvertently; intentionally sensitive alarms going off without reason; flat tyres on trailers for the weapons in question; small fuel spillages when fuelling an aircraft to transport weapons, and matters of that kind.

There were only two accidents in that entire period of the hundreds to which Senator Sanders referred that could properly be classified as nuclear accidents. They were respectively the loss of an A4E jet with a bomb on board when it rolled off a United States aircraft carrier in the western Pacific in 1965, 21 years ago; and another in 1968 which was associated with the loss of the United States submarine Scorpion which sank in the Atlantic, again nearly 20 years ago. Let us have no more of this humbug about a parade of alleged statistics of incidents and accidents that have occurred with nuclear weapons. That is simply not the case.

Turning finally to the substance of Senator Sanders's question about the possibility of accidents associated with the visit of ships to Australia for the naval review, ships which may or may not be nuclear armed, the Government is satisfied that the standards required by the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation countries, including France, in respect of nuclear weapons safety, coupled with the precautions taken on board visiting warships, effectively preclude the possibility of accidental nuclear detonation.

The most serious accident that could credibly ever occur would be detonation of the conventional explosive in a nuclear weapon. This could result in the dispersion of some radioactive material in the immediate surrounds of the vessel, although most would be contained within the hull of the warship concerned.

Measures for dealing with weapons accidents are covered in the general emergency arrangements made for all visits by foreign warships. Routine radiation monitoring of conventionally powered nuclear-capable warships is not carried out because there are no publicly hazardous radioactive fission products associated with the presence on ships of nuclear weapons.

Mr President, I acknowledge that this is a long answer, but it was an unconscionably long question. As to the NUWAX-81 report to which Senator Sanders referred, the situation is as follows: The after accident report of the 1981 United States Defense Nuclear Agency nuclear weapons exercise-NUWAX-discussed the lessons derived from the simulated collision of a light aircraft and a United States Army helicopter transporting nuclear weapons. It is a type of contingency which might possibly occur in a North Atlantic Treaty Organisation country, but has no relevance to the safety issues associated with visits to Australian ports by nuclear capable warships, which I have outlined above, or for any other current United States activity in Australia. To date there have been three NUWAX exercises, all the scenarios of which involved simulated accidents with airborne weapons. The United States Government has not proposed that Australian forces take part in any NUWAX-type exercises, not did the United States Defense Nuclear Agency recommend in the NUWAX-81 report that Australian forces should hold exercises with United States forces.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Resources and Energy seen a report in the Economist magazine from London which includes an international comparison of retail petrol prices? If so, how does Australia rank overall in terms of fuel prices? Does the article support Opposition claims concerning the level of Australian petrol prices?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Naturally enough, I have seen the article in the Economist of 30 August to which Senator Maguire refers. It is based on data collected by the International Energy Agency and provides further confirmation of my statements made on many previous occasions-the most recent was yesterday-that Australian petrol prices are among the very lowest of the Western industrialised countries. I would have thought the Opposition would be impressed by this evidence, coming as it does from an impeccably dry source, the Economist, whose articles are normally quoted with such raging enthusiasm. The petrol price quoted for Australia is about the same as Canada's and is only slightly more than that of the United States of America. It is substantially lower, in most cases, than the prices in the other 12 major industrialised countries which are quoted in the article.

ANSWER.PARA: The rate of tax on petrol is also among the very lowest of those countries quoted in the article. Australia's tax on petrol, quoted in the article at 45 per cent of the consumer price, is the fourth lowest on the list and is substantially lower than the average of 60 per cent for the countries listed. The article also compares the petrol price reduction in the major Western industrialised countries that have followed the plunge in the price of crude oil since the beginning of this year. Australia's price fall, at about 15 per cent, lies in the mid-range of those countries listed. Given our low petrol prices to begin with, this reduction has maintained very much our competitive position among those countries with the lowest cost liquid fuels.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Did the Government cause Mr Des Corcoran, the former Labor Premier of South Australia, to be told yesterday that he was not to be reappointed to the Council of the Australian War Memorial? Did the decision reverse a previous decision that he was to be reappointed? Why was the decision made not to reappoint Mr Corcoran? Why was he informed only 24 hours before he was due to take his place at a meeting of the Australian War Memorial Council today?
—I will have to direct that question to the Minister and obtain an answer as soon as possible.

—Is the Minister for Education aware that claims have been made that there has been a falling off of involvement in post-compulsory education recently? Is there any basis for those claims and, if so, what action does the Minister propose to take to encourage people to participate in further education?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been no fall-off in participation rates in education; indeed, the contrary is true, certainly since the Hawke Government has been in office. Attendance at education institutions has been steadily increasing and has significantly outstripped population growth. The recent Australian Bureau of Statistics finding indicated that in 1985 there were 1,300,000 young people between the ages of 15 and 24 attending an educational institution. This is an 11 per cent increase since our Government came to power and represents 50 per cent of that population.

ANSWER.PARA: The results are particularly impressive for those people over 25 years of age, where there has been a 25 per cent increase in participation over the same period, bringing the number of mature age people in education to 667,000. These figures vindicate our Government's policies directed at increasing participation in education at all levels and reflect the community's confidence in the education system. For example, our moves to bring the youth income support arrangements on to a more rational and generous basis have allowed many more students to continue their education at a time when they may have otherwise chosen to go on to unemployment benefit.

In the case of the secondary assistance scheme there has been an increase of over 20,000 in the number of students assisted to date and we expect that another 38,000 students will benefit from the scheme, which is now called Austudy, in 1987. Similarly, we will be increasing benefits available for tertiary students in 1987. Of course, as the Senate will be aware, in response to the growing demands for higher education, by 1987 our Government will have created an additional 36,000 places since coming to office.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Special Minister of State. No doubt the Minister is an avid listener to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation news in the morning, as I am. I ask whether he noted this morning that the news report referred to the annual report of the Department of the House of Representatives, which indicated that the hours of members of parliament had increased, and referred also to the fact, as reported, that the take home pay of members of parliament is $73,000. I ask the Minister whether the latter statement is correct.

—No, it is not correct, as all honourable senators would be acutely aware. The basic salary for back bench members of parliament is $45,543 which, after tax and Medicare, comes out at around $27,417. Added to that is the basic electorate allowance, assuming that it is all untaxed-that may be a large assumption these days-of $17,329, which is a total take home pay not of $73,000 but of $44,746. In addition, there is the travel allowance component for overnight stays in Canberra and other capital cities. The extent to which that allowance can be fully written off by the individual member of parliament varies to some extent; but equally clearly, it is inconceivable that any possible addition of the travel allowance component to the figures I have mentioned could get a figure anywhere like the $73,000 that has been mentioned.

—Has the attention of the Acting Minister for Foreign Affairs been drawn to a report in the Melbourne Age today indicating an impending famine in Mozambique which in part is the result of a South African backed insurgency in the country? Will the Government urgently consider responding to the Mozambique Government's appeal for emergency aid to assist in the crisis?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware from Press reports this week that the Government of Mozambique has appealed for international assistance in the form of food in view of its precarious domestic food situation. In fact, Mozambique is one of five countries in Africa still critically affected by food shortages. In 1985-86 Australia provided Mozambique with 7,000 tonnes of food aid for use in direct emergency relief feeding and 7,000 tonnes in support of agricultural development. The total cost of that was $5m, including freight. This gift represented a significant increase over the level of food aid provided in the previous year and reflected the Australian Government's increasing concern about the food situation in that country.

ANSWER.PARA: In approving this financial year's food aid allocations Mr Hayden has placed highest priority on allocations of emergency food situations such as the one which is currently facing Mozambique. Consequently, although details have not yet been finalised, the emergency allocation for Mozambique is likely to be of approximately the same magnitude as that in 1985-86. The Australian Development Assistance Bureau is currently examining a number of requests for food assistance to Mozambique, including from a number of Australian non-government aid organisations operating in that country. In view of the Mozambique Government's appeal, the normal procedures involved in making formal food aid offers to recipient governments will be accelerated this year in respect of Mozambique. As in 1985-86, this may include the provision of some surplus Zimbabwean maize generated by a swap for Australian wheat.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Leader of the Government in the Senate aware of the Taillon drug importation case, which has highlighted the fact that drug traffickers travelling through Australia to another country cannot be arrested under existing laws and have to be allowed to go free? Does the Minister know that the Federal Government promised nearly a year ago to carry out an urgent review of this anomaly in our laws and that so far all that has happened is that the Government has taken nine months to work out, under this urgent review, that the matter is one that rests within the Minister's portfolio? What does the Minister intend to do? Will he amend the laws to stop this ridiculous anomaly, or will he follow the example of the Special Minister of State and the Attorney-General and do nothing?
—I am aware of the circumstances of the case in question. The matter is in the hands of the Attorney-General and I will obtain an answer to the honourable senator's question from him.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Senator Foreman having addressed a question to the Minister for Finance-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I rule the question out of order as the matters raised are not within the Minister's responsibility.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. In the light of continuing high interest rates and the continuing decline in new dwelling starts as well as the increasing difficulty Australians face in translating into reality their dreams of home ownership, what changes will the Government make in its private domestic housing policy to give more hope to Australians wanting to own their home, to avoid any further increase in building industry unemployment and to achieve greater equity between new and old home buyers?
—I suppose the most direct answer to the honourable senator's question is that I have no idea.
—That is what we thought.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY: GOVERNMENT HOUSING LOANS

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Finance aware of Liberal Party opposition to the Government's decision to change interest rates on Government housing loans in the Australian Capital Territory? What would be the budgetary consequences if the Opposition's position were to prevail?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware that Mr Louttit, who is still the President of the Australian Capital Territory Branch of the Liberal Party, as I understand it--
—No, he is not.
—He is the former President. He has been running around saying that the Liberal Party is opposed to this Budget measure.
—He is a Liberal Party candidate.

—That is even worse. He has been running around saying that the Liberal Party is opposed to this, it will not allow it to happen, and so on. I do not know whether that view is shared by members of the Parliamentary Liberal Party but I do note that that assertion by Mr Louttit has not been repudiated by the Liberal Party's parliamentary Leader. Of course the Liberal Party's parliamentary Leader ought to be repudiating it for, among other things, this reason: It is asserted ad nauseam that this action involves the breaking of contracts. The fact is that probably far more than half of the contracts have escalation clauses in them. They have always been there. The precise number is not known but it is known that a very large minority, if not a majority, of the people who took out these loans many years ago do not still live in the houses for which they have the loans. A lot of them do not even live in the Australian Capital Territory. Monthly rental-purchase payments have been as low as, would you believe, $40. Even Doug Anthony, a few years ago-of course he was a beneficiary of such a housing loan-had repayments of $75 a month. Some of these loan repayments are as low as $40 a month.

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. The Minister was asked a simple question about the budgetary consequences of this action, and he is clearly debating the question. I would ask you to call him to order.
—I am listening to the Minister and I will hear his answer, but I ask him to bear in mind standing order 100.

—Certainly, Mr President. I do not believe I am debating the matter; I believe I am supplying information relevant to the question. These $40 a month payments could be increased to as much as $83 a month. That has provoked shrieks of outrage from the self-indulgent, selfish and egocentric people who live in this Territory and have been sponging on the taxpayers for 20 years. The interest rates are as low as three and seven-eighths per cent.

ANSWER.PARA: It is also being asserted that there are no precedents for this sort of action by government. Of course there are precedents. The Premiers plan of 1931, for example, arbitrarily cut the interest rate on all existing Commonwealth bonds held by domestic bond holders. In New South Wales freehold titles were amended, I think in 1981, regarding the ownership of coal. Indeed, some other legislation which could be claimed as a precedent is about to come up in the Senate this afternoon. Many of these people have had the temerity to acknowledge publicly that they have second and third houses which they are paying off, but they still have these three and seven-eighths per cent loans which they expect to have in perpetuity from the rest of the taxpayers of Australia. The cost to the Budget is not great-of the order of $2m-should the Liberal Party's opposition to this be pressed. The principle involved is terribly important, and no principle is more important than the obligation on the Leader of the Opposition to repudiate what Mr Louttit has been saying.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question to the Minister for Education follows the answer just given by the Minister for Finance. Does she agree with the description of her constituents as greedy, selfish and egocentric people who live in the Australian Capital Territory?
—I would happily take the opportunity to sing the praises of my constituents, but I am afraid Senator Chaney's question does not come within my ministerial portfolio.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services. The neighbourhood houses provide considerable occasional child care in varying amounts from place to place. —I am representing Senator Grimes today but I do not have a specific brief on the matter raised by Senator Crowley. I am sure that Senator Crowley's constituents have been ill advised because I cannot imagine that we would be ruling out services that already exist. I will have to get the guidelines and a commentary on them from Senator Grimes.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Is it correct that the reported reasons for this request by Mr Warburton are a reflection of Queenslanders' concern about Federal Government policies in general and, in particular, the fringe benefits tax which is so strongly opposed by Mr Burke, the Premier of Western Australia?

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations is about statements concerning the Peko-Wallsend Ltd dispute which were made by the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard. In the first statement, which appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald of 29 August 1986, he said:

QUESTION.PARA: On behalf of the Opposition . . . Mr Charles Copeman and his colleagues in Peko deserve the support of all Australians who believe in the reform of our industrial system.
In the second statement, reported in the Australian of 29 August 1986, he said:
I do not accept that Peko is breaking or defying the law. That is a distortion of what has happened.
Will these statements influence Government policy in light of the decision handed down by the Supreme Court in Western Australia relating to this dispute?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to the latter part of the question, which asks whether Mr Howard's statements are in conflict with the decisions handed down in the Western Australian Supreme Court, the answer is clearly that they are. Mr Howard said that he did not believe that Peko was breaking or defying the law. The Supreme Court of Western Australia found that Peko was doing just that and accordingly issued an order with which Peko complied. I do not know whether the Leader of the Opposition still defends-not only defends but also enthusiastically supports-the action that Peko was taking, now that the court has found that that action was, in fact, illegal. It would be interesting to know whether Mr Howard is still, now that that activity has been declared illegal, supporting it.

ANSWER.PARA: In response to the earlier part of the question, which referred to Mr Howard's enthusiastic endorsement of Mr Copeman and the actions of Peko-Wallsend Ltd in that dispute, let me say that I have already drawn to the attention of the Senate the fact that Mr Copeman's policy on government financing, both State and Federal, would have the effect of withdrawing some $375m from Western Australia. So, it would be interesting to know whether Senator Chaney, Senator Knowles and a number of other Western Australian senators endorse Mr Copeman's view on that. The fact that Mr Howard was an eager supporter of the action that Peko was taking-subsequently declared to be illegal-is, I regret to say, just another symptom demonstrating the fact that under this weak leader the Liberal Party is being taken over by the extreme Right.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Treasurer to statements by the State governments that they are being forced to increase a wide range of taxes and charges and to reduce significantly the numbers in their public services. I ask: First, what consequential increases, if any, in percentage terms were made in the bulk Budget calculation when it arrived at an inflation level of 8 per cent? Secondly, how was that factor calculated? What assumptions were made? Thirdly, if no allowance was made, what increment of inflation will flow from State actions? Finally, in calculating a growth in unemployment of 36,000 in the Budget, what calculations were made for State and local government reductions in employment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the last part of the question, the figure for the estimate of unemployment benefit recipients was derived principally from the growth forecast, with an adjustment incorporating the estimate of the lower number of UB recipients because of the tightening of unemployment benefit administration. Senator Sir John Carrick referred to the statements which have been made by a lot of State governments that, because the Federal Government has not given them enough money, they will have to increase charges, lay off people and that sort of thing. I think I can remember that sort of thing being said every year, certainly since I have been in Parliament and also for many years before. There is nothing new about that.

ANSWER.PARA: I think it ought to be noted that the major payments which the Commonwealth makes to the States, that is, the recurrent per capita grants, have been increased by 2 per cent in real terms. Some 70 to 80 per cent of most State government expenditure is in wages. Wages have already been discounted and will, under the Budget policy, be discounted again during this financial year. So, the major part of State government expenditure is rising at a consumer price index minus rate-a rate less than the CPI-and the major component of State government income is increasing at a CPI plus rate, more than the CPI. So, there is a fair margin between those two things. That applies to the States in general.

Senator Sir John Carrick asked what assumptions had been made in determining the Budget's estimated CPI increase figure of, I think, 7.9 per cent and what portion of that was attributed to State governments having to increase their charges. I am not sure what it was; I will try to obtain that from the Treasurer.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is again directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to claims by the Premier of Queensland that Queensland is a low tax State? Can the Minister verify these claims? If Queensland is not a low tax State, as the Premier of Queensland claims, what are the implications for the Queensland and national economies of the level of State taxation applicable in Queensland?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am asked whether I can verify the Premier's claims that Queensland is a low tax State. The answer to that is no, I cannot verify those claims. Indeed, I will not, because they are not in fact correct. There was a time when many-though by no means all-government charges were lower in Queensland than in other States. The principal reason for that was the hidden tax which the Queensland Government collected from mining companies, principally Utah but also CSR Ltd and others, through overcharging them for rail freight. I think that some years ago an estimate of $150m to $200m a year was made for the excess rail freight which was being creamed off by the Queensland Government. This would be regarded as a tax in any other State, but it was not recorded as a tax in Queensland. For that reason the figures at that time, as they were officially recorded, gave a substantially misleading impression of the real underlying situation.

ANSWER.PARA: However, in more recent times the rate of government charges and taxes, as recorded by the Australian Bureau of Statistics in the government charges index, has been increasing in Queensland at a rate very much faster than the consumer price index and very much faster than in any other State. Therefore, it has been increasing very much faster than the national average. Indeed, the figures show that the government charges index in Brisbane between the June quarter of 1984 and the June quarter of 1986 increased by 21.8 per cent. This was over a two-year period when the weighted average for the eight capitals was only 14.8 per cent and the consumer price index increased by 14.6 per cent. That was some 7 per cent higher than either the consumer price index or the weighted average for all capital cities. Charges in Queensland increased nearly half as much again, as they did in the other capital cities, on average.

If one looks at the period from the June quarter of 1985 to the June quarter of 1986-that is, of course, the most recent year-one finds once again that the government charges index increased at a faster rate in Queensland than in any other State, indeed at a rate of 9.5 per cent. That is significantly higher than the consumer price index increase in the same period and a great deal higher-again, of the order of 50 per cent higher-than the weighted average for the eight capitals.

Queensland is not a low tax State. When a proper accounting assessment is done it never has been a low tax State although it may not have been the highest tax State in the past. In the last two years it is certainly the State in which government charges and taxes have been increasing at a very much faster rate than they have been anywhere else. The fact that the contrary is being claimed by the Queensland Government in its advertisements is just another measure of the fundamental fraudulence of the campaign of that State Government and of its desperation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs to the report in today's Age which indicated that amendments to the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act have been abandoned because of the Federal Government's concern that the Northern Territory will renege on agreements concerning excisions of land for Aboriginals from pastoral leases. If the report is correct, what source does the Federal Government have to suggest that the Northern Territory Government planned to take this action, particularly in view of the fact that in the past month seven newly excised titles have been granted and many others are being processed? If the report is not correct, what is the reason for the deferral? Is it because the Labor Caucus has reneged on the legislation?
—I am not aware of any announcement that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has made on this matter. Cabinet still has the matter of the Northern Territory legislation under consideration.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Defence concerned that a perception that Australia is maintaining only a token presence on Christmas Island, with the winding down of the phosphate mining operations there, likely to invite a dispute over the sovereignty of the island? If so, and in view of the recent problems regarding landing rights for Royal Australian Air Force aircraft in Indonesia, will the Government be reconsidering the possibility of developing Christmas Island as a base to assist our patrols into the Indian Ocean?

—I am advised by the Minister for Defence that there is no dispute with any country over the sovereignty of Christmas Island and none is considered likely to develop. There are no plans at present to develop Christmas Island as a military base. It is not considered necessary to establish a military base to maintain our sovereignty over the island, nor to support defence deployments to the Indian Ocean. Existing facilities at Christmas Island will continue to be used to support defence operations as necessary. I should add, I suppose, for the record that the recent quite separate issue of landing rights for RAAF aircraft in Indonesia, which apparently arose from a misunderstanding, has now been resolved.

—I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. What improvements were made to the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs after the Parliament increased the Institute's responsibilities last year and the government cut of 30 per cent from its Budget? What will be the staffing and annual running cost of the new Office of Multicultural and Ethnic Affairs which is set to replace the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs? What extra funds will the Government channel into community education activities and independent multicultural research to fill the gap left if the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs is dismembered? What was the reason for disbanding the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs, despite the advice of the Jupp Committee, and for this Government's attacks on the independence and integrity of the Special Broadcasting Service, the migrant education program and the English as a second language program and the closure of regional offices of the Department throughout the Australian community?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the honourable senator to place his question on notice. It is a very detailed question requiring a great deal of factual information. However, as an example, let me comment on the reason for disbanding the Institute of Multicultural Affairs and the changes made to the Special Broadcasting Service. Both those decisions were made in a budgetary context. In both cases the Commonwealth had assumed and maintained functions which it was not prepared to continue to maintain. The reason for that, in the case of the SBS, is that Australia is one of three countries in the Western world which maintain a taxpayer funded national broadcasting service, the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. In the view of the Government this country cannot afford to maintain two taxpayer funded public broadcasting services. It is a luxury which cannot be afforded by this country.

ANSWER.PARA: One can make similar sorts of comments about some of the other things which were raised in the honourable senator's question. But in all these matters in which the well of inspiration clearly springs in the honourable senator's heart from the complaints of one or two aggrieved, let me say that the Government is in the position of having to make responsible decisions about these things and is not in the position in which a new Democrat senator from South Australia can indulge himself. Insofar as there are factual matters in the honourable senator's question, I will direct them to the appropriate Minister and have the honourable senator provided with an answer as soon as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister representing the Treasurer seen an international report which has found that the Australian dollar has been oversold and that it is substantially below its true value on the international exchanges? If so, can the Minister provide the Government's response to the report which examined purchasing power based exchange rates in 15 major trading nations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen-this is no joke-an article published in the Economist of 6 September. It is on page 67 if anybody wants to look it up. It refers to the Big Mac triple P rating. The Big Mac triple P rating is the Big Mac hamburger purchasing power parity. In a somewhat lighthearted vein, the article has a table giving the cost of a Big Mac hamburger in a number of countries, adjusted for exchange rate variations between those countries.
—What is it in Saudi Arabia?

—Saudi Arabia is not on the list. What it shows is that after adjustments for the exchange rate there is a 34 per cent discrepancy between the purchasing power of the Australian dollar measured against the cost of a Big Mac hamburger and its official exchange rate. So from that it is concluded-I am not sure how seriously-that the Australian dollar is undervalued by some 34 per cent. I do not think that is a conclusion which many serious students of the international monetary market or any serious student of economics would agree with.

ANSWER.PARA: But to the best of my knowledge the facts presented are correct; that is, that it costs in terms of real purchasing power 34 per cent less to buy a Big Mac hamburger in Australia than it costs in the United States of America. It does, however, draw attention to a more significant and more serious matter; that is, that there are a lot of bargains in Australia, that Australian goods at present current exchange rates are very cheap against the exchange rates of other countries. That is something which the Government is well aware of. It presents a great opportunity to Australian industry, both for export growth and for the increasing substitution of domestic production for goods which are currently imported. Indeed, as the Budget Papers forecast, it is in that very way-that is, the improvement in net exports because of the highly competitive exchange rate we now have-that most of the economic growth forecast in the Budget will originate.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. Given the estimated $6m shortfall in Queensland's compensation for 1986-87 under the brucellosis and tuberculosis eradication campaign, due to a predicted doubling of the number of cattle to be destocked from 60,000 to 120,000, will the Minister support half the destocked cattle being placed in feed lots so that they can be fattened and sold for slaughter, thereby recouping some $3m which could contribute to other aspects of the BTEC program?

—With regard to the last part of the question, I understand that is a matter at which the Minister for Primary Industry is looking. In regard to the first part of the question as to the alleged $6m shortfall and so on, if that figure originates from the Queensland Government, quite frankly I would not accept it until I have had it independently verified. We have ample experience to demonstrate that the facts and figures are sometimes misrepresented by the Queensland Government.
—Rubbery.

—Yes, they are rubbery, to say the least. The Queensland Government, it would appear, will refuse to disclose essential details of the way in which it has handled Commonwealth money. In short, at any time figures produced by the Queensland Government are likely to be rubbery and highly suspect.
—Answer the question. She asked a sensible question.

—I do not know what is agitating Senator Boswell. Perhaps he got one of those lousy $145,000 loans, most of it at 4 per cent as well. I do not know whether he did; if he did, I wish he would stand up and make a declaration about it. Perhaps there were not enough lousy $145,000 loans to go around for every National Party apparatchik in Queensland. At any time figures presented and assertions made by the Queensland Government ought to be subjected to independent assessment before they are accepted, but even more so in a period such as this when there is an election campaign on the way.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that I have received the following letter, dated 24 September, from Senator Siddons:

INTERJECT.PARA: Pursuant to Standing Order 64, I give notice that today I propose to move-
`That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
