More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-
That so much of Standing Order 64 be suspended as would prevent the senator speaking third in the debate from speaking for up to 20 minutes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I amend the motion that has been circulated in my name to change one word which was included by mistake. I move the revised motion:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

`The Government's current strategy of reducing the authority of the Foreign Investment Review Board, which will open the door for foreign companies to buy the remainder of our wealth producing industries at rock bottom prices.'

This motion covers what can only be described as the most important issue facing Australia today or ever likely to face this country. We are debating essentially whether Australians are to control their country or whether we are again to be colonised. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said only last Thursday that he wanted to internationalise the Australian economy as quickly as possible. On the basis of the Government's record we can only assume that when the Prime Minister says he wants to internationalise the Australian economy he is saying that he wants to sell out the assets of Australians to foreign capital and overseas interests.

Foreign investment has been progressively encouraged by this Government, firstly on ideological grounds and later, in a state of panic, as a way of getting our balance of payments problem under control. Unfortunately, most of the foreign investment regulations are policy matters decided by the Treasurer (Mr Keating). This has meant in effect that it has been possible for the Government to weaken substantially the regulations relating to foreign investment in this country without referring these changes of policy to the Parliament. This is one of the few occasions on which we will have an opportunity to debate what is going on. Foreign investment guidelines in Australia at the moment are virtually non-existent, and this has never been brought to the attention of the Parliament.

We saw just two days ago how powerful the socialists in the Victorian division of the Australian Labor Party are. They were prepared to drop the third-ranking Minister in the Government to third place on the Senate ticket and put an ex-member of the Communist Party of Australia in the No. 1 spot. The essential thrust of the socialist ideology, as I understand it, is that they are concerned about who should own the means of production. They believe the state should own it. On this point the Australian Democrats are in fundamental disagreement. We believe that individuals or co-operatives or employee owners or the public should own the productive wealth of this country. We do not believe that the means of production should be owned by the state. At least the socialists have going for them the fact that they are concerned about who should control the means of production. If Australians control the means of production in this country then Australians will control the country. If overseas interests control the means of production in Australia then overseas interests essentially will control this country, and what we say or do in this Parliament will become nothing more than a charade.

It is incredible that a Labor Government, which is supposed to represent the interests of working Australians, has travelled now 180 degrees from the central issue of who should control the ownership of the means of production here. Its members are now saying: `We are economic rationalists. We believe the highest bidder should own the productive capacity of this country'. This means ipso facto that eventually the highest bidders for our productive resources will be overseas bidders, simply because in the long term 15 million people cannot hope to outbid the entire world. As soon as an Australian company goes international and is successful and begins to worry a large overseas competitor, all that competitor has to do is turn to Australia and buy out the company that is causing the trouble, generally for an amount that, in relation to the competitor's size, would be purely petty cash.

I wonder sometimes why we worry about spending money on defending Australia. Who on earth would attack this country when all that attacker has to do is come in and buy it up, not surreptitiously but with the open invitation of the Government? The Government is saying: `Come and buy up our assets'. This is a disastrous course for it to be adopting and one that will have to change. I have spent a lifetime working day and night building up an Australian enterprise of which I am proud and of which the other employee owners are proud. Our motivation over all those years was simply that we were helping to build an enterprise that would strengthen the development of this great country. Our watchword was `achievement'. Financial rewards were always secondary considerations.

The Government is suddenly saying to all those people-a whole generation-who put so much effort into establishing the wealth-producing enterprises of this country: `Don't worry about doing that any more. We are perfectly happy for you to sell out these companies to the board rooms of Japan, the United States of America, the United Kingdom or wherever. We do not care who owns this country's productive wealth'. Australia can never be a great nation while it is subservient to foreign masters. That is the essential reason why this Parliament should revolt at what the Government is doing. As Australians, we should be prepared to make any sacrifice to protect the ownership, integrity and independence of this country.

It is significant that it was the Liberals, under Mr McMahon, who introduced the foreign takeovers legislation. Mr Fraser later set up the Foreign Investment Review Board. I will be interested to hear what the Liberals' attitude is. Are they still concerned about who controls Australia, or has the Liberal Party of Australia been so infiltrated by radical free marketeers that it no longer cares who owns this country's productive wealth?

The proposition which is most frequently cast around at the moment is that we must sell off our assets to finance our trade deficit. This can only be described as the ultimate in idiocy. Rather than addressing the economy's fundamental problem-the balance of payments-we are to solve it by selling off our assets to cover our cash flow problems. That approach is not only morally wrong, because eventually we will have no say in what Australia's direction is, but also economically nonsensical. Overseas investors bring in their money as a once-off cash flow-that is, the money to buy an enterprise comes in once-but, once the enterprise is bought, there is a continual flow outwards from Australia as the dividends from that enterprise continually go back to the foreign owners. No overseas investor would buy a company without planning to get his money back in about three years. It is a short term approach to think that we can sell off our wealth-producing assets and solve our balance of payments problem in that way.

When we look at the figures it becomes obvious that we will not succeed with this policy. Income payable abroad due to foreign investment in this country has skyrocketed from $2,884m in 1982-83 to $6,303m in 1984-85-a three-fold increase in the money flowing out of Australia to service the assets that have been bought by foreign interests.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not dividends.

—That is servicing the dividends. The position is doubly critical now because the dollar is at rock bottom levels. If we do not do something about controlling the selling of our assets, there will be an enormous attack on those assets and they will be bought at very low prices. To illustrate this point, let us consider a Japanese company with, say, 10,000 million yen to invest in Australia. In 1974 that 10,000 million yen would have bought an Australian company worth $24m. Today it would buy an Australian company worth $107m. We are selling our productive resources at rock bottom prices.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats are not, of course, saying that there should be a blanket ban on foreign investment. We are simply saying that it is vital for Australia to regain control of the economy. We would like much greater attention to be paid to how the money that flows into this country is invested. If it is invested in productive resources and new industries, it will eventually help our balance of payments, but if the capital which flows into this country simply takes over an existing company that will not help our balance of payments one little bit. One often hears the argument that, without foreign capital, Australia would not have the capital to develop its enterprises. Over the past 20 years, Australians have supplied 90 per cent of the capital required to develop this country. The problem has been that most of that capital has gone into building houses, roads and other infrastructure, and that we have let foreign capital move in to existing companies and let ownership of those companies move outside Australia.

The whole foreign investment debate has been carried on in terms of bland macroeconomic arguments about the balance of payments. The strategic side of the equation, which is the important side, has been virtually completely ignored. We must consider one very important aspect: If we wish to have a strong export oriented manufacturing and servicing industry, we must have greater Australian ownership. The first thing a foreign-owned Australian subsidiary does is become involved in export franchises. Foreign owners always like to have their research carried out at their head office overseas. There is no doubt that our poor export performance with manufactured goods and our poor research and development performance have been due to the fact that Australian ownership of Australian industry has fallen dramatically. Australia is one of the most foreign dominated economies in the Western world, matched only by Canada.

The United Nations Committee on Trade and Development has estimated that 40 per cent of world trade is conducted on an intercorporate basis-that is, components are transferred between subsidiary companies around the world. This means that, if Australia is to be an exporter of manufactured goods, it must develop multinational Australian-owned organisations. In that way, we will be able to move components from one subsidiary to another and obtain the benefit of that international trade. Multinational companies always think in terms of the best outcome for their global operations. Profits always flow back to head office; they are not generally retained to any great degree in the subsidiary company.

We have a sad record of Australian companies which have been brave and adventurous and which have developed international markets being taken over by foreign companies. Nicholas Kiwi is a case in point. In the 1960s, it was regarded in ethical drug manufacturing circles as a respected international competitor. Recently, it was taken over and it is now owned by Sara Lee of the United States of America. Repco, another company which was export oriented, was recently taken over by New Zealand interests.

There is no doubt that any successful exporting Australian company will be subjected to international attack. As soon as it is successful, an attempt will be made to buy it and take it over just to control its export activities. Unless we face up to the needs for controls on foreign investment in our industries, we will never be a substantial exporting country of manufactured goods. It is very interesting to look at a country such as Sweden which is about half the size of Australia in terms of population. Whereas 10 per cent of that country's industries are in foreign hands, the figure in Australia is close to 50 per cent. Yet Sweden can develop very vibrant and successful export companies which are going from strength to strength.

A survey conducted recently of Japanese subsidiary companies in Australia showed that virtually no export from Japanese subsidiary companies in Australia was attempted. It also showed that virtually no research and development was attempted in Australia by Japanese companies. Although these are economic considerations, I get back to the fundamental point that unless we control our wealth producing industries, Australians will never really have control of their country. We will develop a branch mentality and we will be concerned more with taking orders from overseas bosses than making decisions of our own and trying to do what is in the overall interests of this country.

Australia exports about 20 per cent of its manufactured goods, while most European Economic Community countries export something like 80 per cent of theirs. So we have a long way to go; we are very far behind what has been achieved by other countries. I hope that the Liberals will see the importance of the issue of controlling foreign investment in Australia. They took up the issue first in this country. If we are going to have a complete open door mentality, Australia undoubtedly will finish up being colonised just as surely as it was in the beginning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating today an urgency motion from the Australian Democrats, the thrust of which is as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's current strategy of reducing the authority of the Foreign Investment Review Board, which will open the door for foreign companies to buy the remainder of our wealth producing industries at rock bottom prices.

At the outset, let me state that the Liberal-National coalition cannot support this urgency motion, which is a desperate attempt by desperate Democrats to whip up cheap emotionalism. It does not recognise the critical economic situation in which Australia finds itself today. Australia has always relied on foreign capital. The question is: How do we want that capital? Do we want it in borrowings, the interest on which must be repaid on a regular basis-and, of course, the capital must in time be repaid-or do we want it by way of equity where the investor takes the same risks as do his Australian counterparts? Notwithstanding this urgency motion, the Democrats cannot make up their minds on this simple question.

Over the past year we have heard Senator Siddons repeatedly say that interest on overseas borrowings should not be tax deductible for Australian companies making investments in Australia. Now he is saying that we should prevent overseas capital being directed to equity investment in Australia. I believe that economic realists in the Government, such as, I imagine, Senator Walsh and probably Senator Richardson, who will follow me in this debate, would be the first to admit that encouragement for Australians to borrow overseas rather than encouragement for foreign equity investment was a mistake.

The Foreign Investment Review Board had its origins in the Foreign Investment Committee set up in fact by the Whitlam Government. Prior to that time the only real requirement for a would-be investor was to seek Reserve Bank of Australia approval to enable that investor to bring funds into Australia. The late 1960s and early 1970s were the beginnings of the great mineral developments in the Pilbara and the Bowen basin. It is too horrific to contemplate where we would be today without those developments. The Whitlam Government initiated a political campaign of hate against the foreign equity of those companies. We heard emotive phrases such as `ripping and raping' the country. I heard similar emotive phrases from Senator Siddons today, which rather surprised me. He said things such as `we are in danger of being colonised' and `we must control our means of production'. I would like to ask Senator Siddons: Who votes in this country, who elects governments and who makes the laws? It is not the people who invest here, whether they invest by way of equity or loans.

This campaign in the 1970s by the Whitlam Government culminated, of course, in the shady Khemlani loans affair, the justification for which was to buy back the farm. At that time it cost the Americans $1.49 and the Japanese 440 yen to buy an Australian dollar. Yet there was an enthusiasm to take equity investment in Australia. The aim of the FIC was to tell foreign capital that equity investment was out and borrowings were in. Based on emotion, it set in train a series of managerial decisions which continue to haunt us today. This and export controls, which were also aimed at foreign investors, prevented projects developing and those projects still remain undeveloped today. Others were postponed until the defeat of the Whitlam Government and there are many examples of that, at a great cost to this country. In that period investment in the great mineral industry fell off. I can recall at the time trying to encourage the company I was with not only to maintain but to increase its exploration programs.

As everyone knows, exploration is to a mineral industry what research and development is to other industries. We approached the then Minister for Minerals and Energy, Mr Connor, and asked the simple question: What will happen if, as a result of continuing exploration, a major resource is discovered? His response was `Keep exploring' and, if successful, he would then determine whether the resource could be developed. What an encouragement for continued investment in this country at that time!

Another example is the Newlands mine operated by Mount Isa Mines Ltd. That company had the opportunity to develop Newlands and, with a Japanese partner which also happened to be a buyer, provide the infrastructure, which they were prepared to pay for, for town water, power, roads, rail and a port at Bowen. The FIRB regulations prevented the foreign equity and Mount Isa Mines was forced to borrow overseas an amount of the order of $1,000m. The market turned down, the dollar collapsed and the company was lumbered with enormous regular interest payments which would not have been necessary if that $1,000m could have been in equity. That is not to say that Mount Isa Mines was giving up control; that was not its proposal.

That is the sort of problem which the Democrats apparently wish to perpetuate. It is the sort of problem which the Government, or at least some members of the Government, now recognise. It is something that must not be permitted to occur again. That company, Mount Isa Mines-and many others-has foreign debt problems through no fault of the company, which had its commercial decisions distorted by government interference.

What is the extent of our foreign debt problem? The Australian Democrats would be well advised to read a most opportune article in today's Australian Financial Review by Dr David Clark, a senior lecturer at the University of New South Wales School of Economics. For the benefit of the Democrats, I will repeat some of the facts I provided in a recent debate on the Loans Bill, many of which are included in the Australian Financial Review article. As at the end of June this year, gross external debt totalled $86 billion, which represents over $5,000 for every man, woman and child in the country. Over the past year interest and loan repayments amounted to about $1,000 for every Australian. A leaked Treasury document estimated that the gross debt is likely to exceed $100 billion by the middle of 1987. Mr Will Buttrose of Lloyds Bank expects it to be about $110 billion by that time.

By the end of 1986 about half of our current account deficit will be made up of overseas debt servicing obligations. Five years ago, only 8 per cent of our export income was needed to repay borrowings and meet interest repayments. It has been estimated that by June 1987 that figure of 8 per cent of exports will have increased to 42 per cent to service our overseas borrowings. Naturally, we do not compare favourably with most other countries in the world. That was one of the factors that brought the admission from the Treasurer (Mr Keating) that we were heading towards being a banana republic, and the comment from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) that we face a crisis akin to war.

Dr Clark makes the point that we are not far removed from the debt situation which has required the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank to intervene in other far less developed nations. The policies of the Hawke Labor Government have caused Moody's Investor Services Inc. to reduce our AAA rating as a borrower. In only three years of the Hawke Labor Government, our gross debt has increased from around $36 billion in 1983 to an estimated $100 billion-plus by 1987, and net external debt has increased from just over $20 billion to over $80 billion in the same period. Total debt servicing costs have increased from about $12 billion to nearly $20 billion in the same three years.

Why has our foreign debt increased at such an alarming rate? Why has the private sector, which is responsible for the largest chunk borrowed overseas, moved so much into foreign debt? I will not go into the government sector today as this urgency motion is aimed at the private sector. Until the mid-1970s borrowings were only a very small part of net private capital inflow. The vast majority was in equity capital. Much as the Democrats would like us to believe otherwise, a leading banker has estimated that the blow-out in private foreign borrowings has not been to finance takeovers. Between 1983 and 1985 borrowings for that purpose totalled less than $4 billion, or less than 20 per cent of the increase in gross private foreign borrowings.

One of the many reasons for the blow-out has been the Foreign Investment Review Board, which has encouraged Australian companies to borrow off-shore. Another major cause has been the devastatingly high domestic interest rates imposed upon the Australian community by the Hawke Government. Apart from the classic example I gave previously of the Newlands Mount Isa coal mine, the time and expense required to obtain FIRB approval for a direct investment proposal, and the delays involved, encouraged Australian companies to borrow rather than seek foreign equity partners. There is no doubt that foreign equity can mean repatriation of dividends, as has been pointed out by Senator Siddons. In a growth period those dividends can also be reinvested in Australia. However, the point is that dividends can be repatriated only if a profit is made. There is no requirement to repay the principal. With borrowings, the interest must be repaid on a regular basis whether the venture makes a profit or not. The absence of profit, where borrowings are concerned, means rollover or renegotiation of loans, which can be totally devastating if the value of our dollar is then lower than it was when the loan was first negotiated. There have been many examples of that. That very real problem does not exist with equity investment.

Briefly, I have some comments about the functions and practical operations of the FIRB. As honourable senators will know, the FIRB was set up to assist the Government in the administration of its foreign investment policy. This is done by an examination of proposals by foreign interests wishing to invest directly in Australia and by explaining Australia's foreign investment policy to business groups.

The average time taken to process all proposals was 43 days in 1984-85, which was 10 days longer than in 1982-83. This does not include the time and money involved in preliminary discussions which can take place prior to formal application. That time can range from three to six months. The delay imposes considerable costs on applicants, even before any investment takes place. There have been occasions of proposals being found to be exempt from review. Such mix-ups are not only costly but also totally unnecessary. In 1984-85 some 1,300 proposals were approved, with a total value of $4.5 billion. Of those 1,300, 40 per cent were approved subject to conditions, and 34 were rejected. If 34 of the 1,300 were rejected, over 1,200 were approved. The average time delay was 43 days. If one wishes to assess the real cost, one has to take into account the time factor, which was between three and six months.

The 1980s have seen a major change in the composition of foreign investment inflows into Australia. In the five years to 1978-79, direct investment accounted for 70 per cent of total foreign capital coming into this country; it now accounts for only 25 per cent. On the other hand, portfolio investments have risen from an average of 29 per cent of total foreign investment in Australia over five years to 74 per cent. Within the portfolio category, inflow into equities has fallen from 23 per cent in 1979-80 to about one per cent. This reflects interest rate differentials which have favoured overseas borrowings. Borrowings have risen from 27 per cent of total foreign investment to 73 per cent. I refer to a graph showing levels of foreign investment in Australian enterprises, broken down into debt and equity investments, between 1975 and 1985. I seek leave to have the graph incorporated in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think it is possible to incorporate such a graph in Hansard; so we cannot give you leave to incorporate it, much as we would like to.

—It is apparent that the Government has at last recognised the negative effects of the Foreign Investment Review Board, particularly the requirements which have forced investors to seek overseas borrowings rather than equity investment. The Government's foreign investment policy has been identified as a major factor that is responsible for enormous foreign debt. The Liberal-National Party coalition does not support the Australian Democrats' urgency motion, which would serve only to compound an already serious and dangerous level of foreign debt in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Had I been asked when I was at university to make a speech on the matter of urgency introduced by Senator Siddons I would have totally agreed with him. The problem in taking that course is that I left university about 16 years ago, and I grew up. What I discovered when I grew up and went into the real world was that the sort of jingoistic nonsense spoken by Senator Siddons bears no relation to the Australia of the 1980s. Any attempt to turn back the clock to pretend that we are not part of the wider world community will fail and there will be great cost to Australian workers. I cannot support such a concept.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to reply to some of the comments made by Senator Parer, who got his wires crossed. I have been critical of honourable senators from Tasmania and Queensland, States which have their problems, but on this occasion Senator Parer spoke about the scourge of foreign debt, the amount by which it has risen, and compared figures in 1981 with what they are likely to be in 1987. However, he failed to point out that the reason that we have had a huge growth in foreign debt in this country is that at the end of 1980, in yet another attempt to win an election, Malcolm Fraser and John Howard talked up a minerals boom. That boom, which lasted all of five minutes, was paid for by foreign debt. Australian companies went all over the world borrowing lots of money for lots of projects, some of which never got off the ground. It is those opposite who put Australia on the path to an increasing foreign debt. Fortunately, it was a Labor government that did something about it.

I agree that foreign debt is a significant problem. It will never get fixed up, however, if the best we can do is to talk up sectors of the economy and ask them to borrow money. What we have done in the past few months is to bring about changes in conditions. I wish to quote from a Fairfax publication-I have never shrunk from doing so-namely, the Australian Financial Review. An article on 22 July this year set out details of the changes in government policy for the Foreign Investment Review Board, which were announced on 28 July. The editorial on that date made a number of points and I wish to take a few minutes to go through them:

The fact is that foreign ownership has not represented a threat to Australian independence in the past, and there is no credible threat presenting itself, notwithstanding the low level of the dollar. Australia desperately needs more, not less, equity investment.
I say to Senator Siddons that it is very hard to argue with that. All the facts bear it out. The editorial continues:

. . . Australia's restrictions on foreign investment are more onerous than most other countries. While most maintain some supervision of the level of foreign ownership, few, if any, have a law against equity above a certain percentage without government approval.

That is also worth knowing, because again I say to Senator Siddons that when one checks around the world one finds that that is true. That is another lesson for the Liberal Party. That Party when in government talked long and loud about deregulation, but did nothing. It has only discovered that it should do something about the suggestion since this Government started doing it in the last couple of years. It is all very well for Senator Parer to talk about the wonders of de- regulation. Where was he during all the years of Fraser Government when it did nothing? He was probably trying to obtain pre-selection, which took him a long time to organise. The editorial further comments:

. . . what statistics there are about the proportions of foreign ownership and control for major sectors of the economy do not support the belief that foreign influence over Australian industry is increasing.

Whenever big changes are required in any section of Australian life, in industry, the unions or anywhere else, one always faces the entrenched opposition. The major part of the editorial goes on to explain where that opposition comes from. It reads:

Inefficient management who want a quiet life in protected home markets need to be threatened, not shored up. The trouble with bodies like the Foreign Investment Review Board is that they give bad management an additional layer of protection. They also inhibit the growth of an efficient, export-oriented manufacturing sector which is desperately needed in Australia now that domestic manufacturing can no longer be parasitic upon agricultural and mineral exports.

That is the crux of the problem. The Government had to deal with the fact that all that has happened by making it harder and harder for people to invest in our manufacturing industry is that it has propped up the inefficient ones and made certain that more and more industries close down. Manufacturing industry was never discovered by the Liberals when they were in government. They had never heard of it and did not want to know about it. They were interested only in the mining industry and in agricultural products. They forced Australia into an unrealistic reliance upon those commodities. This Government is trying to change that balance and to improve the mix. The changes that were announced at the end of July are related to that policy.

I wish to go through the changes because nobody in this debate had spoken of what the Government had actually done. There seems to have been a fundamental misunderstanding, certainly on Senator Siddons's part. First, there was a major relaxation of the foreign investment guidelines to be implemented relating principally to manufacturing industry and to real estate. That was to facilitate equity investment in both those sectors, to try to correct the problem of which Senator Siddons and Senator Parer have spoken. Secondly, the Government decided to abolish dividend withholding tax and branch profits tax from 1987 to coincide with the introduction of the full imputation system. Thirdly, one of the three measures announced was the closing off of interest withholding tax exemption; that was to be reversed.

All these steps were taken to facilitate foreign equity investment and continued access to European and other capital markets through widely spread securities. Fortunately, we have already seen some successes in that program. They flow from the Government's desire to ensure that foreign investment policy is more flexible-more flexible than it has been under the Hawke Government in the last three years and much more flexible than it ever could have been under a Fraser government, which was always a government for regulation. As well as removing a regulatory burden on companies, it makes it easier for foreign investors, not just on their own but in partnership with Australian firms, to pursue opportunities in manufacturing and service activities. The sharp improvement in our competitiveness brought about by the fall in the dollar should enable foreign firms and our own companies to capitalise on that advantage.

Let us look at the details of change in manufacturing. This is the area that interests me most. If we are to have a truly structured Australian economy that can compete with the rest of the world and provide increased standards of living for Australians, that is the sector we have to look at first. The requirement for investors to satisfy economic benefit and Australian equity tests is to be suspended. However, under the terms of that policy suspension, investment proposals will be approved automatically unless they are judged to be contrary to the national interest. Senator Siddons should take note of the national interest.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is that?

—Senator Parer would not know what the national interest is, that is for certain. Fortunately, I have an idea. Senator Siddons should take note that those national interest provisions are still intact; they still have to be satisfied. That is what the Foreign Investment Review Board has to do. Under the changes the rules for foreign investors to notify the Foreign Investment Review Board of their intention to invest remain the same-that is, a single foreign investor planning to take more than a 15 per cent share in a local company or a portfolio investor planning to go beyond 40 per cent has to notify the FIRB before proceeding. It is necessary for that to be maintained because we must ensure that the situation can be monitored. If the dire consequences which Senator Siddons predicts, but which there is no evidence to conclude are happening now, were to happen, the Government would be in a position via the Board and via the maintenance of those provisions to examine the situation and to ensure that it is constantly monitored. The fact is that proposals no longer will have to satisfy the twin tests of economic benefits in Australia. Those proposals will gain automatic approval, provided they are not against the national interest, which will ensure a dramatic increase in equity in Australian industry. That is what everyone in the Parliament wants, which is why the fact that this matter of public importance came up at all today was such a surprise.

SPEECH.PARA: The second area into which the Government moved was real estate. There was a substantial liberalisation of the policy in this area, as there should have been. I took up the cause for a number of very large developers who had problems under the previous regime of investment controls. The reason they had problems was that very often investors, particularly the Japanese, who were prepared to pay very high prices for Australian real estate, were prevented from doing so. That meant that a number of very large development and building companies, particularly in New South Wales and Victoria, had to lay off staff, because the only real prospects they had of selling some of their developments were to foreign investors. As these things became more obvious to the Government over time, the Government did the right thing and brought about the changes. Under the previous policy, acquisitions of real estate of $10m or more for development and retention or development and sale to Australians were generally approved only if they provided 50 per cent Australian equity. That provision was abolished. It will still be the case that applications will be subject to a national interest test which the FIRB can administer, but it will mean that there will be an opportunity for our construction industry to grow. One of the sectors that will always be the backbone of an economy and will always be one of the first indicators of recession or good times is the construction industry, and it needs a boost of this kind.

Under the previous policy a stricter test than usual was applied to acquisitions if service industry real estate-proposals for the status of new hotels, tourist resorts, et cetera-was involved. That normal requirement of at least 50 per cent Australian equity in joint Australian-foreign control was abolished. That will be a boon for development in that area. Having looked at the issue, not just since 28 July when it was announced but for the past couple of years, as more and more people in the industry have come to complain, I cannot see why there is any problem with that whatsoever. It will not mean, for instance, that things will be prevented from going ahead; it will mean that more Australians can be in jobs because projects that would never have got off the ground without that foreign equity will now be given the nod, so more and more Australians will be in employment and the economy will be able to start ticking over. That is what this Government is about. I really did not see anything in the contribution of Senator Siddons that even began to touch on that aspect of the changes.

Previously there was a virtual prohibition on acquisitions of developed commercial real estate. It had been very difficult for foreign investors in that area. Now that a capital gains tax is in place, why have that provision anyway? Profits made by foreigners can be taxed, so there are plenty of gains to be made by governments in their revenues. There is considerable interest on the part of overseas pension funds in this area and time and time again they have been rolled back. I hope that these changes will lead to a great number of them looking once again at Australia as a place for investment. When it can be demonstrated that 50 per cent Australian equity participation is not available on reasonable terms and conditions, investment will be approved-again, unless it is contrary to the national interest, which Senator Parer has difficulty in understanding.

TALK.START.PARA: —You still haven't explained it to me.

—As I said, trying to explain the national interest to Senator Parer would be a pretty futile exercise. In the six minutes left to me to touch on the real topic of today's debate, I could not attempt it; in six years I could not attempt it. To encourage foreign investment in Australia and to reduce tax distortions which favour debt over equity, the Government has decided to abolish the dividend withholding tax and the branch profits tax. This is to reverse the trend to increase debt as distinct from equity, which got a rocket-like start under the Fraser-Howard Government. We have taken a direct step to reverse that situation and to encourage it to go back the other way.

SPEECH.PARA: The first point I want to make about the motion, in the light of what the changes are rather than what Senator Siddons thought they might have been, relates to the inference that if the authority of the Foreign Investment Review Board is reduced in the way it has been by relaxing some of the guidelines, Australian companies will be sold at rock bottom prices. I do not understand the connection. Obviously the sale of any Australian company or asset will still be subject to the ordinary commercial negotiations that go on, as I am sure they do when Senator Siddons's company is taking over another company. He will still be able to negotiate with the owners of it and to set a price. That will still happen, whether the pursuer is a foreigner or an Australian, so the idea that in some way the relaxation of these controls affects price is beyond me.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did explain it.

—Senator Siddons did not explain it very well, because it is a nonsequitur; it just does not happen. The price at which a company's assets are sold is, obviously, a matter between the buyer and the seller. That is the way the world goes around, always has and always will. The suggestion that foreign investment in all cases leads to takeovers is wrong. Obviously there will be a lot of investment into new companies and new directions, and that is something to which all of the Government's deregulations over the past couple of years has been directed. We want to see new firms established. I have no doubt that joint venturing will go on apace under the new guidelines, which was one of the principal reasons for the Government moving in the first place.

SPEECH.PARA: The changes related to the manufacturing sector are largely designed to streamline the application process, not to reduce the authority of the Foreign Investment Review Board. One of the great complaints from foreign and domestic companies which had applications before the Foreign Investment Review Board was the length of time it took to get a decision. That complaint has existed for many years-it did not happen yesterday, it went on and on. The delays were not the fault of the Foreign Investment Review Board but were because the regulations were of such a complex nature and the test of such a high standard that it took a long time to assess applications; a lot of work had to go in. What we have done will mean that applications which go before the FIRB, most of which are fairly routine, can be dealt with easily and decisions can be made quickly. One thing is for sure: If foreign investment is delayed it will go somewhere else. There is no doubt that plenty of places around the world are crying out for it and we have missed the boat for too long. Hopefully we can get on it now.

Considering the acute problem we have with our balance of payments at the moment, the Government policy as announced on 28 July is the only appropriate response. The current account deficit of $14 billion a year, which is 6 per cent of gross domestic product, has to be covered by net capital inflow into Australia-there is no other way. We need to get that capital in, but it will come always in two forms; equity or debt. When foreigners put up the share capital for new or existing business in Australia, or buy real estate or other physical assets, we are getting equity investment, which is what this game has to be all about.
In conclusion, I go back to that editorial of Tuesday, 22 July, in the Fairfax publication, the Australian Financial Review. It says:

. . . the immediate problem facing Australia is not the control of foreign investment, but the lack of it. To agonise about the institutional and policy means of controlling, limiting or excluding foreign investment which is not in any case being offered is an absurdity only too typical of Australian economic policy. . . . The real threat to our future economic independence is not foreign ownership and control of our industry, but the lack of world interest in the Australian economy, despite its enormous natural endowments.
That is the real problem. It is not a matter of being taken over, it is a matter of interesting anybody in it at all. The headline of that editorial is `There's no-one at the door, let them in'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-In summing up this debate I would like to make clear some of the misstatements of Senator Richardson and Senator Parer. Senator Parer began by saying that this was an attempt by the Australian Democrats to whip up an emotive issue. He did not address the fact that two Liberal Prime Ministers, Mr McMahon and Mr Fraser, both thought it was necessary to have regulations and laws in this country to control the direction of foreign investment. So it escapes me why the Liberal Party is now saying, through Senator Parer, that this is an emotive issue. It has not been an emotive issue for about 10 years because we have had regulations to control forforeign investment. These regulations are now being dismantled, and we should address the consequences.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Richardson made great play of the fact that he is concerned about jobs. He suggested that if we did not have investment, expansion of the job market may be held back. Nobody-certainly not the Democrats-is saying that there should be any discouragement to foreign investment in new enterprises. If foreign interests want to start up a new business, whether it be a mine or a factory, obviously it is good for the country. They may be prepared to risk capital in enterprises in which local interests are not prepared to risk it. That is a good thing. The very structure of the Foreign Investment Review Board covers that situation. Where foreign investment can be seen to be constructive and developing the potential of this country, of course it should go ahead; but where foreign capital is used to take over existing companies that are performing profitably and paying dividends to Australian shareholders there is no advantage to the economy in having those successful enterprises suddenly in the hands of foreign interests with dividends from those enterprises all of a sudden flowing overseas rather than into the Australian economy.

I believe that Senator Richardson's comments were not very helpful and they did not address the fundamental point being made. He also went on to say that he could not see why at present Australian businesses were subject to being taken over at rock bottom prices. I thought I had explained that. For example, a certain number of Japanese yen can buy much greater equity in an Australian company simply because of the devaluation of the Australian dollar. The falling exchange rate has reduced such costs to foreign interests by roughly half compared to a few years ago. So it is much more profitable for foreign companies to buy Australian companies at the depreciated value of the Australian dollar. I thought that would have been clear.

Neither speaker addressed the two central problems. First, subsidiaries of foreign companies do not, by and large, export to any great degree. I did not have time to cover previously the case of the Ford Motor Co. of Australia Ltd. It wanted to export Falcon cars to the United States of America but was stopped from doing so by its parent company in the United States because that would have affected the market for motor cars in that country. That is typical of what goes on. No Japanese subsidiary companies operating in Australia export to any degree at all. Secondly, no foreign subsidiary companies involve themselves in research and development to any degree. That is almost always carried out by the parent company back home, where it can be watched and directed. I refer also to successful exporting countries with similar populations to Australia's-countries like Sweden and Switzerland, which have very successful organisations exporting around the world. Nestles, and the Volvo car company in Sweden, are cases in point.

TALK.START.PARA: —Throw them out. Is that what you are saying?

—I am simply saying that foreign subsidiaries do not have an open go to export their products. Controls are placed on their export franchises by parent companies. If companies are Australian owned, of course, they can export to wherever they like.

SPEECH.PARA: I was pleased to hear Senator Richardson say that the Foreign Investment Review Board would be retained and that overseas investment in Australia would be monitored by that body. It is reassuring to hear that. That matter was raised with Senator Walsh a few days ago and he was unable at that stage to give any assurance that the Foreign Investment Review Board would be retained by the Government. That could be good news.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Siddons's) be agreed to.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY BUSH FIRE COUNCIL

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN MEAT AND LIVE-STOCK CORPORATIONAUSTRALIAN MEAT AND LIVE-STOCK RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT CORPORATION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the papers.

I would like to start off by paying credit to Dick Austen, the Chairman of the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation, for having injected into the Corporation a change of attitude. The Austen philosophy is now really showing through in the operations of the Corporation and the operations of the Australian Meat and Live-Stock Research and Development Corporation. The main change is that it has been built on a consumer-led and not a production-led arrangement. The basis now is to give the customers more of what they want. In the past we were very much inclined to produce meat in Australia and then hope that somebody would buy it. That seems now to have changed. The objects of the Corporation and the research and development group are to show the producers and the processors how to achieve what the customers are after and to improve the techniques and requirements to do it.

The year under review was a difficult year. Not only were there problems with the international market, but there were problems with the season as well. I cannot see that the marketing situation will get a lot easier. I believe that it will require ever so much more expertise than we have exhibited in the past. The unloading of surplus stocks, from the European Economic Community in particular, has been a major problem. I hope that these stocks have been reduced somewhat, but I believe that we will still see a major problem in that area for some years to come. The dollar devaluation in recent times has helped and provided some offset benefit. However, in spite of the difficulties there was an overall figure of almost one million tonnes of exported meat, and there was improved access to several of the markets that we have enjoyed in the past. I think it is important to note that the stock numbers of both cattle and sheep increased during the year-cattle to 23.2 million, sheep to 156.2 million. I believe that the producers ought to keep an eye on those figures and make sure that they get them to a level which will optimise the market but not exceed it. I think it is also worth noting that mutton sales have gone up, but live sheep sales have gone down. Besides that, of course, lamb has turned out to be a very big winner. I see a good future for an extension of the lamb market.

The big issues have been faced and that is heartening. This question of consumer orientation and giving the markets what they want has been the main feature, as I have already said. The Corporation has also gone in for computer-aided livestock marketing. I believe that that is of enormous advantage to producers everywhere. All the producers want is to be paid for what they produce. They do not want more and they do not want less, and computer-aided livestock marketing will give them a much better chance of that. There has been a change in the amount and direction of funding in research and development. I think it is interesting to note that the task of improving the efficiency of converting livestock to meat has received an expenditure this year of 20.7 per cent of the funds available compared with 8 per cent in the previous year. With an improved product range and quality, marketability has been increased from 13.1 per cent in 1985-86 to 19.3 per cent in 1986-87. That is the direction in which the industry needs to continue. I think it is very commendable that the direction is so clear in relation to what it is trying to achieve.

The research effort has gone for leaner meat, for presentation in merchandising, for curing diseases such as footrot, and for better breeding. It has been a very good year. I believe it is very promising. The drought position in 1986-87 is better than it was previously. I congratulate the AMLC on the results it has achieved for the year. I call on the industry to follow that lead and to make 1986-87 even better.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also congratulate the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation for its performance and for the presentation of this report. It is clean, easy to read and attractive. The importance of the rural industry is well known to most people, although probably not to Senator Sanders. I am sure it is well known to every other senator in this chamber. The important role of the AMLC in promoting meat both here and overseas is also well known. The report highlights areas in which meat exports have recorded the largest annual increase in almost a decade. Both veal and beef shipments are up some 12 per cent, and lamb has re-emerged as the major export industry, showing an increase of 51 per cent on the previous year. The promotional programs, especially the short cuts campaign, are to be commended.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Archer has already said, the computer-aided livestock marketing is an important innovation. Work during the year with the United States of America and the European Economic Community to protect the Australian markets is also to be commended. Senator Archer also mentioned the commencement of in-depth research into the demands and priorities of the beef market in the United States of America and Japan. This will provide a framework for future marketing strategies and promotion campaigns, which has been lacking in our industry for quite some time.

I would like to dwell on the short cuts campaign. Recently I was privileged to participate in the short cuts campaign in Canberra. I assure everyone that meat produced in that manner is a delight to eat. I recommend the short cuts recipes to anyone who has not tried them. As part of its research the AMLC found that the housewife wanted something that was easy to prepare, had variety, and provided an awareness of nutritional benefits. That is pretty good. The fact is that 5,500 butcher shops now have these short cut recipes; the material has now been distributed to 1,800 supermarkets, and 18.5 million recipe cards have been distributed. One project relates to new lucerne varieties. I ask the industry to look closely at bloat control for the new lucerne varieties and for the existing lucerne varieties and clovers. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a vegetarian I object to the blatant advertising for these short cut recipes that Senator Brownhill has recommended. I did not think I would ever hear recipes being exchanged in this Senate. It was done in very sexist terms. Lots of men, as well as women, have to decide what they are going to cook for the evening meal. TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I wish to congratulate the Overseas Telecommunications Commission on its performance this year. With a revenue of $473m and a pre-tax profit of $101m resulting in an after-tax profit of $56m, this is the most profitable year yet for the OTC. Unfortunately, the report does show some real problems, not with the OTC but with the Government. This organisation, which is involved in an industry with growth rates exceeding 20 per cent per annum, that is, the international communications market, needs a large amount of capital expenditure for such capital projects as the submarine cable between Australia and New Zealand-the Tasman 2 cable-and various amounts of money for new switching systems and the upgrading of facilities for satellites. All of this money must come out of its operating capital. Yet the Government which in 1983 set a 10 per cent dividend target for the period 1987-88 is now about to ask not for the 10 per cent which it promised and which would have been something to keep a stable industry going but for 15 per cent. It is trying to bleed this industry of the working capital which could make it possible for Australia to be the hub of the communications systems of the Asian-Pacific region.

This blindness, this killing of the goose that lays the golden egg, is typical of the attitude the Government has towards high technology industries such as that which exists within OTC. I deplore it. I believe that the Government must allow organisations such as OTC to re-invest their capital in order to keep Australia ahead in the telecommunications industry and to give it a presence which is really important to our future viability as a world trader. I also wish to congratulate the OTC on its seaphone system, which has been quite effective, as is claimed in the report, in saving lives. It actually keeps people in radio contact in the sheltered regions around our coastline.

The next area that I would like to mention is that of forward planning. Henry Ergas of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development pointed out last year that the lack of adequate investment in telecommunications systems is a threat to Australia's economic development. In the report he said there was a recognition by people overseas that it was possible for Australians to move ahead in this area in which lead times are around 10 years and the initial planning stages may take three to four years. However, having a penny pinching government that is squeezing the research efforts of an organisation such as OTC can be debilitating and can leave us with a real long term problem. SPEECH.PARA: When one looks at page 19 of this excellent report from OTC, one can see under the heading `Optical Fibre Network' that plans have been announced this year for a billion-dollar optical fibre cable network linking Australia and New Zealand with North America and Asia. That gives some indication of the magnitude of the costs about which we are talking and the significance of projects that are under way. I believe that Mr Somervaille and the Commission are to be congratulated on a very productive year. I also extend congratulations to Mr Somervaille in terms of his appointment to the newly announced Australian Space Board. I hope that he will be able to bring some of his undoubted expertise to the development of a space industry in Australia, and a space technology industry in particular.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is an apology for nuclear power. It is biased.

It needs to be given proper time in the Senate, not under the pressure that we have at present. SPEECH.PARA: Understandably, the immediate response to the accident has been adverse and there is no doubt that the performance of the industry will be under closer scrutiny than ever before. Nevertheless it would be wrong to draw conclusions from Chernobyl which are subsequently invalidated as a more thorough understanding emerges.

This report is a notable contribution to a more thorough understanding. It will clearly inform the Australian Parliament and the people about many of the issues. I think one of the most striking things that have occurred since Chernobyl is the degree of international co-operation and efforts to understand scientifically and come to grips with the problems presented by the Chernobyl disaster.

Those meetings have been held, and draft conventions have been agreed upon. The governments which have been represented in this process are meeting again this week to consider them further. It is likely that those conventions will soon be agreed on. Australia has played an important part in the meetings and the Opposition has supported those attempts. In addition, there has been a major conference at the International Atomic Energy Agency which the Russians attended and use has been made of the very detailed report which they gave. The task group's report has made use of the matters considered at that IAEA conference.

It is clear, as I said immediately in the wake of the Chernobyl disaster, that the implications require rational and informed consideration and debate. I said that we must all work in conjunction with the rest of the world to enhance our control over nuclear power. We cannot just wish it away.
