DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON INDUSTRY AND TRADE

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 23 September, on motion by Senator Childs:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 13 June 1986 the following matter was referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Industry and Trade-an inquiry into certain aspects of Australia's manufacturing industry revitalisation. At that time the Committee noted that it was very concerned about the need for Australia's manufacturing sector to become more internationally competitive and export oriented. The Committee indicated also that it wished to make a tangible contribution to the debate on manufacturing and that it would not try to cover all aspects of this large and complex issue but rather would concentrate on a number of issues that require further investigation and report.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee has spent a great deal of time discussing various aspects of manufacturing industry revitalisation with many people and organisations directly involved in this sector. It has become apparent to the Committee during these discussions that Australian attitudes towards and awareness of manufacturing need to be exposed to the widest possible public debate. Today, the world oversupply in agriculture and mining threatens the post-Second World War prosperity which we have enjoyed in Australia. The devaluation of the Australian dollar presents advantages to Australian manufacturers; yet there are difficulties that inhibit this growth. All Australians will benefit from a discussion that identifies the steps to manufacturing industry revitalisation.

We must learn from the protection debate of the 1960s and 1970s which concentrated on tariff issues and can be seen with hindsight to have been too narrow, short term and pre-occupied with sectoryal interests. At the same time, the rest of the world erected a complex and sophisticated system of non-tariff barriers in a rapidly internationalised market. As a result, in Australia imports replaced many locally produced manufactured goods and many industries simply disappeared, along with one million jobs. We were able to continue to do this because our agricultural and mineral exports were growing at a sufficient rate to pay for these imports.

The story is now vastly different. Everyone is talking about the need to revitalise our manufacturing sector. Unfortunately, it appears that many Australians have developed a negative attitude towards manufacturing. As a community, we are not supportive of the manufacturing sector. It would appear that we have developed attitudes which tend to favour imported goods over locally produced goods. It would appear also that we have adopted a view that there is no long term future for manufacturing in Australia. Therefore, my Committee feels very strongly that these attitudes towards manufacturing require the fullest possible public debate.

If we can raise the level of awareness in our community, we will be in a better position to develop a more positive approach to manufacturing in Australia. It is for that reason that the Senate Standing Committee on Industry and Trade has chosen the following terms of reference as its first inquiry into Australia's manufacturing industry revitalisation: The prevailing attitudes to manufacturing and the need to develop an environment more conducive to sustained growth and increased investment in manufacturing. The aim of the inquiry will be to examine community and industry attitudes towards Australian manufacturing.

A vital determinant of industry's performance is Australia's prevalent manufacturing environment-that is, employer and employee attitudes to each other, to decision-making, to work practices and to productive efficiency. Many see our present environment as isolationist and adversarial, which only encourages confrontation, irresponsibility and industrial self-destruction. The Committee believes that, if we can gain a clear understanding of these community held views and the views of employers and employees in the industry and why they have persisted, it will be possible to address the issue of manufacturing growth and investment in a more positive manner. I commend the report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Industry and Trade, I would like to speak briefly to support the Committee's report, which was tabled yesterday, and the remarks just made by the Committee Chairman, Senator Childs. The Committee is about to embark on an inquiry which could have very important positive implications for the future of Australia's manufacturing sector. I think that there is general agreement throughout the community and between all major political parties that revitalisation of the manufacturing sector is of the greatest importance for Australia's future. There is no doubt that the manufacturing sector in Australia-certainly in relative terms and, in some important areas, in absolute terms-has slipped considerably over the past couple of decades. The share of the work force engaged in manufacturing has fallen admittedly along with the trend in the rest of the Western world, but so, too, has the share of manufacturing in the nation's total production. I guess that, to some extent, that is inevitable as we move through a period of industrialisation into, as some would say, an increasingly post-industrial world. My view is that those who say that we are about to enter a post-industrial world are writing off manufacturing too easily and far too quickly.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no doubt that we need to look at many of the factors that concern manufacturing. We need to look at the reasons why it has slipped and we need to look at what can be done about it. Perhaps more than ever before we need, more than many other countries, a revitalisation of our manufacturing sector. We have as a nation relied, particularly for our external trade, on agriculture and mining over many years, and I think that is going to continue. However, it is equally obvious that the prospects for some of those industries in the years ahead are not looking as good as they were. In view of the balance of payments situation facing this country, I believe that the manufacturing sector will be required to play an increasingly important role in our export effort and also in the area of import replacement. That can be achieved only on the basis of internationally competitive industry.

Gone forever are the days of believing that we can have a vibrant and vital economy and manufacturing sector, or any other sector for that matter, based on a high degree of protection and assistance. It is interesting to note the fundamental change in the manufacturing industries themselves towards the question of industry assistance over the last few years. Indeed, the manufacturing sector-I welcome this-has led the way in many respects in undergoing a change of attitude towards industry assistance and a recognition of the need to be internationally competitive. That brings me to the question of investment, because we will not be able to produce at all, let alone be competitive, unless we have an environment conducive to investment in manufacturing and in this nation as a whole. For that reason I am very pleased that the Committee's terms of reference for its threshold inquiry will include the need to develop an environment more conducive to sustained growth and increased investment in manufacturing.

The reference also includes the important task of looking at the question of attitudes to manufacturing. It is obviously very important to consider community attitudes, attitudes of the work force and attitudes of management. There is a great deal of talk today about work practices and other factors that affect the manufacturing sector, which are all in their own way attitudinal. Surely at the end of the day it is the bottom line that counts. If we cannot have an environment in which investors in the manufacturing sector can make an adequate return on their investment, we are not going to get investment and therefore manufactured output; we are not going to get the revitalisation of the manufacturing sector we need.

We have, as the report says, discussed our terms of reference before finalising them with a wide range of people involved with the manufacturing sector-people from companies, industry associations, trade unions and other sources. There is no doubt that, as the report says, competitiveness, productivity, rationalisation, wages, profit shares, export market development, labour skills, education and training, which at the end go to determine the bottom line for a company's performance, are matters that we are going to have to look at very carefully. I welcome the opportunity the Committee will have to do that. I think we will have to be very careful that we do not try to re-invent the wheel by looking at all the things that are being looked at in other forums as well. We have an important role to try to develop a separate niche in the market, if you like, of investigation of these matters. I think we will be very well equipped to do so.

I was very interested to read an editorial that a friend sent me recently from the Melbourne Age of 2 December 1952 which commented on a speech which Viscount Bruce of Melbourne, a former Prime Minister, gave before 2,500 people at the Town Hall on 1 December 1952. The theme of his speech was the need for `relevant data on the export industries so crucial to maintenance of our incomes and living standards'. The editorial stated:
The picture strongly suggests that this is no time for thinking of sectional gains, but for setting about devising means to avert a widespread collapse that could bring severe effects to all.

Viscount Bruce observed that `our costs are out of line with those of the rest of the world, and that for our own safety they must be brought into line'. I had a distinct sense of deja vu when, 35 years later, I read similar comments. They are the sorts of things we need to look at. We all have a great and vested interest in the future and in the revitalisation of our manufacturing sector. I hope that in its own way the work of this Committee will contribute to that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The reference that the Senate Standing Committee on Industry and Trade is about to embark upon is a vital and much needed investigation into Australia's manufacturing industry. The demise of Australia's manufacturing industry over 20 years or so is of great concern to the nation as a whole. I speak in particular of those people who have a vital interest in the industry-that is, the workers and, more importantly, those people who ought to be in the industry but who unfortunately, because of its demise, have been retrenched and have no jobs at the moment. They number many thousands. It is a sad reflection on the industry as a whole that it is not operating at the optimum at the moment.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee has been discussing this matter for some six months or so now and our investigations have been spread quite widely. We had consultations with people from the Industry Councils Secretariat; with private corporations such as CRA Ltd; with the Metal Trades Industry Association, the Business Council of Australia, the Confederation of Australian Industry and the Australian Manufacturing Council; and, through the Australian Council of Trade Unions, with representatives of the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union. We did so to find out what they thought were important elements of an inquiry into a rejuvenation of Australia's manufacturing industry. Issues that were raised by those bodies and by Committee members ranged far and wide and were quite exhaustive. Each of the points raised could warrant an inquiry in its own right. Obviously the Committee would not have the time to deal with each one, but I think we will cover most of them through the life of the inquiry.

The issues raised covered matters such as competitiveness, productivity, industry rationalisation, industrial democracy, wage profit shares, import substitution, export marketing development, marketing, research and development, marketing skills, labour skills, education and training, industry assistance, government regulations, investment, conciliation and arbitration, and the general macro-environment. It is obvious to any person listening to the debate that it will be an exhaustive inquiry.

I am very pleased that the Committee, which is a bipartisan committee, has shown a tremendous degree of unity of purpose in addressing this inquiry. It is hoped that on our way through the inquiry we might be able to spell things out to some of those in our society who feel that workers in industry ought to be serfs and not have any say in the enterprise in which they are involved. They might wake up and show some degree of unity of purpose towards their own enterprises and towards the country as a whole. There is ample proof that workers and management, operating with the assistance of government at a State and Commonwealth level, can go forward and build an enterprise, a manufacturing industry, in this nation of ours that will be capable of import replacement as a first step and that will also be competitive in world markets. It is an exhaustive inquiry. We should not start the inquiry, which probably will be a long and enduring one, with lengthy speeches. The really hard work is still to be done and I am very pleased to be a part of what, in my opinion and the opinion of the Committee, will be a very important inquiry to the Parliament, the Government and the people of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend the report to the Senate. The Standing Committee on Industry and Trade was asked to conduct an inquiry into certain aspects of Australia's manufacturing industry revitalisation. After examining many alternatives, the Committee has adopted the following terms of reference:

SPEECH.PARA: (a) The prevailing attitudes to manufacturing; and
(b) the need to develop an environment more conducive to sustained growth and increased investment in manufacturing.

It is a fact that Australians have tended to favour imported goods. I welcome the Committee's inquiry, which could lead to a change in Government policy and to renewed `Vigor' in manufacturing industry. I hope that it will lead to more value added, more bounties and fewer tariffs, and a more co-operative approach between the labour force and the forces associated with capital.

The preference for buying imported products is particularly evident in government purchasing where imported products are purchased in preference to similar Australian products. Government and its agencies are major purchasers in Australia. Currently government has no commitment to buying Australian products, despite certain noises to the contrary. In fact, Australian high technology industry finds it very difficult to deal with government at all. I would like to bring this aspect to the notice of the Committee.

In April, during examination of the Estimates, I learned that only 52 per cent of minor defence equipment purchases come from Australian suppliers. In April the Department of Defence asked Parliament for an extra $68m to cover currency fluctuations in its overseas purchases; yet its `buy foreign' policy jeopardises the whole of our defence because in time of war we could not depend on supplies of essential spare parts being available in Australia in a timely way.

I draw the attention of the Senate to my notice of motion of 17 September last calling on the Government to introduce a Bill for an Act for the purpose of ensuring that Australian suppliers are given maximum opportunity to compete for Commonwealth contracts and that such contracts be awarded to Australian suppliers unless there are cogent reasons to do otherwise. Such affirmative action for Australian industry is necessary to counter the present preference for imported goods by Public Service purchasing agencies. The motives for preferring to buy foreign goods could well reflect a community attitude. It could also well reflect a cultural cringe. However comforting this idea may be to managers in our manufacturing industries, we cannot afford to assume that the fault lies wholly with the Australian consumer.

Let us look further at ways in which Australian manufacturing industry needs to lift its game. In order to sell in a competitive market, products need to meet customer's needs. The Australian Science and Technology Council, in its report `Mechanisms for Technology Transfer' this year, underlined major difficulties for Australian manufacturing industry in meeting local needs. These difficulties result from the lack of investment in new technologies and products and from the domination of Australian manufacturing by foreign controlled enterprises. ASTEC was concerned with the steady decline in private capital expenditure in the manufacturing sector and other evidence of a slow rate of innovation over the past two decades. This decline is reflected in an aging of capital stock and an obsolescence of its associated technology.

We also have the problem of foreign technology transfer. There is a need for us to control our industry locally. Three-quarters of all payments by Australian companies for technology know-how are made to related overseas companies, to what are essentially `head offices'. Many of the technology-intensive industries are foreign owned and subsidiaries obtain a large part of their technology from the parent company. There is generally an attitude of `head office' research.

ASTEC also looks at the problem of transfer pricing, which is a means of tax avoidance. This must be considered by the Committee because it also is having a devastating effect on the development of a sound Australian export industry. Restrictive conditions on licensing of technology are common in world markets, particularly on exports of manufactured products from Australia. Thirty per cent of licensing arrangements involve export restrictions on the product being developed. I commend to the Committee that it look at these types of restrictive practices. With regard to licensing back of improvements, 45 per cent of licensing arrangements insist that ownership of all improvements in technology be vested in the original overseas licensor. With regard to modifications to the product or quality control provisions, 35 per cent of all licence agreements prohibit adaptation of the technology locally. We cannot accept these types of restrictions on development in our industry.

In the heavy engineering industry, nearly 60 per cent of companies have technology agreements with overseas companies and 95 per cent of foreign controlled companies have such agreements. Many of these agreements have restrictions on exporting offset by sweetheart agreements in the way the local market is handled. Foreign owned manufacturing industry in Australia does not compete on international markets with its parent companies; nor does it invest in local development or in local market requirements. We need to solve this `branch office' attitude that we have in Australia.

The Foreign Investment Review Board in its 1984-85 report pointed out that approximately 71 per cent of total expected foreign investment approved that year would be spent on acquiring existing businesses. Of that foreign investment, 86.7 per cent would be in the form of borrowings, the interest payments on which will be a drain on our foreign exchange for years to come, while earnings will be exempted from tax for the interest paid.

Australian taxpayers are in fact subsidising the foreign takeover of our Australian manufacturing industry. Of the 30 per cent of foreign investment in Australia that will be invested in new business, most will be in the service industry-in hotels, accommodation and other services to people coming in from overseas-and in the finance and insurance sectors, `the invisibles'. Foreign investment in manufacturing is declining while total foreign investment is rising overall. If we look at the foreign investment in manufacturing in 1985, we see that only $50m, which is 0.5 per cent, was invested in new developments, compared with $1,000m used in taking over existing manufacturing complexes.

I wish to bring to the notice of the Committee that in Australia we have employed in manufacturing only one-tenth of the number of engineers that is judged appropriate overseas for a similar effective operation. We also have only about one-fifth of the amount of investment in industrial research and development in `comparable' countries of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. That is 0.21 per cent of gross domestic product in Australia and 0.93 per cent of GDP in those corresponding countries. We need to solve our intellectual property problems; we need a sensible patent system. We need to look at vast numbers of problems, which in the time available I could only hint at. I wish the Committee luck in trying to bring this matter together, because Australia needs a competitive manufacturing industry as an essential base on which to build a strong, independent Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is dealing with the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Industry and Trade which deals with certain aspects of Australia's manufacturing industry revitalisation. I acknowledge the comments of Senator Vigor, my colleague from South Australia and an Australian Democrat senator, who has taken an enthusiastic interest in the revitalisation of the Australian manufacturing industry. No doubt some of his concerns will be taken up by the Committee.
—You are not recruiting him to the Centre Left, I hope.

—If he were to change political parties, he may well be an admirable recruit to such a body. But I do not think that he would change political parties, and therein lies the problem. However, on this issue, which is not in any sense to be lightly regarded, it will be fairly recognised by all members of the Committee that Senator Vigor takes a sincere and deep interest in these issues and he speaks strongly on them in the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: In my experience of the Senate, there is sometimes criticism that occasionally Senate committees do not fulfil their potential. It is said that sometimes they sidetrack themselves into great areas of activity and that at the end of great study and expressions of concern, and having heard a great deal of evidence and so on, they bring down reports that gather dust on the shelves of the library-reports that are not much use and are not resorted to as a reference in industry and in the practical world outside Parliament. I think that the report now before the Senate indicates a direction that will be relevant to the interests of unions, commercial operators in manufacturing and those who are concerned about Australia's manufacturing performance generally. Indeed, I believe the Committee will produce recommendations that will be of great value to the Government as well.

I do not want to repeat the remarks made by those who have spoken in this debate about the importance of revitalising Australian manufacturing industry, except to make a few short observations. Anyone who is at all concerned about Australia's balance of trade is struck, when comparing Australia's trade performance with that of other more buoyant economies, by the fact that about 90 per cent of our exports comprise minerals and agricultural products, whereas in the world's stronger economies most exports are made up of manufactured goods. Quite clearly, the economic challenge for Australia, a challenge which is more foundational than almost any other, is to revitalise our manufacturing output, not only to meet the needs of our own domestic market but also to compete with other world exporters on the international stage and to beat them, so that in our export effort we can take a bigger share of manufacturing export and be a producer of quality manufactured goods that people, including consumers overseas, want to purchase. That view has a great deal of bipartisan support in this Parliament-it certainly has on the Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tripartisan.

—Tripartisan, if I include my South Australian colleague Senator Vigor. The Committee has been helped in its deliberations by an input from industry spokesmen, union spokespeople and various departments. I was particularly struck by comments made by representatives of the Australian Manufacturing Council who helped the Committee to choose the reference. In particular, the Council produced the reports of the industry secretariats and showed the work done in each of the industry sectors in getting on a tripartite basis an agreed stocktake of the deficiencies in that sector. That work was impressive, as was the Council's work on the sectoral strategies in examining how those industries should proceed to develop themselves more effectively.

SPEECH.PARA: The report showed a number of issues that were common across the board to all industry sectors in this country. My colleagues on the Committee have probably heard me ad nauseam on some of these matters, but let me repeat two of them. Quite clearly, there is across the board in all those industry stocktakes a tripartite agreement that there is a need to look at more flexible work practices, and specifically at multi-skilling. There is in all those industry sections, again as a matter of tripartite agreement, a belief that there is a need to improve middle management and managerial expertise in Australian companies. Everyone is in agreement on both items. The challenge is not simply to cite principles that are commonly approved, but to apply them to make real change. The strategies that those industry committees were developing seem to me to be addressing those matters. Although the Australian industrial landscape is often portrayed as divisive and confrontationist, the work of the committees clearly involves co-operation and common problem-solving by management, union and government. It not only expresses the spirit of the Australian Council of Trade Unions-Australian Labor Party wages-prices accord, but also stands as an effective way-I believe the only effective way-for this country to address fundamental economic problems.

The report does not directly address those two themes. We have focused on the broad issue of the manufacturing culture in Australia. We have asked whether there is a cringe in Australia in that our manufacturing industry is not worth the candle and is to be considered only in minor domestic terms, and that we should concentrate our efforts on developing mineral and agricultural resources. Is there a cringe inbred in our culture that something made in Australia is not as good as one which comes with an exotic label from some foreign source? Is there a belief among those who invest in industrial development that it is better to put it in bricks and mortar than in manufacturing goods, and thus to achieve a speculative gain down the track rather than produce real wealth in the community? Do we have that cringe? These are some of the aspects of the manufacturing culture which I expect the report will address.

The report makes clear that many see our present environment as isolationist and adversarial, which only encourages confrontation, irresponsibility and industrial self-destruction. What the report will not be able to do is to come deeply to grips with that wide canvass, but one hopes that by directing attention to certain specifics it will be able to carry out a useful service, not by repeating all the findings of previous reports but by synthesising those findings in a way that is relevant to the development of manufacturing industry. I commend the report and the future work of the Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the inquiry by the Senate Standing Committee on Industry and Trade into the revitalisation of our manufacturing industry. In the last 20-odd years Australia's share of world markets has fallen from 2 per cent to about 1.2 per cent. This country has abundant resources and there are no clearly perceived reasons for not employing teamwork and striving for higher productivity as is the case in some of our competing countries, such as Japan. The quality of our manufactured goods has to be maintained and improved and we must recognise and reward excellence. We pay too much attention to our sporting heroes. We have an Institute of Sport, which is most probably a good thing, but we do not pay much attention to our apprentices. Institutes such as the work skills Australia programs, which do something for apprentices and which try to promote higher standards in the community and to promote public awareness of trades, are a step in the right direction in making an effort for the young working people who want to go into the manufacturing industries. I note that the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney) wants to speak on this, as does Senator Button, so I will leave my remarks at that. I believe that this inquiry will achieve a lot to help our manufacturing industries-industries on which we will rely so much in the years ahead to get us out of our economic problems.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the members of the Senate Standing Committee on Industry and Trade for the comments they have made on the report on certain aspects of Australia's manufacturing industry revitalisation and also for the invitation they extended to me as the Opposition spokesman on industry, technology and commerce to join in this debate; an invitation they issued also to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), who is at the table. It is instructive that there is a good deal of common ground in the approach which is being adopted to manufacturing industry, not only by the Parliament but also by the various bodies around Australia which are concerned about its future. We find in the first paragraphs of this report a reference to the revitalisation of Australia's manufacturing industry, which is generally accepted as being necessary. The Committee noted that it was concerned about the need for Australia's manufacturing sector to become more internationally competitive and export oriented. I can only say that those words seem to have been used by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Minister, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) and by me and those words will be found sprinkled throughout the documents which are presently being produced by so many people on manufacturing industry. That common ground is to be welcomed because it is more likely that we will get acceptable long term solutions if, even at that broad level of generality, there is agreement.

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of addressing the Committee's task, it is important to note the way in which the debate has changed even in this decade. At the end of the 1970s and the beginning of the 1980s we were concerned about the Gregory thesis and about the fact that Australia faced the problem of a continually appreciating currency because of our massive exports surplus. In those circumstances, the future of Australian manufacturing industry was seen to be rather doubtful but also as being relatively unimportant. There has been a very sharp change in our expectations. We now apply the Gregory thesis to the reverse conditions. We see long term problems with respect to our balance of payments, a depreciated currency which may, but we hope will not, depreciate further if the balance of payments goes against us further, and we have a situation where, rather than accepting the fact that manufacturing may decline and so what, almost everybody agrees that a vigorous and internationally competitive manufacturing sector is of fundamental importance to us.

In that brief look at recent history there is an explanation of why we cannot expect an immediate and rapid response to the changed circumstances. In fact, industry has not been living in an environment which suggested that it would be subjected to the pressures and requirements which are now being placed upon it, not merely by the Government and the Opposition but also by the trade union movement and virtually every commentator. I express the view to the Committee that any response to our present problem requires a long term approach. It requires a situation where those who we wish to invest in new industry in Australia can see that there is a predictable future. To the extent that anything is predictable in economics, those people ought to be able to see that there is a framework of policy which is broadly blessed by the Government, the Opposition and hopefully by the trade union movement and business organisations, so that there is some hope of a more predictable environment in which they can invest with confidence and certainty.

The second point which flows from that is that there is a real requirement in this area for bipartisanship, if that can be achieved. A number of the Committee members stressed the bipartisan approach which has been adopted by the Committee and I suggest to them that there is value in that approach in itself. If industry faces a situation where there will not be radical changes to the approach being adopted just because there is a change of government, which may be caused by factors which have nothing to do with industry policy, that will be helpful. In that regard I draw attention to the fact that the present Opposition has sought to follow that approach over recent years. It has supported many of the broad objectives put forward by the Minister at the table and has supported in the main his steel and car plans, just as when the Minister came in in 1983 he said that the textiles, clothing and footwear arrangements would run their course because people were entitled to rely on the arrangements which had been put in place. In this debate I affirm that as something which should be an important element of our speaking.

My concern about the report, which I am glad to have the chance to express, is that the Committee may adopt too narrow an attitude to its inquiry and run the risk of becoming very expert about one aspect of what many of the speakers have stressed is essentially a multi-faceted problem. I noted that Senator McKiernan, like Senator Short, stressed the range of issues which are relevant to obtaining a better future for our manufacturing industry. Senator McKiernan read extensively from page 2 of the report, where the Committee referred to issues such as industrial democracy, wage-profit shares, import substitution, export market development, marketing, research and development, management skills, labour skills, education and training and so on. As time is short I will not go through the whole list.

My concern is that, whatever the Committee does, it should be placing some stress on the second limb of the self-imposed term of reference, where the Committee refers to the need to develop an environment more conducive to sustained growth and increased investment in manufacturing. If we fall into the trap, which we have fallen into in the past, of concentrating too much on either a specific industry or a specific element of policy which impacts on industry, we will not achieve the overall result we wish. In that regard, the Opposition has recently published a document called `Policies for Business' which tries to bring together, for the sorts of reasons I have been stressing, a range of policies which we believe affect the investment environment in Australia and need to be tackled if we are again to make Australia a place which is attractive to investment, rather than people putting their money overseas, be they foreign or Australian investors.

For the sake of confirming at least one element of the Committee's approach, I direct attention to the fact that the third issue which is raised in that document is community attitudes. The Opposition supports the importance of community attitudes as an element to try to get a better environment for manufacturing industry. Indeed, our policy document contains words which are very close to the words which appear on page 3 of the report, where there is reference to work practices and employer and employee attitudes. I quote from the Liberal-National Party document, which states:

Australia's chances of success in a world of fierce competition and constant change depend upon more than simply having correct policies. Community attitudes need to be conducive to improved productivity. In the past, our biggest single handicap has been a lack of common purpose.
It states further:

This is most clearly seen in the workplace: confrontation, `us against them,' bosses versus workers- have been the order of the day too often. Too few employees have identified with the interests of their employing firm.

I quote that to underline again the high degree of common ground which exists but which needs to be developed further. It is the view of the Opposition parties, on the examination of this very important area so far, that there is a great range of things which need to be tackled in our community if we are to have a genuinely good environment for investment in manufacturing and indeed in other areas of business and industry. That multiplicity of things that need to be addressed, some of which were referred to in the debate by Senator McKiernan, may be brought together under what we have described as four broad requirements. We suggest that they are, firstly, reduced and restructured taxes, made possible by reduced government spending; secondly, reduced and less costly regulation of business activity-the present Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce has a Regulation Review Unit which is obviously aimed at tackling one of those essential areas; thirdly, the restoration of the rule of law in industrial relations and a flexible labour market, a matter of great debate currently; and, fourthly, rigorous control in the reduction of business input costs, especially government taxes and charges.

Time does not permit me to go through the great range of points, but I ask the Committee to bear in mind that any examination of a factor in isolation is likely to give us a false picture. I hope that the Committee will pay close attention to its second point, which is the need to develop an environment more conducive to sustained growth and increased investment in manufacturing. That will inevitably require the Committee to address some of the things which have been addressed by others, but I am encouraged by the fact that the Committee will have much common ground in the material put before it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —Having listened to Senator Chaney I do not have much to add. I agree with many of the general comments he made. It is suggested that the Standing Committee on Industry and Trade inquire into two matters-prevailing attitudes to manufacturing and the changing environment for manufacturing. I do not know how the Committee can establish prevailing attitudes to manufacturing. I assume that refers to attitudes of the community at large. The Committee is likely to find that manufacturing is seen as something of a burden on the truly productive sectors of the economy and out of date, slow to innovate, complaining, an area of entrenched industrial relations warfare, cosseted too long from real competition, perhaps noisy, polluting, and all those sorts of things. They are the very negative perceptions probably held by fair sections of the Australian community about manufacturing. I think they are wrong and are largely out of date, but I rather suspect that they still exist.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that the Committee will also find that the educationally upwardly mobile in Australia do not want to go into manufacturing as a career. The professions probably have the greatest lure, the greatest attraction, for people undergoing post-secondary education, rather than attaining the skills which go into manufacturing. I am not sure what the figures are but I think we employ about two engineers in manufacturing per 1,000 compared with something like 75 engineers per 1,000 in Japan. The figures for other countries are somewhere in between. I accept that there is an enormous need to encourage the skills of the engineering profession into manufacturing, particularly into process engineering and areas of that kind.

The second thing that traditionally manufacturing here does not do-one cannot generalise about these things because some companies have a totally different history-is direct attention to the skills required by middle level management. I remember reading last year an Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development survey which assessed the relative competitiveness of British and German industries. Its conclusion, which came down heavily in favour of German industry, was that this was largely as a result of the long-standing attention given in Germany to skills in middle management. In Japan-Senator Chaney has had the misfortune of hearing this twice in one week-motivating the work force is seen as a task of middle management, such as foremen and supervisors. That is their fundamental task. In a country such as Germany, where the social and structural arrangements are different, the task of middle management is still in a sense the same; that is to say, arriving at the best methods for producing whatever the enterprise produces, ensuring that those methods are discussed with and communicated to the work force. Again, the purpose is to obtain the best results in terms of productivity.

Australia has inherited something of the British tradition and has not developed those skills which I regard as important ingredients of good manufacturing. Insofar as developing an environment more conducive to sustained growth and increased investment in manufacturing is concerned, those economic factors are very important. I agree with what Senator Chaney had to say basically about them, but I also agree very strongly with him that changing attitudes in industry and about industry is a multi-faceted task. For example, the education system in Australia probably suffers from a similar British disease. By and large post-secondary academic institutions in Australia have been divorced from industry. There has been an academic stream of basic research, which I believe to have been of world class-per head of population I think we are outstanding in basic research-but the level of applied research in academic institutions and the interaction with industry in this country is probably well down the pecking order in world terms. The Japanese are now devoting enormous financial resources to basic research. For years they were criticised for their very low level of basic research; all their research was applied, but that applied research has provided the benefits that have now enabled them to make a national decision to devote far more resources to basic research.

I am not claiming firsts, but I was the first industry Minister in this country to have a meeting with the vice-chancellors of Australian universities to discuss the relationship between universities and industry. I do not claim any credit for that. I am just saying that, as Senator Chaney suggests, circumstances have changed and things have to change with them. There is now an ongoing relationship between the Business Council of Australia and the university vice-chancellors, which again is a first. It takes time to break down those sorts of problems, but they are matters which go fundamentally to the environmental issues that afflict manufacturing, quite apart from the questions of investment and a whole range of other macro-economic issues which affect the environment in which industry can operate.

I welcome very much the Committee proceeding with this inquiry. I guess it is not for us in the Senate to say what we believe it is likely to find in the course of its inquiry, but I hope that it will look at the multi-faceted nature of the issues which affect the two questions to which it is fundamentally directing its attention. It involves many attitudinal matters. One could talk about the economic issues forever, but also involved are a whole lot of quite intangible attitudinal factors which are immensely important in building a productive culture in this country. They involve, for instance, a commitment to excellence, pride in workmanship, corporate teamwork, a commitment to quality and service, innovative capacities, management practices, co-operative industrial relations and, above all in relation to the Committee's first term of reference, community recognition for commercial success. This country is great at recognising its tennis players and its golfers. My second name is Norman and I see all those headlines: `Norman wins again'. I think, `My God, I have done something at last', but of course it is never me; nor would it ever be a managing director.

I must say that in the last six months there have been signs that some of the media in this country are starting to get interested in some of these issues. I do not hand out bouquets to particular newspapers, but the Australian Financial Review is now running a series of columns about success in innovation, success in exports and so on. I think this is very welcome and very important and the sooner some of the other newspapers catch on to that idea the better it will be for this country, because the more we recognise success in business and innovation in industry the more success will follow from that recognition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

—As you said, Mr Acting Deputy President, my time has expired. I wish the Committee every success in its deliberations and I hope that the process of the Committee inquiry will add further to the pressure for change in desirable directions on the issues into which the Committee proposes to inquire.

—I can take only three minutes, but I rise to add perhaps another dimension for consideration by the Standing Committee on Industry and Trade. No doubt this point has been mentioned in passing, but I want to suggest to the Committee that it examine, if it has not already done so, ways and means by which the participants in manufacturing-those many thousands of workers who are in the manufacturing industry-are able to share in the means of production. Those workers, of course, have the right not only to fair wages and safe working conditions, but also to feel and in fact be creative.
