DEBATE.TITLE: SUPERANNUATION AND OTHER BENEFITS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Superannuation and Other Benefits Legislation Amendment Bill seeks to implement the Budget decision of the Government to reduce by 2 per cent the indexation rate of pensions payable to Defence Force pensioners and also to Commonwealth superannuitants. This will yield about $12m in savings to the Commonwealth in the Budget this financial year.
—It will be less this year.

—That is the full year figure. The point that is being made by the Government is that it is looking everywhere for savings in order to get the deficit down to the $3.5 billion figure that it announced some weeks ago, which was designed to make sure that the Government was presented in the best possible light in the financial markets. So the Government went skimming around in the last few days before the announcement of the Budget looking for every possible saving. It came up with this one, which means a reduction in the amounts that are going to go to pensioners of the Commonwealth, be they from the defence forces or former public servants. The Government will rob them of 2 per cent of their pension.

SPEECH.PARA: The point at issue here is simply this: The Government has announced that it intends to go to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and seek a 2 per cent reduction in the flow-on of the consumer price index increase in the forthcoming national wage case. That relates to the inflation rates that have already been announced by the Australian Bureau of Statistics for the quarters ended March and June of this year. Obviously the national wage case hearing has not yet started. It will be some time before it does start. The Government will then go to the Commission and put down its argument in favour of that particular proposition. It will then be open to the unions to go to the same Commission and put forward their opposing arguments.

This will be open to other interested parties-employers and others who might argue for indexation adjustments to allow for the discount factor, as we have been discussing. They will have full opportunity to appear before a commission and to put their case. The matter will be decided with all the facts in hand, with all the arguments before the judicial persons on the Arbitration Commission and, consequently, a judgment will be made. If a judgment is made along the lines of the argument presented to the Commission by the Government and the Commission comes out in favour of the Government, that decision will flow through to all wage and salary earners in this country.

The point at issue here is that that remains to be argued before and decided by the Arbitration Commission, yet this 2 per cent discount factor is being applied from 1 July this year to pensioners of the Defence Force and Commonwealth superannuation schemes. The discount is being applied without individual members having an opportunity to put before the Commission a case against the Government's decision. Individual members of the Commonwealth pension schemes or of the Defence Force pension schemes have no representative to put their case before a commission and have the matter judged. To that extent there is a difference of treatment of the pensioners who will have this 2 per cent discount applied to them arbitrarily, whereas in the case of wage and salary earners that matter is yet to be determined. That is the basic argument about which we are complaining in respect particularly of the Defence Force pensioners.

This legislation comes at a time when there have been numerous broken promises as far as the treatment of superannuation is concerned. We go back to the earliest days of the Hawke Labor Government, in May 1983, when it first imposed the lump sum superannuation tax. You may recall, Mr Acting Deputy President, that the Opposition raised arguments which could have some force and which were recognised by the Government at the time that this tax, as it would be applied by the Government, would impact heavily upon Defence Force personnel. One of the reasons that it falls unduly heavily on that group is that Defence Force people are compelled to retire at mandatory ages which are somewhat lower than the retiring ages for the general population. For instance, majors who are around 45 years of age are compelled to retire and cannot continue in the Regular Forces until the normal retirement age of 65 years. That means that at the height of their middle age they are required to set about establishing new careers. It was perfectly reasonable that people retiring at that stage of their lives should have been able to obtain a tax free capital sum by commutation of their future pension rights and to use that to invest in a business or some such to get themselves started in new careers. Also, considering the vagaries and the special kind of life which people in the defence forces have to put up with, as they are moved from place to place around the country and perhaps around the world, many times they do not have the opportunity of acquiring a home. A lump sum by way of commutation of their pension benefits is useful in establishing homes for such people while they get their new careers established.

These are the special considerations which apply to Defence Force persons and the sorts of things which this Government failed to recognise when it introduced the lump sum superannuation tax in May 1983. That was just one of the broken promises. We recall quite well that before the election in March 1983 the then Opposition said that there would be no superannuation tax. That was one of the first promises that it broke upon being elected to government. The others are well known to us. For instance, there was the breaking of the promise with regard to the assets test. We well remember Senator Grimes in this place and the National Economic Summit of 1983 saying that there would be no assets test on pensions, but that was broken in the August 1983 Budget.

The Government cannot be trusted in the handling of superannuation matters. That has been demonstrated quite clearly since it came to office three years ago. Now we have seen a further change brought about in such a way as to affect the pension entitlements of Defence Force personnel. After the introduction of the lump sum superannuation tax in 1983 and after much pressure was brought to bear upon the Government by the Liberal and National parties it did recognise to some extent the special problems of Defence Force persons by increasing the amount of the commuted value of pensions. That had the effect, partially at least, of offsetting the impact of the lump sum superannuation tax, but also it reduced the future benefits that pensioners would obtain by virtue of the need for future pensions later in their lives. In other words, the tax was imposed; there was no alleviation of it for this special band of people.

I think it shows a degree of ignorance of the special problems of Defence Force persons that the Government has failed to adjust properly its taxation policies to take account of these special circumstances. We recall the attitude which this Government adopted in 1983 to people who were in the Regular Army Reserve. We recall that, whereas those people had previously had their reserve pay exempted from taxation, the Government sought to tax half of that pay. Now, three years later, with falling recruitment of people into the Reserve, the Government has been forced to go back to the original position of exempting the Reserve pay. That has been announced in the recent Budget. Again that demonstrates an attitude of the part of this Government to take the bat to those people in the Defence Force and reduce their opportunities to look after themselves and their families and to make it difficult for the Force to prosper and develop.

That point of development is essential when we consider the very important requirement of the building of morale for Defence Force personnel, to ensure that they operate at the highest possible levels in their duties in the defence of this nation. That attitude question seems to be one that has slipped straight past this Government in that it has little regard for the problems of maintaining morale. I am sure that honourable senators on this side have had experiences of dealing with personnel from the forces who tell us of the very real problems faced by those in that community and the demoralised attitude which is developing amongst them towards their status, work and position in society. That can have only a downward effect on this nation's preparedness for war if, heaven forbid, that should occur.

That is a principle which we believe is vital to this legislation which is now before us. It is interesting to note that the effect of this 2 per cent discount on Defence Force pensioners' benefits, which will apply from 10 October this financial year, will accumulate. It will never be recovered by those people from future indexation adjustments, except by somebody making an ex gratia payment some time in the future. This means that over a 10-year period the accumulated reduction of such a benefit will amount to more than $2,000 for each pensioner. Those people will be less able to look after themselves in their retirement, which means that they will no doubt find themselves coming back into the social security system by way of age pensions or other benefits in order to protect themselves against the rising cost of living. It is quite possible that what the Government gains here it may well lose in terms of future costs of social security for the people whom it is punishing now in this legislation. All in all, this legislation is aiming to raise from defence people and from those former public servants some $12m. That is the Government's judgment. We have a concern about it, as is evidenced by my remarks. In order to put extra weight to the position of the Liberal and National parties, I move:
At end of motion, add: `, but the Senate-

(a) expresses its concern that the level of discounting of superannuation, Defence Forces Retirement Benefits (DFRB) and Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits (DFRDB) pensions imposed by the legislation has not yet been proposed in a National Wage Case, let alone given effect by a decision of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, and notes that:

(i) the Bill imposes on Commonwealth superannuants, without consultation, a burden greater than that proposed for the community generally, in that it will come into effect before equivalent discounting of wages is even considered,
(ii) discounting of DFRB and DFRDB pensions further erodes conditions of service in the Australian Defence Force (ADF) at a time when ADF resignations are at near-crisis level, and
(iii) the Bill breaks, for the second time, Labor's 1983 election promise not to cut DFRB and DFRDB benefits; and

(b) calls on the Government to direct the Defence Force Remuneration Tribunal, as a matter of urgency, to inquire into the adequacy of pay and conditions of service in the ADF compared with those in the private sector and public service'.

The amendment clearly makes the point that we are concerned about falling morale in the defence forces caused by the Government's approach and exacerbated by this legislation. We are concerned that the Government is not fully cognisant of the problems in the defence forces. We believe that this motion will draw attention to those problems. If it is carried, as I expect it will be, it will at least bring these serious problems to the Government's attention. I commend the amendment to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats oppose the Superannuation and Other Benefits Legislation Amendment Bill, which we believe is yet another manifestation of the Government's policy of economic attack on those people least equipped to fight back and, in many cases, least able to afford it. I listened with considerable care to what Senator Messner said on behalf of the Opposition and to the terms of his amendment. I suggest to him that, if the Opposition really thinks that way, it should join us in opposing the Bill. If the Democrats and the Opposition in the Senate vote against the Bill, it will not pass. If it does not pass, we will have done something of great value for the Australian people, for reasons which I shall proceed to outline and which, I am sure, the Opposition understands. I have discussed this legislation with Mr Sinclair and Senator Messner. I think they see that there is a problem, one which they would very much like to do something about but for certain inhibitions they have about Budget Bills, which I shall later suggest are ephemeral and should not bear directly on this issue.

SPEECH.PARA: It is of great interest to the Democrats that the Government is bringing on this Bill and seeking its passage with almost indecent haste. It was in the House of Representatives only yesterday. I think that this is because the Government understands that there is now a growing groundswell of justifiable protest about the measure and it wants to get the dirty deed over as quickly as possible and with as little media attention as possible. I see the hand of the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, in this measure. He resembles an aging and short-sighted shark in a school of schnapper. He bites up whatever comes into his view without much discrimination or thought.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very good. I could not have said it better.

—I thank Senator Newman. This legislation is certainly short-sighted and thoughtless. Basically, it is designed to short change people on defence and Public Service superannuations. It is a strict short change operation, a breach of a promise and a breaking of undertakings.

SPEECH.PARA: The benefits paid under these superannuation schemes have always been indexed to the consumer price index, with the very reasonable aim of ensuring that a pension is not eroded by inflation. That has been one of the basic principles of government-one we have all striven to support over many years. When one talks to people on pensions, one sees why that is so. They are looking for security in their pensions, without governments meddling and tampering for what they see are political and economic reasons. If the Bill passes, the Government will have destroyed that principle.

The Bill is simple enough. It seeks to pay next month not the 9.2 per cent full indexation, as assessed on the CPI at 31 March last, which is due to many thousands of people, but an amount discounted by 2 per cent to 7.2 per cent. Hence the value of the pension in real terms will be reduced this time and, I suppose we can assume, many times in the future. We are talking about a genuine attack on the income and position of those who in many cases are least able to afford it.

The Government has put forward some very tenuous reasoning. It has claimed that because of wage discounting there should also be superannuation award discounting. Do I hear the voice of the Australian Council of Trade Unions somewhere in this? Of course I do. The Government claims that, because of wage discounting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I can assure you that the ACTU is not very happy about it.

—The Government claims that superannuation should be cut, too, and that one class of people should be discriminated against. That is what it amounts to, and Senator Walsh knows that as well as I do. The Democrats disagree fundamentally with this principle. For most people on superannuation, their pension is their only source of income. They are past the age and stage when they could increase their expectations. All they want is a secure future in which their financial stability is reasonably guaranteed. In many discussions I have had with older people on this issue, the fact has emerged clearly again and again, and it is so important that I will repeat it, that their principal worry is that the Government will meddle with their pensions. The prime consideration is not the amount of the pension, although that is plainly important. The most feared manifestation of government is its tendency to tamper with pensions for political reasons or for what it sees as sound economic reasons. I shall return to that point a little later.

SPEECH.PARA: The point of major interest in the Bill, which I ask everyone who is listening to consider carefully, is that it establishes the principle of cutting back on the indexation of pensions. I ask Opposition senators to consider this point carefully. If the Government gets away with this one, it will feel that it has been given green lights all the way to treat other pensions in the same way. Why should it not feel that way? If we in this place are so silly as to leave open a gate as wide as this, can we not expect that consequence? Of course we can. I believe that the Government already has in mind in a mini-Budget early next year the idea of reducing age pensions, and probably all pensions, by applying the same principle of discounting. The age pension is particularly significant in this regard. I know from contacts in my State of New South Wales, particularly in Sydney, that the present age pension is totally inadequate to provide reasonable accommodation and healthy food. That is a fact. I have been told by social workers and others closely associated with the aged in Sydney, especially central Sydney, that it is not unusual for old people to eat dog and cat food-only the best brands, of course-because meat is too expensive. That is a deplorable shame which we should not tolerate.

This situation of poverty is partly due to the meanness of the pension in terms of today's cost of living but is due also to another factor which I have had occasion to mention here before and which I will go on mentioning as long as I am a senator. I refer to the Government's failure to index the rent allowance paid to pensioners to the cost of living in different parts of Australia. The reason, I am told, is that the Constitution says that all citizens must be treated equally. How far into wonderland can we get? Is it equal treatment to pay the same rent subsidy to a person in Sydney as to a person in, say, a Tasmanian country town? In Sydney, a room in a hovel in Kings Cross will cost more than a small but reasonable apartment in Tasmania or Western Australia. It is not treating people equally to apply the same rent subsidy throughout the country. It is guaranteeing a situation in which there is not only actual hardship in Sydney but even danger to life. In recent years, there have been some extremely nasty cases in which old people have died or been terribly injured because of fires in residential slums which were fire traps. Those elderly people were in those places because that was the only accommodation they could afford.

I suggest that this is an indictment of the Parliament and of the Government. Over the years I have become sick of raising this matter and being told blandly by some public servant in a Minister's office who has drafted a reply that the only reason for this is that the Constitution says that all Australians should be treated equally. It is an Animal Farm situation in which some animals plainly are more equal than others. I repeat: A government attempt to discount age pensions next year and allow those pensions to drop further and further below the poverty line would only increase those hardships. I want to make it quite clear that, if the Bill passes, the principle will have been established and there is every reason to expect its extension to other pensions, regardless of government denials or promises.

As the Opposition amendment before me points out, the Government is breaking a promise that it made in the 1983 election campaign in bringing forward this very Bill we are discussing today concerning Service pensions. The Government, of course, will deny things. It undertook then not to interfere with Service superannuation. Now it is interfering with it. So if we hear later in this debate any Government protestations from the Minister or anybody else that there is no way that they will affect old age pensions, do not believe it, my friends. Do not fall into the trap of Service pensioners who believed what the Government said in 1983 and who will suffer from it today if this Bill is passed.

Let us assume that the Government finds some other schnapper to bite at and that it does not index age pensions in the next mini-Budget. What is the other thing? People are plainly being discriminated against. Here again, not all animals are equal. Some people are going to have their pensions discounted and others are not. Let us get back to the concept of treating all Australians equally. I would suggest that the Minister's public servants, who are discussing this matter so intently at this stage, might consider that point, among others.

Defence Force and Commonwealth Public Service pensions are indexed annually in July, based on the March consumer price index figure. There is, therefore, a 15-month lag already in catching up with the rest of the community. When the superannuation recipient received an increase in July of this year, it was in part compensation for price increases which occurred over 15 months ago. By contrast, the indexation of age pensions and of wages occurs at six-monthly intervals, not annually. In another Budget decision, which, I must say, the Australian Democrats find very untenable and unpalatable, the Government has deferred the age pension indexation by six weeks, and that in itself indicates to us that it is getting bold about this matter and is prepared to interfere with age pensions. What will it do next?

The Government says that by carrying out this measure it is only extending the wage pause to superannuitants-only those superannuitants whom they have it within their power to disadvantage, of course; and that is the point. Is this wage pause corollary reasonable? The Australian Democrats suggest not. We reject this whole idea as discriminatory and totally unfair. So I would like the Minister to say later on, when he replies in this debate, whether the Government intends to extend this to all pensioners or whether it proposes to be discriminatory. To my mind, it has no options other than those two.

This, of course, is not the reduction of a prospective increase; rather, it is the reduction in real terms of an income already being received by pensioners. The discount was not contested before any independent tribunal and no opportunity was given to those who are being discriminated against to make their case to oppose this cut. We are dealing here with pensions paid out from superannuation fund contributions which were, in most cases, compulsory. In the case of the defence forces, the contribution is 5.5 per cent of salary and for permanent officers of the Commonwealth Public Service a contribution of 5 per cent is compulsory. While we disagree with this totally, we believe, for a variety of reasons, that there is an even stronger case for Service pensions than there is for Public Service pensions. As those reasons have been put, I think, by Senator Messner, I will not go over them again. Nevertheless, the former public servants on superannuation are not rich. This is not a fat cat situation. The discount of 2 per cent of the real value of the pension will have a greater effect on the disposable income of a pensioner receiving less than half his former salary than it has on the person in employment. This is the whole point. People in employment have more money; ipso facto, pensioners in virtually every pension scheme in Australia have considerably less. Therefore, a cut bears on them much less fairly and creates much more real and genuine hardship over a period.

On figures that we have, the average income of a superannuated Commonwealth public servant last year was $10,452. That is no princely sum in today's situation. A person who retires at 55 years of age after 10 years in the Public Service will receive 14.4 per cent of his final salary. If that person were to die, his surviving spouse would receive five-eighths of that pension. Many Public Service superannuitants are on pensions akin to the age pension, but without the associated fringe benefits. I think these people are going to suffer particularly badly if this situation continues. I think the Minister ought to tell us in his reply what the Government's intention is. Having established this principle, if economic conditions appear to justify it over a period, will it go on doing this? Will it go on year by year reducing the--

TALK.START.PARA: —Our policy is to ignore the real world and pretend it is not there!
—The Minister might like to take up the point when I have finished my speech and he is replying. I agree with him; he does ignore the real world and pretends that it is not there.
—It is something we picked up from you.

—It is time the Minister went out and found out how people in the community live. They do not live as well as rich farmers from Western Australia who also get a Senate salary. It is time that the Minister went out into the real world and had a talk to them to find out what it is really about. He should have done that before he started cutting their incomes about in this callous and unregarding way.

SPEECH.PARA: It is no wonder at all that this action is considered by the Defence Force and Commonwealth Public Service communities to be a breach of trust. It is a breach of trust. These people went into the service of this country on the clear understanding, as set out in legislation, that they would receive a certain income on retirement after paying a considerable amount of their salaries into superannuation. That promise is about to be broken. Their incomes will never catch up with what they should be. Every future increase will be calculated on a diminished figure, and it will become more and more difficult for these people to afford accommodation, food and the basic necessities. This will apply especially in the higher cost areas of the country, including my own constituency in the city of Sydney. It is my duty and my job to get up here and remind the Government of what it is doing to those people in Sydney. It is also my duty to implore the Opposition to do something. The Liberal and National people have a big responsibility here not to let this Bill get through. In spite of the decision they have made on this matter, they ought to vote against the legislation. They know what they should do as well as I do.

I would like to read two quotes from letters that are not exceptional. We have had many letters on this subject and these quotes are indicative of the feelings of most people on superannuation. They are plain and simple statements, but they are to the point. The first is from a Mr Wrigley, who wrote:

On joining the Public Service, I was forced to join the Superannuation Scheme and the relevant payment, as decided by the Government, was automatically deducted from my pay each fortnight. Over the years the pensions on retirement entitlements were published and, of course, in taking the final decision whether to retire or not, these entitlements were very carefully scrutinised.

I can see what this gentleman is talking about. He had to assess the whole of his future-what he bought, what sort of car he would have, his house, his furniture and everything else-on what his expectations were. The average person's expectations would be based only on the superannuation payment. There is no way that he can go out and get another job and do things like that. We know what the job market is like now for elderly people. The second quote is from a Mr McLennan, who said:

When I was employed by the Commonwealth Public Service, I understood that the conditions of employment were binding on both the employer and employee. One of the conditions was to contribute to the Superannuation Fund. Therefore at retirement I anticipated that the Government would honour its commitment to pay the superannuation pension in accord with the 1976 Act.

His view is a perfectly reasonable one. One does not expect governments to break their financial undertakings. If a commercial organisation broke its undertakings in the way the Government is breaking this undertaking by using the weapon of legislation, it would be taken to court because it would be regarded as committing a crime.

TALK.START.PARA: —They would probably be put in gaol.

—As Senator Vigor says, probably the person responsible would be put in gaol if he had managed to con elderly people into somehow accepting such a proposition over a period. What the Government is doing is a very serious matter. It is even more serious when we consider that in 1973 the Defence Force superannuation scheme was transferred from an investment trust to Consolidated Revenue on the clear understanding that contributors would be in no way disadvantaged. That is a matter of fact. No doubt the contributors felt that governments of the future would honour their commitments. Not only are those contributors being disadvantaged, but so are all future Defence Force superannuitants and all Commonwealth Public Service superannuitants.

SPEECH.PARA: Members of the Defence Force are under a particular disadvantage in this situation. Because their contributions are paid into Consolidated Revenue, if members of the Defence Force decide to leave before 20 years service, I understand their contributions are returned to them with no interest. They are in effect giving the Government a subsidised loan through their superannuation contributions. When their final superannuation is calculated, they receive 35 per cent of their final salary after 20 years service. The Government now proposes to disadvantage even further these people who, in fact, give the Government interest free loans.

As we all know, the armed forces are having the greatest difficulty in retaining well qualified professional staff. They are very badly paid. I have looked at service housing and things of that kind and I am concerned when I talk to senior non-commissioned officers whose job is to train people in parachuting, weapons use, skills and occupations demanding teaching skills and tact, and often with elements of danger. They are paid very small sums of money. Given their salaries, and the many moves that they have to make, it is not likely that they will save very much during their service career which, as we know, is short because they are retired early. They need this superannuation payment. Their retirement is based on their being able to rely on the superannuation payment. That is what the Government wants to destroy. The Minister for Finance finds this so unpalatable that he is now leaving the chamber. It is probably a damned good idea that he should.

TALK.START.PARA: —You will be leaving it permanently soon.
—I hope that the Minister will be leaving it permanently soon. After the things that he said about us this morning, I think he should consider it. I have no respect for him.
—You will all be leaving it permanently soon-and a good thing too.

—The Minister should get back to his dirt cupboard. The discounting of retirement benefits would greatly increase the rate of loss of professionals from the services. There is no doubt about that. Any organisation will tell the Government that. It will cost the Government far more than it will receive. That is what I meant about the Minister being a short-sighted elderly shark. He has not thought about those sorts of consequences, but they are there. Anybody in the armed services, anybody who has retired from them and any of the service organisations could have told the Minister that. Any of the higher officers in the Army could tell him this. The Government will lose people and money because of this action. It will be taxpayers' money that is lost in order for the Government to get a miserable sum of money. It will be just a few million dollars that the Government will get from it and it will lose a lot more than that.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill could very well prove to be counter-productive, at least in relation to the Defence Force. The Federal President of the Armed Forces Federation of Australia wrote to Senator Haines on 22 September. He made some very good points which I commend to the Minister. He said:

At a time when Defence Force resignations are at a post-war high, such a proposal provides little incentive for retaining committed personnel. The Bill will have a heavy impact on what can only be described as marginal payments, yet the total savings expected could be lost by the resignation of less than ten front line pilots.

That is what I mean by short-sighted and thoughtless. In the last two months the Royal Australian Air Force has lost 22 pilots, each trained at a cost to the community of more than $1m. They left the Defence Force because of just this sort of penny pinching measure. Indeed, over 560 male officers have resigned from the Defence Force this year. The cost to the Government of denying this Budget measure is estimated at $4.7m for Defence Force superannuation and $7.9m for public service superannuation this year. These are not massive amounts. By way of comparison, a massive $274m is being spent this year, not very far from here, on construction costs for the new Parliament House-that monolith that will cost over $1 billion. It will be the world's first $1 billion building. Does the Government have any right to bring in a Bill to cut back on an undertaking to people in order to save $4.7m when it is quite prepared to spend so much money on something that will not be of any real value to the people of this country? Flesh and blood should come before bricks and mortar. That is the way the Minister should look at it. We are aware that the $274m is being spent in an effort to have the building completed by the bicentennial year of 1988. Big deal! We must ask ourselves what is more important-the welfare of elderly people in our community or a massive and very expensive monument to the Parliament of this country. The Minister should think about getting rid of or perhaps deferring that ridiculous flagstaff which has cost such an enormous amount.

The Opposition has said that it will support this legislation because it is a necessary part of Supply, because it is a Budget Bill. I often wonder whether the Opposition wonders why we are here. What are we here for? Are we here to allow the Government to get away with any kind of murder just because it does so in the context of the Budget? Of course we are not. In this instance we are not touching or meddling with Supply. We get the constant talk and buzz that every time we look at or try to stop a Budget Bill we are said to be blocking Supply. I want to deal briefly with this matter. The Bill that was blocked in 1975 when the Whitlam Government was dismissed was Appropriation Bill (No. 1). That action took away the overall revenues from the Government and it could not pay the public servants or continue with the business of governing the country. From our inception, the Australian Democrats have said-and we maintain this view-that we will never use our balance of power in the Senate to connive with the Opposition to block Appropriation Bill (No. 1). We never will. But that is another matter. It is deceptive and wrong to raise that issue. People who run around with the story that, because this is a Budget Bill, we must regard it as sacrosanct and that to vote against it is equivalent to blocking Supply are attempting to deceive the people. I know that everybody in the Parliament knows that that is so, but it is bad that people go around spreading this stupid idea which misinforms the Australian people.

If the Opposition feels strongly about this, as it says it does in its amendment, it should vote with us against the second reading to defeat the Bill. The Bill ought to be thrown out. The Democrats believe that a clear breach of conduct is contemplated by the Government in this legislation and therefore it should be rejected as a matter of ordinary equity.

Meanwhile, we have looked at the Opposition amendment. It has no real effect. It is an amendment to the motion for the second reading. It does not affect the Bill. It will have no effect whatsoever on what the Bill does. However, it says various pious and useful things. If the Bill passes, as, regretfully, I believe it may do, it is better that it pass with at least that attachment than for that attachment not to be there. We will support the Opposition's amendment and we will vote against the second reading of the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad that the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) is in the chamber because I must here declare my interest in this matter as the wife of a returned serviceman who fought for his country in Malaya and Vietnam. I am glad to have him here and know that that is why I have an interest in this matter. However, I am afraid that I must take issue with Senator Mason and immediately say that, although he supported the servicemen, I am afraid that the Australian Democrats are masquerading here and are hypocrites. The Australian Democrats talk about blocking the Budget and the legal distinction between what is a Budget measure and what is an Appropriation Bill but they were not too fine on that point over the years when they trumpeted about how they would never stop the Government's Budget measures.
—We have said that we will not block Supply.

—The Democrats were very strong on this point. It seems to suit them to say different things at different times. Senator Mason knows as well as I do that the Government must answer for its Budget and this is a financial measure which affects the Government's ability to implement its Budget measures. Regrettably, we will not block this measure. I challenge Senator Mason to support our amendment in a meaningful way.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government has been breaking promises to the servicemen. Senator Mason has said so. He has said that the Government is short changing the servicemen and the public servants with this superannuation measure. I would call it straight out robbery, and I do not think that that is putting too fine a point on it.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will vote for your amendments.

—Thank you. I am very glad to have Senator Mason's reassurance. These servicemen and women, these employees of the Commonwealth, have been receiving pensions since the beginning of this financial year. It is interesting to look at the number of people who will be affected by this measure. As at 30 June 1985 the number of pensioners from the Department of Defence was 30,589, the number of public servants 74,635, and those from Papua New Guinea 714. So we are not talking about a small part of the Australian population; we are talking about a very large number of Australians who are having their benefits and entitlements stolen from them by this Government. I rather like Senator Mason's description of the Minister for Finance as the shark. That is apt and appropriate. I did not know that Senator Mason had such poetry in his soul. It would be interesting to know what the Australian Council of Trade Unions would have to say if its members were having cash refunds taken away from them. This is money taken out of their hands.
—You stupid woman, ACTU affiliates are being affected. They are the main people who are being affected, you silly woman.
—Order! The words used by the Minister are unparliamentary. I ask him to withdraw.
—I called her a silly woman. If that is unparliamentary, I withdraw.

—Most Australians recognise that the ACTU represents people in work. It does not represent the unemployed or the retired. It only looks after people who are on better and better salaries through the present Government's inflationary system. I would like to know what Senator Cook, Senator Devlin and Senator Harradine would say if their union members were being asked to take a cut in wages. For example, our own parliamentary messengers in this place, many of them returned servicemen, took jobs here because they could afford to as they had some sort of back-up pension. Now Senator Walsh and his Government are cutting those pensions and taking away rights on which people have planned for their later years. The Government's lack of honour is demonstrated in the way it is treating mortgagors in the Australian Capital Territory. The Government has no regard for keeping its word and is totally without honour.

SPEECH.PARA: This measure will save $4.7m this year and $6.3m in a full year. Let me go through some of the measures which the Government regards as priorities. For example, women surfboard riders can have $11,000, and Mr Keating can have $17,000-odd for not sleeping in his own bed. If one is a unionist, and only in that case, one will be able to take part in a $1m art in working life program, but a working person who is not in a union will not be eligible to participate. Prisoners take out $1.4m in dole moneys. Those who wish to defend the America's Cup are to be given $30m, but we cannot afford to defend our country. These are just a few ways in which this Government sets its priorities for spending its money.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the people's money.

—It is the people's money; that is correct. If the Government gave more thought to where the money came from it would probably spend the money more wisely. The Government spends as if money is going out of fashion. Assistance to mortgagors and pensioners is being removed unilaterally. There has been no consultation and no consensus. Consensus applies only when it suits this Government. There is not opportunity for pensioners to put their case to any sort of industrial tribunal. We are talking about compulsory contributions which were made in the belief that the Government's word would be honoured.

SPEECH.PARA: The Defence Force retirement and death benefit pensioners have contributed 5.5 per cent of their annual salary over 20 years; they were compulsory contributions. What are the effects on the recipients? Typically, they average about $9,900 a year and they will lose $161.54. Compare that with the age pensioners who are being asked to wait and who will lose $26.40. A submission from the Armed Forces Federation makes clear that a typical married service pensioner will receive only $231 a year more in the hand than equivalent recipients of the age pension, despite contributing 5.5 per cent of his annual service salary over 20 years towards the cost of his pension. The Federation points out that at a time when Defence Force resignations are at a post-war high, such a proposal provides little incentive for retaining committed personnel.

The Regular Defence Force Welfare Association has pointed out that the change represents a diminution in the conditions of service for those now serving. It also says that there has been enough tinkering with conditions of service for members of the regular Defence Force over the past few years. Anybody who knows anything about the defence forces will recognise that there may have been tinkering, but certainly not enough attention has been given to the conditions of service of our servicemen and women. They are voting with their feet, and Senator Mason has already referred to the alarming resignations in the defence forces.

At this stage I wish to refer to evidence given to Estimates Committee E on 18 September. Commodore Dickson said that the Defence Force was unable to maintain the professional standards that were attainable in times when more resources were provided. So there is criticism about what the Government is doing in the Services. Obviously the Services are not able to maintain professional standards when training time and steaming time are limited. Commodore Dickson in responding to a question by Senator MacGibbon said:

There is a 23 per cent shortfall on HMAS Platypus as at present. We have 493 sailors out of a target of 603, so we have 81 per cent of the manning we desire. We have 92 officers out of a target of 111, or 82 per cent. That has come up since April. In respect of the other ranks, sailors have gone from 454 to 493 and officers from 86 to 92.

It was said that there was an Army officer wastage rate of approximately 10 per cent. Any thinking Australian will ask what is happening. We cannot afford to go on like this. This country has only 0.8 of a pilot per aircraft. If these are not serious matters, I do not know what are. This Government is going on cutting away at any conditions of service that servicemen currently enjoy. Wing Commander Mills, who has recently retired, claimed in the Defence Force Journal that the RAAF manpower was at a critical point. He said that if loss rates increased without an increase in manpower allocation, operational tasks would have to be surrendered. Air Commodore Prior, referring to this matter in the Estimates Committee on 18 September, said:
As to the effects of increased wastage rates and the necessity to shed tasks, this is a threatening issue that is with us all the time.

It is no good this Government making the headlines as to what it intends to do about the defence forces. The fact is that when it comes to the crunch the Government is cutting, cutting, cutting at the conditions of the men and women who are here to serve and protect this country.

These are not the only matters to be borne in mind. We all know what service people have to put up with in their terms and conditions of service. They face difficulties with removals and in many cases live in intolerable housing conditions. They have difficulties with their children and face educational problems in moving from State to State. Their spouses have problems looking for employment and they have a lack of extended family to give them support in times of need. This Government, to its credit, brought in Sue Hamilton to look into the conditions of service. She came up with a number of recommendations which the Services and the families have welcomed. But what has this Government done? It has set up a team-which is fine-and will monitor these conditions, but the progress of that monitoring will be private because no progress reports will be made public. The rest of us will not know what is happening to the conditions of service of servicemen and women, and I express my fears as to what will happen.

Once these things get into the maw of the bureaucracy, where finance, national wage implications, flow-ons and industrial relations implications have to be taken into account, God help the poor servicemen because they are at the very end of a long line. With all these problems, these servicemen and women serve on. We know full well that they will serve on for their fixed terms until their retiring ages. They expect that in return, having put up with the inconvenience, discomforts and problems that service life brings, at least their pension entitlements will remain inviolate. This is typical of the way this Government treats servicemen.

Look at what the Government did to the tax deductibility for the Reserve. My side of the Parliament told the Government what would happen about that, but it would not listen. What happened? The target last year for the Army Reserve was 26,500. Last year the Government started with 23,772 and finished with 23,539. The Government spent $2.5m on an advertising campaign in order to lose 537 men and women, but in the course of the year it lost 7,411 members of the Reserve. The Government lost 9,535 people in the previous year. So over two years it lost nearly 17,000 Reserve personnel from a force of under 24,000. So much for protecting this country. When we got to the Estimates Committee we found that the Department of Defence admitted that the efficient strength of the Reserve is only 17,000. That is the number of people who can be deemed to be in training. So the Government's figures, even for the Reserve forces, are pretty rubbery.

The next item must be right up Senator Walsh's alley; it is probably due directly to him personally. We find that there are delays, sometimes up to months, in paying the men and women in the Reserve the amounts due to them. Is that on instructions from the Department of Finance?

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right.

—Yes, that sounds right. That is the way it treats the servicemen. They used to get paid straightaway, but now they have to wait. In at least one State they have been attending some parades in their own time. Due to government restrictions on man days, courses have been cut for recruits and drivers and camp periods have been cut. Only the best shots are being given ammunition for weapons training because ammunition cannot be wasted. Bad luck if the enemy happens to meet one of those bad shots who has not had any training!

SPEECH.PARA: A report has been given to the Hawke Government which recommends a continuous 3 per cent real growth in expenditure on defence. The Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) is trumpeting that the proposal will be implemented, but what is the reality? We have a Budget with rubbery figures trying to demonstrate a one per cent real growth in defence spending, yet the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment (Mr Cohen) is boasting how he saved his Department from cuts. Obviously this Government's priority is for cakes, not bread.

This nation cannot afford to put its defence and the welfare of its servicemen and women at the end of the queue. Our servicemen and women and their morale are vital to an efficient, trained defence force. Attempts such as this current legislation to cut once more and break one more promise on superannuation will be one more nail in the coffin of the defence of this country. We cannot afford this economy measure. I call on the Government to get its priorities right and I urge the Senate to support the Opposition's amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh so genteel, sanctimonious, ersatz upper middle class Liberals offer and pontificate about unions and industrial relations. In the process they exhibit their ignorance, and we have just had a magnificent exhibition of that tonight. Senator Newman should have stuck to the script that somebody else wrote for her and not decided to interpolate some comments of her own. She challenged the Government and Senator Cook, among others, to say what they would do if the Government were proposing something which affected the membership of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. The plain fact is that of the 112,000 people or thereabouts who will be affected by this measure, approximately 80,000 of them are Commonwealth superannuation scheme pensioners who have been or are members of Public Service unions, almost all of which are affiliated with the ACTU. Senator Newman is a silly woman who could not have been wider of the mark than she was. Three-quarters of the effects of this measure are directed at members or former members of unions which are affiliated with the ACTU. You could not have been more wrong, you dopy creature.
—Order! The Minister will withdraw that remark.

—I withdraw. Senator Newman could not have been more wrong. Before she gets up, pontificating and throwing around what she thinks is a smart jibe at the ACTU, she had better do a bit of homework about unions, industrial relations, and who is affiliated with whom. Senator Newman declared that she had a vested interest in this question-and she does. I do not know whether she wants me to spell out some of the details of it. Her spouse receives a parliamentary pension of about $13,000 a year, having previously commuted a lump sum of $130,000. In addition to that he receives a Defence Force retirement benefits pension of another $13,000 a year or thereabouts, and he commuted a lump sum; I do not know how big that lump sum was. So he is doubly superannuated, as well as being a spouse of a member of the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: We have seen yet again the sort of disgusting performance from the coalition that we saw earlier today. The Australian Democrats were their usual mixture of irresponsible opportunism, coupled with occasional flights away with the fairies, whereas the Liberals displayed their usual stupidity, opportunism and cowardice. I will return to the question of cowardice when I delve into the Clayton's amendment the Liberal Party of Australia has moved, which demonstrates a fundamental cowardice and dishonesty. One point was made, if not in the debate in the House of Representatives then about which members of the Opposition in the House were told. This cowardly, tatty little amendment that has been moved on behalf of the Opposition expresses concern at the level of discounting of superannuation and Defence Force retirement benefits imposed by the legislation which has not yet been proposed in a national wage case. I know that there is an abundance of ignorance on the other side of the Parliament on all matters pertaining to industrial relations and unionism, but I would have thought that even the members of the Opposition might have noticed that there has already been a 2 per cent wage discount and that the Government is seeking a further 2 per cent wage discount. If they were too far or too often away with the fairies to have noticed that that happened, some members of the Opposition were briefed yesterday and told that that was the case. So the premise upon which almost the entire Opposition argument is based is patently false. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Queensland: Out of Court Defamation Settlement

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being near the hour of 7 o'clock, I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators will be aware that there have been allegations that the Premier of Queensland, Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen, benefited from a defamation pay-out from Brisbane television station Channel 9. It has been suggested that Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen received a settlement of $400,000. Today certain documents were released by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal relating to its investigation of the Premier's out of court settlement. These documents did not reveal a settlement figure.

SPEECH.PARA: It may be necessary for me to expand on my comments on this matter on a future sitting day. This evening, however, I just indicate to honourable senators that I have today made a request to the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal under the Freedom of Information Act. I have requested all documents held by the Tribunal relating to this out of court defamation payment. I trust these documents will reveal that settlement figure. I agree with the Opposition Leader in Queensland, Mr Warburton, that the matter must be pursued. In view of the gravity of the allegations which have been made, I trust that the Tribunal will act on my request expeditiously.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
